title: Currency Realignment Needed, Spaniard Says
description: Spain believes that a further realignment of currency rates in the European monetary system will probably be necessary before the end of the year and that changes are necessary to restore stability to the system, Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga said in a recent interview.

title: Jar in Iranian Ruins Betrays Beer Drinkers of 3500 B.C.
description: They must have had some bibulous days and nights six millenniums ago at the Sumerian trading post of Godin Tepe, in the Zagros Mountains of what is now western Iran. Archeologists can tell by sampling the dregs.

title: Spartan Motors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company mis listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Parting of the Ways
description: The occasionally stormy but undeniably nonpareil professional partnership between MARTINA NAVRATILOVA and PAM SHRIVER, the most dominant doubles team in the history of women's tennis, is about to end.

title: CAE Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rockwell International Has Profit Drop of 9% in Quarter
description: The Rockwell International Corporation reported a 9 percent decline in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings today and a 20 percent drop for the year before a special charge. Analysts said the results were within expectations.

title: Net Income at Woolworth Rose by 59% in 3d Quarter
description: The Woolworth Corporation posted a 59 percent increase yesterday in third-quarter earnings as the retailer's store reorganization program continued to improve results.

title: Ross Studies Stock Sales
description: Stock sales by the founder and a former officer of Ross Cosmetics Distribution Centers Inc. are under investigation by the company on suspicion they kept proceeds that should have been given to the company, spokesmen said today.

title: Reviews/Fashion; The 30's Inspire Lauren To Change His Style
description: RALPH LAUREN, fashion's leading traditionalist, has changed his style. He hasn't gone crazy, of course -- just loosened things up, mixed pieces around. He has gone back to the 1930's for inspiration. The 1960's and 1970's, to which some designers here and abroad have returned, are much too close and too familiar for him.

title: With Help, New York High Tech Could Rival Silicon Valley
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN TOURISTS ARE TO BE FREED
description: A Federal magistrate today cleared the way for 15 more Malaysian visitors to go home as soon as they give videotaped testimony as witnesses in a smuggling case that has kept them detained in county jails for two weeks. And she ordered that process speeded up.

title: GENERAL MOTORS UNIT OPENS NEW PLANT IN ENGLAND
description: The General Motors Corporation's Adam Opel unit of Germany opened a new auto engine plant yesterday in Ellesmere Port, in northern England. The company said it had invested $364.3 million in the plant, which would produce low-emission Ecotec V-6 car engines. Ecotec stands for emission consumption optimization technology. Maximum annual production at the plant, which will employ 450, is estimated at 135,000 engines a year.

title: Police Abuse of Homeless Splits North Carolina City
description: Norman Ben Hannah could not make out who had thrown lukewarm oil on his face as he lay under a railroad trestle. Later, he said he heard laughing and, through the greasy film that stung his eyes, he could see a police car pull away.

title: Incumbency Keeps Balance Intact
description: For nearly 20 years, one overarching feature of state government in Albany has been division: the Democrats in control of the Assembly, the Republicans ruling the State Senate and a governor often wringing his hands over his seeming inability to bring them together. Consciously or not, state voters firmly ratified more of the same on Tuesday.

title: Adolescent Obesity Linked to Adult Ailments
description: Being overweight during the teen-age years can lead to life-threatening chronic disease in adulthood, even if the youngster later sheds the excess weight, according to new findings from a study spanning more than 60 years. The study indicated that adolescent obesity was even more strongly linked to health risks than being overweight in adult life.

title: Mario the Magician Offers Thrill a Minute
description: Watching Mario Lemieux perform, now, while his hockey powers are at their peak, is like watching the man walking the high-wire at the circus. On any given day, you may see the most thrilling show of a lifetime, or you may see one false move that brings about the sudden end of a career.

title: Citgo Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Citgo Petroleum said that both third quarter and year-to-date figures have been restated to reflect an accounting change. In addition, the company said both 1992 periods were negatively affected by reduced production while a catalytic cracking unit at the company's Lake Charles, La., manufacturing complex was being repaired.Citgo Petroleum is owned by a unit of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., the national oil company of Venezuela.

title: Cairo Dish (Best Eaten on Street) Is a Big Hit
description: Perched behind a green wooden donkey cart, Hanafi Mohammed al-Gahsh nightly transforms a tiny patch of Cairo into a kingdom.

description: b-Pro forma, reflecting pro forma tax provision as if the company, which was treated as an S Corporation during the first 9 months of 1991, had been subject to corporate income taxes during the period.

description: Mums Under Glass New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park section of the Bronx; (212) 220-8777.

title: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: REACTION Off the Trail: Visits With Americans; New Hampshire Voter Recalls Clinton's Stern Test
description: Bill Clinton arrived at Phil and Ann Ackerman's house on a snowy night nine months ago, plummetting through a double-digit fall in his poll standings. His Presidential campaign was failing and a pack of news reporters was staked out on Mr. Ackerman's icy driveway.

title:
CURRENTS;
Small Temples for Book Worshipers
description: OF the current crop of architects who design objects and furnishings for the home and office, Michael Graves seems to be one of the most prolific. To his design collection of teapots, clocks, leather goods, chairs and bed linens, he recently added bookends that resemble miniature, abstract versions of his buildings. Three styles -- two with openings that look like windows, one without -- are available.

title: FLY-FISHING WITH: Leigh H. Perkins; Such Joy, Where a River Always Runs
description: IT was a perfect day for curling up in front of a fireplace. The sky was battleship gray. The air was dank with drizzle and sleet and fog. To any sensible person, the weather could only be called dismal.

title: Quaker Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 5,675,000 from the cumulative effect on prior periods of accounting changes for income taxes and for postretirement benefits other than pensions.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: D'Amato: Combining Money, Attacks and Foe's Blunders
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's campaign strategists describe their remarkable defeat of New York Attorney General Robert Abrams as a long, brilliantly plotted march to victory. But it might not have happened had it not been for a word.

title: Hudson Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3

description: BARNEYS NEW YORK, New York, named Charles W. Bunstine 2d senior vice president and chief operating officer. CHIRAL TECHNOLOGIES, Exton, Pa., a unit of Daicel Chemical Industries Ltd., appointed Thomas B. Lewis president and chief executive.

title: Move to Limit Terms Gathers Steam After Winning in 14 States
description: The national movement to impose term limits on members of Congress gathered momentum today following sweeping approval of such limits by voters in 14 states Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 28 about the financial condition of the General Motors Corporation misstated the company's fiscal practices regarding its pension fund. While it is illegal to use pension fund assets to pay for operations, G.M. has employed the common corporate practice of spending on operations cash that might otherwise have been contributed to its pension fund.

title: Richard W. Hall, 65, an Author Who Specialized in Gay Themes
description: Richard W. Hall, the author of six books of fiction and a collection of plays, all on gay themes, and a book critic, died last Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nassau Clerk's Race Requires More Paperwork Before Decision
description: For months, the Nassau County Clerk's office has been plagued by lengthy backlogs in handling paperwork. Now, a special election to choose a new county clerk is mired in a delay of its own. And again, huge amounts of paper will be decisive.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CARGILL INC., Minneapolis, has reached an agreement to acquire a fruit-juice processing operation in Frostproof, Fla., from Proctor & Gamble Co. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. IVAX CORP., Miami, announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Norton Healthcare Ltd., had completed the acquisition of certain assets of the British generic pharmaceutical operations of Medeva P.L.C. for $37 million.

title: In Russia, the Coup Against Yeltsin Has Begun
description: To the Editor;

title: Utilicorp United reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 3.9 million after-tax charge in the quarter and a $ 7.4 million charge in the 9 months due to a previously reported investigation into a misappropriation of funds at a subsidiary.

title:
CURRENTS;
The Fold-Up Chair Gets Some Respect
description: IN its ready-for-use state, it looks somewhat like an overgrown duffel bag. Folded up it resembles a large, flat handbag. Henner Kuckuck, a New York sculptor, designed the Spine Chair K-1 as an exercise in origami. He has succeeded in folding a sheet of vinyl into a seamless construction capable of supporting 300 pounds. An internal metal structure gives it shape and allows it to collapse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: CNA Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: CNA Financial Corp. said that its latest third-quarter results were significantly affected by Hurricane Andrew.

title: Bomb Defect Called Key to Chief's Escape
description: The Yonkers police commissioner survived an apparent attempt on his life on Tuesday because an explosive planted in or under his car malfunctioned, according to a city official.

title: Dinkins's Former Aide Is Sentenced for Embezzlement
description: Arnold I. Biegen, the former finance chairman of Mayor David N. Dinkins's re-election campaign, received the same sentence yesterday from a state judge that he got last week in Federal court -- 35 months in Federal prison.

title: Foreign Affairs; Who Gets What Jobs
description: While the world waits to hear who will be Bill Clinton's Secretary of State, the President-elect is thinking more about strategy than names.

title: Bio-Rad Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that third quarter earnings reflected $ 4.1 million of pre-tax income resulting from net gains on sales of marketable securities. Also, $ 600,000 of gains from securities sales were recorded in 1991's third quarter.Bio-Rad said that 1992 earnings to date reflected the following pre-tax non-operating items recorded during the second and third quarters: a gain of $ 21.6 million from the settlement of an eminent domain action, a loss of $ 2.4 million for the estimated cost of certain unresolved legal disputes and a $ 6.3 million net gain from the sale of marketable securities.In the second quarter, the company said it also recorded $ 8.1 million in charges against operating earnings related to the downsizing of certain manufacturing operations.

title: Backer Spielvogel's Heir Apparent
description: After intense speculation, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide made clear who is most likely to succeed Carl Spielvogel as chairman and chief executive. The agency yesterday named Michael Bungey president and to the new post of chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: Ruble Falls to 593 to Dollar
description: The ruble fell to a new low of 593 to the dollar in futures trading at the Moscow Commodity Exchange today.

description: One of El Salvador's most powerful military leaders has lashed out at a plan to purge scores of officers for human rights violations and other reasons, saying the officers are considering steps to fight their dismissal.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FIXING a fluorescent light that does not light or that exhibits mysterious symptoms is usually fairly easy if you understand how fluorescent lights work.

Bridge
description: Good players understand that when prospects look hopeless as declarer they should assume a favorable lie of the cards and play for a long shot. But they do not always apply the same guideline in defense. This was pointed out by Anders Brunzell, a frequent member of the Swedish international team, in an entry in the Bols Bridge Tips contest organized by the International Bridge Press Association.

description: The German Government is supposed to move to Berlin by 1998. To get ready, the national Parliament moved last week into a new $171 million building in Bonn with glass walls.

Europe Ready to Open Talks With Finland
description: The European Community's executive body recommended today that the community open membership talks with Finland, but it said that Helsinki must promise to drop its longstanding policy of neutrality.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Oct. 23 reported the waning of environmentalist resistance to disposable diapers. An adjoining chart illustrated environmental costs of cloth diapers versus disposable ones; in four categories out of six, disposable diapers were depicted as kinder to the environment.

title: The Talk of Paris; Backstage Drama at Paris Opera
description: The opera season in Paris has lurched to life this fall with interesting productions at three different sites. That's not counting Peter Brook's latest streamlined opera, "Pelleas Impressions," which is to open at his Bouffes du Nord theater here on Nov. 13.

title: Critic's Notebook; New Spice To Season TV Oldies, Mildly
description: While gray hair obviously hasn't put a crimp in Bill Clinton's ambitions, the slightest sign of age or aging is enough to make some skittish broadcasters dive for the cancellation button. These are the network executives propounding a single and hardly unassailable advertising rule: young audiences, good (they spend more); older audiences, not so good (they're more careful). So Fox Broadcasting, waving its "Beverly Hills 90210" banner, traffics almost exclusively in youthful romps featuring pretty faces and taut muscles.

title: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: CONGRESS
description: District-by-district results of the contests for the U.S. House of Representatives appear on pages B18-B19.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 165,000, or 3 cents a share, and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 273,000, or 5 cents a share.c-Net lossd-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,568,000 and $ 1,842,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary charge from reversal of net operating loss carryforward of $ 105,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 605,000, or 12 cents a share, in the 9 months.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

description: b-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Shifting Field of Battle, Incumbents Win Handily
description: It was supposed to be the year of the outsider, but all 10 incumbent members of the House of Representatives won re-election on Tuesday. The reason, candidates and other analysts say, is that voters judged the candidates individually rather than sweeping them away in a wave of anger at Congress and President Bush.

title: Russell J. Cooper; Industrialist, 74
description: Russell J. Cooper, the founder, owner and president of the Consolidated Metals Corporation in Dover, N.J., died on Tuesday at his home in Essex Fells, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: Fernandez Broadens Plan To Permit School Choice
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday that empty seats in any of New York City's elementary and junior high schools would have to be made available to children from other districts as part of a new school choice plan.

title: Coalition Government Falls Apart in Ireland
description: The small but powerful party that gave Prime Minister Albert Reynolds the votes needed to run a coalition Government turned against him tonight, and its officials said they had withdrawn from the Government and would vote for its collapse in Parliament on Thursday.

title: It's Live Spots Only At WFMT Radio

title: PHIBRO HEAD TO SELL 20,000 SHARES OF SALOMON STOCK
description: Andrew Hall, chairman of Salomon Inc.'s Phibro Energy Inc. subsidiary, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 20,000 of his shares of Salomon. Salomon's shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $34.75. At that price, the shares Mr. Hall plans to sell would be worth $695,000. In August, Mr. Hall owned 568,988 shares, according to the Washington Service, which tracks stock sales by corporate insiders, and has since sold 60,000 shares. Mr. Hall, also a member of Salomon's board of directors, was not immediately available for comment, and a Salomon spokesman declined comment.

title: 17 Hurt Fighting Fire In TriBeCa Building

title: Teacher Walkout Threatened
description: Teacer union officials say they plan a one-day walkout against the Los Angeles school system next week unless stalled contract negotiations over pay cuts are resolved by then. A spokeswoman for the system, Diana Munatones, said tghe district wold hire substitute teachers and reassign administrators to schools open if the walkout, planned for Nov. 13, occurs. Teachers face a 9 percent salary cut in paychecks this Friday. Two weeks ago, union members voted to authorize a strike, but no strike deadline has been set and negotiations have continued. District officials say the salary cuts are necessary because of a $400 million budget shortfall.

title: Review/Film; Father, Son and One Dead Fish
description: "Fathers and Sons" is actually about only one father -- Max Fish (Jeff Goldblum), a former bad-boy movie director now living in mock-modest circumstances on the Jersey Shore -- and one son (Rory Cochrane). Beyond that, it is in no way succinct. As written and directed by Paul Mones, this is the torpid, myopic story of two brooding loners in a cute setting, to which the film pays unhelpfully rapt attention. "Things change; things remain the same," says the teen-age son, Ed, as the camera lingers lovingly on a bleak shot of the beach.

description: Cucina just celebrated its second anniversary last month on this graffiti-strewn block on the fringes of Park Slope, and already it's a Brooklyn institution. Young, up-and-coming business types stop at the friendly bar after work for a drink before dinner; romantic couples and boisterous groups go for the wide-ranging Italian-based menu, and families go for special occasions. One recent night, there were at least five birthday parties, each assisted by a waiter with a stentorian tenor whose rendition of "Happy Birthday" rang out with operatic elan.

title: NEC BEGINS SHIPPING A NEW SERIES OF 64-BIT CHIPS
description: The NEC Corporation yesteraday began shipping a new series of 64-bit microprocessors for use as the main controllers of work stations and other high-powered personal computers. The new chips are reduced instruction set computing products. RISC chips use a different processing and calculation method that allows the chip to carry out more instructions per second, increasing a computer's speed. RISC chips are commonly found in powerful computers that handle large amounts of data. NEC's new chips, which sell for a sample price of 400,000 yen, or $3,250, each, will be mass-produced beginning in April 1993. They have reduced power consumption and clock speeds as fast as 150 megahertz.

title: PRIMERICA PLANS TO OFFER A MASTERCARD WITH A REBATE
description: The Primerica Corporation plans to offer Mastercards with a 1 percent rebate on purchases to policyowners of its life insurance unit. Primerica Financial Services will initially offer the Mastercard to 187,000 pre-approved Primerica Life Insurance customers, as part of a marketing effort, the company said yesterday. By the end of 1993, the program will expand to about 750,000 policyowners. The card will be issued through Primerica Bank.

title: Patrick's Dilemma: Injury Adds to Insult
description: James Patrick knows the minutes are not what they used to be. Oh, the ice time is almost the same -- almost, but not quite. It just isn't prime time any longer. He does not skate the first shift of the power play. He does not play in the top defensive duo, which is made up of Jeff Beukeboom and Brian Leetch. The goals haven't been coming. Things aren't the same.

"Los Angeles: Identity, Community and Cultural Activism," a discussion of the disturbances last spring and the role of the arts in addressing urban problems. With Renee Tajima, a film maker and critic; Wanda Coleman, a writer; Ruben Martinez, a journalist and poet; Avital Ronell, a professor of comparative literature; Joel Wachs, a Los Angeles City Councilman, and Jerry Yoshitomi, the executive director of the Japanese-American Cultural and Community Center. Sunday at 6:30 P.M. Admission: $10; $8 for museum members and students. Information: (212) 570-3652. FICTION READING, Arts at St. Ann's, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights. title: SUN ALLIANCE AND CHUBB CUT HOLDINGS IN EACH OTHER
description: The Sun Alliance Group P.L.C. said yesterday in London that it had sold 3.4 million shares in the Chubb Corporation for $281 million and would reinvest the proceeds. The British insurer said it would continue to hold 4.5 million shares, or 5.1 percent, of the insurer, compared with 9 percent previously. Chubb also reduced its stake in Sun Alliance to 3 percent from 9 percent and will realize about $50 million after tax in the fourth quarter on the sale.

title: Review/Film; Hopping Down the Bunny Trail With Hugh Hefner
description: The documentary "Hugh Hefner: Once Upon a Time" works nicely as a Rorschach test. There are those who will find it an appreciative portrait of Playboy's founding father as pioneer, libertarian and social critic, a man "with a castle for a home and a dream for a life." There are also those who will find it a tale of eerie isolation and weird excess, revealing the spiritual emptiness in a life of full-time fun. (Comments like "Hef was having this great time playing pinball" are often heard.)

title: Better-Armed Muslims Warn Croats
description: In this war-ravaged city, where Muslims and Croats joined forces in June to break a Serbian siege, the leaders of the main Muslim party say the prospect of long-term violence and terrorism will head off any possibility that the Croats will join the Serbs in carving up Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Critic's Notebook; Choice Snippets Sell Big Films
description: "NO one can see what Jennifer saw," intones an announcer, as Uma Thurman glides across the screen. "No one can imagine what Jennifer felt." Now it just so happens that Ms. Thurman plays Helena, not Jennifer, in "Jennifer 8," the thriller whose trailer we are discussing. And Jennifer's thoughts and feelings are rather beside the point, since Jennifer is a never-seen character who is dead. Furthermore, this trailer's two-minute intimation of a steamy, suspenseful crime drama is a lot more feverish than the actual two-hour-and-seven-minute "Jennifer 8" (review on C6) happens to be.

title: Critic's Choice; Gentler 'Juno,' But It Sings
description: Sean O'Casey's tragicomic masterpiece "Juno and the Paycock" is a drama of such depth and poetic weight that any attempt to turn it into a musical would inevitably soften its devastating portrait of an impoverished Dublin family in the early 1920's. When the composer Marc Blitzstein and the book writer Joseph Stein turned the play into the musical "Juno" in 1959, the show lasted for only 16 performances on Broadway. Since then, however, Blitzstein's score has won many admirers through an original-cast recording. Now the Vineyard Theater is giving "Juno" its first New York production since 1959, with a revised book and some musical additions.

title: Thrown Into Frying Pan, Favre Is Doing Just Fine

title: Golden Moments of the Philharmonic
description: AT the start of a magical program that CBS broadcast on Jan. 30, 1960, Leonard Bernstein led the New York Philharmonic in the opening of the Beethoven "Eroica" Symphony. The reading was brisk, agitated and crackling with drama, but after 36 bars, Bernstein stopped, turned to the camera and asked his audience to think of the performance as "the interpretation of Maestro A." Then he conducted an alternative, the carefully shaped, velvety, lyrical reading favored by Maestro Z.

title: Reviews/ Art; Brashly Modern Vision in an Ancient Chinese Landscape
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art calls the great Chinese painter Tung Chi-chang (1555-1636) "the Picasso of the Ming Dynasty." The comparison may not leap immediately to mind when seeing the monochrome ink landscapes and calligraphy in "The Century of Tung Chi-chang," but in many ways it is apt.

title: Review/Photography; Paradox of Freezing the Essence of Movement

And for many years, photographers, hampered by slow films and lenses, were limited to recording dancers in essentially static poses. When Edward Steichen photographed Isadora Duncan framed by the columns of the Parthenon in 1921, the image served to evoke a mood rather than record a performance.

title: Critic's Choice/Dance; A Dance Center Reborn
description: The demise of the 14th Street Dance Center, an active and imaginative producing organization in the Emanu-El Midtown Y, brought consternation in December. But the center is back in business, starting this weekend, at the Educational Alliance on the Lower East Side. Dance concerts will be presented in the intimate Art Deco theater of the alliance, a center for education in the visual arts since its founding in 1920's by Moses Soyer. The theater seats 197 and has not been used for some time. It has been renovated, with new curtains, an enlarged stage and upgraded electrical equipment.

title: The End Of Cynicism
description: It was only a false alarm, 1988. It had only the potential for national revelation, when we would decide as a country to leap into or withdraw from the future. A different sort of discussion that year -- between Mario Cuomo and Jack Kemp, for instance -- might have fulfilled that potential or confirmed why some of us believed that, at the end of the Reagan era with no incumbent seeking the Presidency for the first time in 20 years, it was Leap Year.

title: BDM Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossBDM Holdings noted that the 1991 loss resulted from an accounting adjustment arising from the purchase agreement under which BDM regained its independence in 1990. The amount of this charge was not disclosed.

title: Koll Management Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Repap Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Interwest Savings Bank reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Court Says USX Tried To Avoid Paying Benefits
description: A Federal judge in Salt Lake City has ruled that the USX Corporation, operator of the nation's largest steel company, idled a mill in Utah five years ago in an attempt to avoid paying millions of dollars in pension benefits to 1,900 steelworkers.

title: Major Lawsuit On Smoking Is Dropped
description: The most closely watched damage suit against the tobacco industry was dropped today, more than 9 years after it began and months before it was to be retried in Federal District Court here.

title: CHRYSLER ADDS MORE $500 FIRST-TIME-BUYER REBATES
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it was adding first-time-buyer rebates of $500 on four more small and sporty cars until the end of the year. Cars eligible for the rebates include 1992 and 1993 versions of its Plymouth Laser and Eagle Talon sports coupes made by the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation in Illinois, as well as all Plymouth Sundance and Dodge Shadow compacts, except convertibles. Chrysler already has such a rebate on 1992 and 1993 models of its Dodge Daytona coupe, as well as other buyer incentives, of $500 to $2,000, on a number of new cars, trucks and mini-vans. Low-rate financing is offered as an alternative to the rebates on most models.

title: Mr. Coffee reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: October Sales Give Retailers a Brighter Holiday Outlook
description: The nation's big chain stores reported further sales gains in October, continuing a trend that began in August and raising hopes among analysts that for the first time in four years retailers will not have a cold Christmas.

title: In Fatalistic Fashion, King Tells Jordan of Cancer
description: In his first report to the nation about his illness, a pessimistic-sounding King Hussein told Jordanians today that his cancerous left ureter and his kidney had been removed, and that he had to undergo further treatment in the United States.

title: Serbia: Blowing Up the Balkans
description: Even while the blood bath of ethnic cleansing continues in Bosnia, the danger of a new horror arises: that Serbia will spread the war to the province of Kosovo.

title: CITICORP WILL SELL 20% OF STUDENT-LOAN BUSINESS
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it planned to sell 20 percent of its student loan business in a public stock offering that could raise up to $76 million. The offering, to be handled by Smith Barney, Harris Upham, is for a new company, the Student Loan Corporation, that previously was part of Citibank and specialized in issuing Government-guaranteed student loans and handling the collection of those loans. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Citicorp said the stock might sell for a maximum of $19 a share. Citicorp remains in talks to sell the rest of its student loan business to the Student Loan Marketing Corporation, known as Sallie Mae.

title: Japan Scandal Grows on News of Big Bribe Offer
description: Prosecutors dropped a bombshell in Japan's latest political scandal today when they said in court that seven top officials of the governing party had offered as much as $25 million to persuade the head of a rightist group to halt mocking verbal attacks that were preventing their chosen candidate from becoming Prime Minister five years ago.

title: Home Oil Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: James E. Gerstner Sr.; Executive, 48
description: James E. Gerstner Sr., an executive at Bristol-Myers Squibb, died on Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in East Amwell, N.J.

title: Officer Shoots Teen-Ager
description: A police officer shot a 16-year-old youth in the knee last night after the youth pointed a revolver at several officers who were chasing him down a Brooklyn street, the police said. The youth, identified as Hasshim Andrews, was shot once at 8:18 P.M. in front of his residence, at 1198 Pacific Street in Prospect Heights, said a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann. Mr. Andrews was in stable condition early this morning at Kings County Hospital. Sergeant Mohrmann said the officers had spotted Mr. Andrews with a gun and began pursuing him when he turned toward them, gun in hand. The police said they recovered a .32-caliber handgun.

title: Demers Wakes Up Team of His Dreams
description: Jacques Demers keeps going home again. This season, he is back in Montreal, the city of his youth, coaching the Canadiens, the team of his dreams. This week, he was back in Detroit, his home for four years in the late 1980's, where he enjoyed the most success of his coaching career.

title: Sybase Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time pretax charge of $ 2.2 million related to the company's merger with Gain Technology, in the quarter and 9 months.c-Included extraordinary tax-loss carryforwards of $ 666,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,038,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 9 months.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Canadian Tire reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Art in Review
description: Jan Groover Robert Miller Gallery 41 East 57th Street Through Nov. 14

title: Citadel Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dallas Journal; Is the Doctors' Anxiety Pathological?
description: The test takers are edgy; some chain-smoke and gulp coffee from large Styrofoam cups. Others admit they have taken tranquilizers to ease the stress.

title: Garrison Helped Extend Freedom of Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning Not to Look A Mount in the Eye
description: She describes herself as "the Donald Trump of the horse show world," buying and selling horses like so many pieces of real estate, pocketing a profit and never shedding a tear as she watches her property being trucked away. She even went bankrupt once, if only emotionally.

title: Ruling by Court Backs Networks On Rerun Issue
description: A Federal appeals court dealt a major blow to the Hollywood studios today in their effort to keep the big television networks out of the $5 billion business of selling reruns of popular programs.

title: Birth Pangs Of a Nation -- A special report.; Ukraine Facing the High Costs of Democracy
description: Fourteen months into independence, Ukrainians are learning that the romance of nationhood is hard to sustain when the economy is in shambles.

title: Digital to Form Separate Units
description: Robert B. Palmer, the president and chief executive of the Digital Equipment Corporation, said today that the company was being restructured into 8 to 10 "customer focused" business units.

title: A Heileman Account Goes to Deutsch
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company yesterday named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle its Rainier beer account outside the Pacific Northwest. The account, previously unassigned, is Deutsch's second from the brewer in less than two months after being awarded the Colt 45 Malt Liquor account.

title: U.S. Puts a 200% Punitive Tax On White Wines From Europe
description: After years of skirmishing over European farm subsidies, the Bush Administration fired the first shot today in what may become a trade war, announcing that in 30 days it would begin collecting a 200 percent import tax on all still white wines from the European Community.

title: In Possible Sign on Jobs, Subway Ridership Is Up
description: After declining for 32 months in a row, the number of people riding the subway has finally begun to pick up, climbing modestly for three consecutive months, transit officials said yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: High Hopes Along Hudson as N.B.A. Takes Court
description: It wasn't so much that Bill Fitch was too old to relate to the New Jersey Nets last year. It was that he was from another era, of one-year contracts and no free agency, when coaches talked and players trembled.

title: Pacificorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charge of $ 297,000,000 from asset disposition and restructuring programs at the company's Nerco and Pacificorp Financial Services units.c-Net income

title: A Provocative Defense Wins for Fischer
description: By coolly parlaying an audacious defense into a victory, Bobby Fischer defeated Boris Spassky yesterday and won their exhibition match in Belgrade. It was perhaps a new beginning for the world champion of 20 years ago, who gave up a dazzling career for solitude.

title: Napa Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: The Winds of War, 90's-Style
description: War with Europe: an inconceivable thought that suddenly isn't so inconceivable. This war, however, would be of the post-cold-war variety -- fought not with bombs and bullets but with escalating barrages of trade restrictions.

title: CCL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 48.2 million, or 99 cents a share, on the sale of Crown Cork & Seal shares in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net lossd-Included a gain of $ 23 million, or 47 cents a share, on the sale of Crown Cork & Seal shares and a provision of $ 30 million for a decline in real estate values, in both the quarter and 9 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: On Trade Ties to Hanoi, Japanese Jump the Gun
description: Jumping ahead of American policy in Asia, the Japanese Government announced today that it was resuming broad economic ties with Vietnam, including the offer of a major loan package, senior Japanese officials said.

title: Grateful Blue Jays Give Gaston New Pact
description: The world champion Toronto Blue Jays went to relatively great lengths yesterday to express their appreciation for the job turned in by Manager CITO GASTON.

title: Is G.M. Fate Still Crucial to U.S.?
description: "What is good for the country is good for General Motors, and what's good for General Motors is good for the country," Charles E. Wilson, the G.M. president who was to become President Eisenhower's Secretary of Defense, is said to have told the Senate Armed Forces Committee. The pronouncement by Engine Charlie Wilson instantly became a symbol of corporate arrogance for a nation that simultaneously loathed and worshiped big business, for there was rough truth in his words.

title: Transatlantic Holdings Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Transatlantic said that its results for the latest third quarter and 9 months contained losses totaling $ 18 million from hurricanes Andrew and Iniki.

title:
Subdivision With a Club;
Lots on L.I. Include a Polo Membership
description: A 50-acre land subdivision in Old Westbury, L.I., which opened on Sunday, is offering purchasers of its 12 lots an unusual amenity: a five-year membership in the Meadowbrook Polo Club, the nation's oldest polo club. Membership provides a range of benefits, from the ability to stable horses to the use of exclusive club property. The lots, which range from 3 to 6.7 acres, are priced from $775,000 to $1.2 million.

title: Camacho Is Arrested
description: HECTOR (MACHO) CAMACHO, the former World Boxing Council superfeatherweight and lightweight champion, was arrested early yesterday in Miami after battling two police officers in a hotel parking lot, authorities said.

title: Books of The Times; Trying to Separate Fact From Myth About Jesus
description: Jesus A Life By A. N. Wilson 269 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: A Top I.B.M. Executive Is Retiring Early
description: Terry R. Lautenbach, a 54-year-old I.B.M. senior vice president and a member of the company's four-member management committee, decided yesterday to join some 40,000 other employees of the computer giant who chose to take early retirement this year.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Labor Dispute

title: U.S. Drops Case Against Guide for 16 Jailed Tourists
description: The Federal Government today dropped all charges against a Malaysian tour guide accused of smuggling illegal aliens into the United States, ending a painful and puzzling ordeal for members of a tour group who had been held in jail here for more than two weeks as material witnesses.

title: United Asset Management reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' results were restated to reflect the acquisitions of Acadian Asset Management Inc. and Spectrum Asset Management Inc., which have been accounted for as poolings of interest.

title: Police Seek Edison Woman, Apparently Kidnap Victim
description: Middlesex County officials have begun a search for a woman who has been missing since Tuesday evening when, the police say, a man approached her and her 3-year-old daughter at a traffic light in Piscataway and forced his way into their minivan. He later dropped the girl off in front of a day care center and abandoned the van.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN BANK EXPANDS MUTUAL FUNDS LINES
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it was expanding its mutual funds business by becoming a commodity trading adviser. Chase will manage clients' funds on a discretionary basis in such markets as foreign exchange, bullion, interest rates and selected commodity futures. Previously, the bank had gathered funds from investors and allocated them among other advisers. Charles E. Minnaar, a managing director, will head the commodity trading advisory business. He previously directed the bank's managed-funds group and managed Chase's North American foreign exchange sales.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday, about new Federal Communications Commission rules for automated dialing systems, misidentified the party planning to file a lawsuit challenging the rules. It is the National Association of Telecomputer Operators, not Raymond Kolker, the founder of Kolker Systems Inc. in Carlsbad, Calif., which makes autodialing systems.

title: National Penn Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' per share earnings and year-ago third quarter's shares outstandings were adjusted for stock dividends.

title: BankWorcester Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from distribution of stock of Savings Bank Life Insurance of Massachusetts of $ 972,000, or 15 cents a share, and a gain from cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change of $ 9,139,000, or $ 1.38 a share.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Reviews/Fashion; On Opposite Sides Of the Cutting Edge
description: Anna Sui and Adrienne Vittadini provided a study in contrasts on Wednesday. And what contrasts! Women who are designers like to say their strengths lie in knowing what women want to wear. These two designing women obviously have very different groups of friends.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of competing designs for a new Whitehall Ferry Terminal omitted illustration credits for the designs. The large drawing was by Tom Schaller; the inset drawing was by Mike Womack.

title: The Art Market; Auction Houses Await The Upturn
description: IT has been a tense few months at Christie's and Sotheby's. With the art market struggling to inch its way out of a two-year recession, putting together the fall sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art hasn't been easy. Many sellers are still holding back, hoping that the market will show signs of a recovery, so it is estate property that the auction houses count on most. Until just weeks ago, when the catalogues had to go to press, the two companies were vying for what little hot property was available.

title: Bond Traders Await Data on Jobs
description: They may not be reading entrails or putting pins in voodoo dolls, but bond traders and dealers are preparing in their own restrained way with forecasts, analyses, trading strategies -- and maybe even some crossed fingers -- for the October unemployment report that is scheduled to be released today.

title: Suiting Up in N.B.A.: Finding the Right Fits
description: When the New York Knicks open their 1992-93 season tonight against the Atlanta Hawks at the Omni, Marv Albert will sport a double-breasted gray pinstriped suit. It is not just any suit.

title: Abroad at Home; The New Landscape
description: "In victory, magnanimity." So Winston Churchill advised. But for Bill Clinton it will have to be watchful magnanimity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 RAISING TAXES ON EUROPEAN WINES The U.S. fired the first shot in what may become a trade war, announcing that in 30 days it will begin collecting a 200 percent import tax on all white wine from members of the European Community. A1 TOUGH TIMES IN UKRAINE Ukrainians find that the romance of nationhood is hard to sustain when the economy is in shambles. And virtually no new economic policies have been put into effect after 14 months of independence. A1

title: N.C.A.A. Takes On Auburn
description: A year after former Auburn cornerback Eric Ramsey released secretly recorded tapes indicating that he had received illicit financial assistance and that Coach Pat Dye had done nothing about it, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has filed formal charges embracing Ramsey's allegations.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Weight
description: If nothing else, the new National Hockey League system under President Gil Stein moves quickly.

title: Clinton May Quickly Name Transition Chief in Effort to End Dispute Within Staff
description: President-elect Bill Clinton may announce his choice of a transition planning chief as soon as Friday in order to quell a dispute that has broken out among his top advisers about who will oversee the transfer of power from the Bush White House.

title: Kemet Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: At the Bar; Knitting Circle In A Conference Room: With An Eye On Winter, A Law Firm Thinks Of The Needy.
description: Lawyers are often accused of making things out of whole cloth. Or of tearing at the social fabric. Or of embroidering the truth. Or of spinning yarns. But here is a story of a law firm in which some sleights-of-hand are serving humanitarian ends.

title: American International Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hollywood Park reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 815,000, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,266,000, or 14 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net lossYear-ago results are restated pro forma earnings.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Becton, Dickinson reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iran Continues to Deny Access to American Charged With Spying
description: Iran continues to deny consular access to an American arrested on charges of bribery and espionage in September, the State Department said today.

title: In Suburbs, a Stealthy War Against Infiltrating Students
description: With the stealth and precision of agents on a drug raid, private detectives and security guards fanned out through Elmont, L.I., in unmarked cars one recent morning.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The elevator at the Upper East Side building where OSBORN and INGER ELLIOTT were giving a party for SCHUYLER CHAPIN on Wednesday evening had just broken down when BROOKE ASTOR arrived. So, Mr. Chapin went from the penthouse to the lobby to greet her and to sign her copy of his new book, "Leonard Bernstein: Notes From a Friend," published by Walker & Company.

title: J. P. Morgan And Insurer Start Venture
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies and J. P. Morgan & Company opened a major reinsurance company in Bermuda yesterday, hoping to take advantage of a world catastrophe reinsurance market that is dramatically shrinking after years of huge losses and the recent tolls taken by Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki.

title: Reviews/Film; A Serial Killer, a Blind Girl and a Footloose Detective
description: Andy Garcia has a profile to recall Barrymore's, which is as good a reason as any to watch "Jennifer 8," in which he steps up to a starring role. As Detective John Berlin, Mr. Garcia smolders his way through this story of a serial killer, a beautiful blind witness (Uma Thurman) and a footloose detective trying to make his way in a new town. Professionalism is not necessarily John Berlin's strongest suit. "I'll tell you what," he says to Helena, the blind girl. "If I promise to stop being a cop, will you promise to stop being a witness?"

title: Money Store reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics of The Times; Senator Defendant
description: Howard Babbush is too ill to stand trial on charges relating to a jobs scandal but not too ill to run and win. His re-election Tuesday to the New York State Senate certainly made the system look sick. Having knocked his Democratic challenger off the September primary ballot through legal nitpicking, the Brooklyn lawmaker coasted unopposed to a ninth two-year term.

title: Stephen Sheridan, 80, Electrolux Executive
description: Stephen S. Sheridan, the retired chief operating officer of the Electrolux vacuum cleaner company, died on Wednesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Art in Review
description: Peter Hristoff Penine Hart Gallery 152 Wooster Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: The Making of a French Literary Legend
description: Danny Huston's "Becoming Colette" purports to be the story of how Sidonie-Gabrielle Colette, an innocent country lass with a fervid imagination, grew up to be the worldly-wise grande dame of French letters known simply as Colette. The film, which opens today at the Sutton, is not quite a nonstop scream but, in its determinedly flatfooted way, it's as saucy a piece of movie baggage as has turned up in two or three decades.

title: All Mattingly Touches Turns to Gold Again
description: Don Mattingly wanted to talk defense. He wanted to discuss the sparkling play at first base for the Yankees that helped him earn the vote of American League managers and coaches for his seventh Gold Glove award yesterday. But Mattingly conceded that defense is often ignored and some fans consider it boring.

title: With Tight-End Variation Clicking, Jets Enjoy a Rushing Renaissance
description: In the last two weeks, the Jets' rushing attack has returned to the form that vaulted it to the top of the National Football League charts in the first six weeks of last season, when they cruised past opponents for an average of 164 yards a game.

title: Review/Film; Anthony Hopkins vs. Friendly Inefficiency
description: After his first tour of Ball's, a small factory in Melbourne, Australia, that has been turning out casual footwear for 30 years, Wallace (Anthony Hopkins), a tough-minded efficiency expert, is almost in despair. It's the sort of place where the employees gather to sign a sentimental going-away card for a fellow who is leaving after three weeks. The men in the engineering shop spend more time worrying about a toy-car race than their jobs. The women, who sew the moccasins and pastel bunny slippers for which Ball's is known, favor long lunches that turn into tea breaks.

title: William T. Woodhull; Advertising Executive, 80
description: William T. Woodhull, a former newspaper advertising executive, died Nov. 3 at Charlton Memorial Hospital in Fall River, Mass. He was 80 years old and lived in Little Compton, R.I.

title: International Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 849,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 1,455,000, or 4 cents a share, in the 6 months.The 1991 second quarter included a net gain of $ 6.7 million, or 20 cents per share, from the sale of EXEL common stock.

title: Devils Shoot and Shoot and Take a Loss
description: Almost an entire hockey game was spent in Kelly Hrudey's lap tonight. The New Jersey Devils penetrated the Los Angeles defense for more than 40 fairly simple shots here at the Forum, but Hrudey -- his blue bandanna flopping out of his protective mask -- was a capable barrier.

title: Third Party's Leaders Say It Had an Impact
description: After Tuesday's election, leaders of Connecticut's legislature concluded that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s independent third party was not materializing as a potent force in state politics. Today, leaders of Mr. Weicker's party said that the voting proves exactly the opposite and that lawmakers were just defending their outmoded two-party turf.

title: Review/ Film; First Love And Sartre, As a Youth Grows Up
description: John Duigan's "Flirting" is the second low-key, easy-to-take installment in the Australian film maker's projected trilogy about the coming of age of Danny Embling (Noah Taylor), the sensitive young fellow introduced in "The Year My Voice Broke," released four years ago. The new film opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinemas.

title: Why Perot Thrived in Fertile Kansas
description: One of the original Kansas populists, an orator named Mary Elizabeth Lease, reportedly urged farmers in the 1890's to "raise less corn and more hell." That's exactly what Kansans did on Election Day, when they turned out in record numbers and gave Ross Perot 27 percent of their vote, one of the highest percentages for him in any state.

title: Review/Theater; A Lout, but a Lout Who Means Well
description: Aubrey Piper, the title character in "The Show-Off," is a braggart buoyed by misplaced self-confidence. But with his blissful unwillingness to accept discouragement, he also has an engaging side. The full dimension of this eternal optimist is captured by Boyd Gaines in the revival of the George Kelly comedy at the Roundabout Theater Company.

title: New England Business Service Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Included a charge of $ 466,000 from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago first quarter's share earnings included a gain of 8 cents a share for the impact of a favorable state income tax abatement.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Lemieux Rolls On Mario Lemieux resumed his torrid early-season scoring pace with a goal and three assists, leading the Penguins to an 8-4 victory over the St. Louis Blues last night in Pittsburgh. Lemieux, coming off his first scoreless game of the season that stopped a club-record 12-game goal streak, helped the Penguins break open the game with five straight goals after St. Louis had tied it at 2-2. (AP) BASEBALL Grace Powers U.S. Mark Grace of the Chicago Cubs hit two-run homers in consecutive at-bats yesterday, and a team of major leaguers routed the Japan All-Stars, 10-2, in Fukuoka, Japan. (AP) TENNIS Courier Beats Stich Top-seeded Jim Courier fought off 13 aces from Michael Stich of Germany to win by 7-6 (7-3), 6-1 at the Paris Open yesterday. Stefan Edberg, who is seeded No. 3, rallied to defeat Derrick Rostagno of the United States, 7-6 (7-2), 7-6 (8-6). (AP) GOLF American Team Coasts Things went extremely well for the Americans yesterday in the World Cup of Golf in Madrid. Fred Couples shot a six-under-par 66, combining with Davis Love 3d, who fired a 68, as the United States team opened a two-shot lead after the first round of the event at La Moraleja Golf Club. (AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL Kansas State Wins Kitt Rawlings and Tom Randolph blocked Iowa State's first two punts and Eric Gallon rushed for 164 yards as Kansas State beat the Cyclones, 22-13, last night in Manhattan, Kan. Gallon broke a 56-yard touchdown run in the fourth period as the Wildcats (4-4 and 1-3 in the Big Eight) snapped a four-game losing streak. (AP)

title: Briton Holds Off Vote on Europe Until May
description: A day after winning support in Parliament for the European unification treaty, Prime Minister John Major said today that he would not seek ratification of the pact by Britain until at least May.

title: Foreign Policy Test
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey National Hockey League
