description: Outside the world of Newark's Central Ward, the description of Qsan Williams given by his friends today, hours after he died, might be considered a contradiction. He was a good-natured teen-ager who never did anyone harm, they say, but he happened to enjoy stealing cars.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOUSEHOLD noises like squeaky stairs, a humming refrigerator and rumbling radiators give life to a house or apartment, but they can also be irritating. Fortunately, most common household noises are usually easy to eliminate with simple repairs.

title: Review/Dance; Rage and Affirmation in 'Creole Dreams'
description: In "Urban Scenes/Creole Dreams" the experimental choreographer David Rousseve has a more than interesting story to tell about his Creole grandmother from Lafayette, La., and his own feelings as a black child being bused to white schools in Houston: He was scared stiff, but stayed the course and went on to graduate from Princeton in 1981.

title: Maine's Wild Blueberries and Their Unabashed Champion
description: Amr A. Ismail knows as much about self-promotion as he does about the succulent little blueberries that grow wild over thousands of pristine acres on the coast of Maine.

title: Elias E. Manuelidis, Yale Neurologist, 74; Viral-Disease Expert
description: Dr. Elias E. Manuelidis, an internationally known expert on viral brain infections and brain tumors, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Quaker Profit Forecast
description: The Quaker Oats Company, which had a 47 percent jump in first-quarter net income, expects a sizable earnings rise in the 1993 fiscal year, the chairman, William D. Smithburg, said today at the Chicago-based company's annual meeting. The increase would put the cereal and pet foods company within its target of 7 percent average annual growth for real earnings through the 1991-93 fiscal years, he said. In the 1992 fiscal year, Quaker reported net income of $243.4 million, or $3.25 a share.

title: Pay TV Is Looking To Score Knockout
description: Once again -- as in the days when Gillette's hyperactive parrot inquired "How are you fixed for blades?" -- Friday night is fight night.

title: Tartabull Twist: He May Be Available
description: The Yankees were hoping their 15-man protected list would remain secret. They wanted only the Colorado Rockies and the Florida Marlins to know which players were left unprotected and available to be snatched in the National League expansion draft next Tuesday. But the secrets apparently are seeping out.

title: How They Fought Drinking Under Czars
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Bela Fleck and the Flecktones 1 The Blue Note Greenwich Village

title: A Designer Coppers The Lily
description: COPPER seems to be the metal of the moment for home furnishings. In the last year, copper tubing or mesh has been seen in everything from beds to votive-candle holders. Now David Bergman, a Manhattan architect, has designed copper lamps that look like glowing calla lilies.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Fatal Stabbing Lawyer in Bronx
description: An 18-year-old Bronx man was charged yesterday in the slaying of David L. Schwartz, a prominent New York lawyer who was found stabbed to death on Monday in a Bronx motel room, the police said.

title: Epigen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The biopharmaceutical company had no revenues in 1991 because it was a development stage company. Revenues in the current year are solely from interest income.The company is listed on the Emerging Company Marketplace.

title: It's a Crowd of Sorts At Taylor's Old Spot
description: With Lawrence Taylor gone for the season and perhaps forever, the Giants began preparing today for Sunday night's game in Denver against John Elway and the Broncos. In Taylor's position at right outside linebacker, they will have plural replacements for this singular player.

title: Power Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 61.5 million, or 73 cents a share, in the second quarter from a stock issue by Investor's Group at a price in excess of Investor's carrying value and in which Power chose not to participate.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Stephen Drury Pianist Roulette TriBeCa

title: Some Good Old-Fashioned Fun
description: THE Victorians liked to perch on overstuffed sofas or heavily carved wooden chairs and play board games with titles like Yankee Doodle: A Game of American History, and The Lost Heir.

title: Review/Rock; Where Kindness Constitutes a Sin
description: Bonds can be formed in blood, by the word or in ritual. Heavy-metal fans form family ties by piling in front of a stage where their heroes make a roar. They push and sweat themselves into a state of ravishment, letting go of the anger they feel about their daily circumstances and finding a crazy strength in violent communion.

title: Was Chambers Then the Victim of a Spy Sting?; Orthodox Party Hack
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; At Time Warner, Stock Is Stuck
description: BY a number of key measures, Time Warner's stock should be thriving. Since Time and Warner merged in January 1990, the company has managed to pay down about 27 percent of its $11 billion in debt, attracted foreign equity investors and has seen its core businesses do well.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings in the latest periods of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. were $ 1.82 in the quarter and $ 4.96 in the 9 months, compared with $ 1.17 and $ 4.27 in year-ago periods, respectively.The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings in the latest periods were 92 cents in the quarter and $ 2.51 in the 9 months, compared with the year-ago periods of 59 cents in the quarter and $ 2.16 in the 9 months.Sales represented sales proceeds.Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Power Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Huskies Escape Punishment
description: A Pacific-10 Conference subcommittee recommended today that the University of Washington football team not be stripped of its eight victories this season even though quarterback Billy Joe Hobert accepted a $50,000 loan last spring.

title: Loewen Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Philip Glass Premiere
description: The composer and keyboardist Philip Glass is to join the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra and the New York Choral Society in a performance of his music entitled "Glass Reflections," at 8 tonight and tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene. Dennis Russell Davies is to conduct the orchestra and play keyboards in a program featuring the premiere of Glass's "Low Symphony," based on music by David Bowie and Brian Eno; the New York premiere of "Itaipu, a Symphonic Portrait for Chorus and Orchestra" and "Music in Similar Motion." Tickets are $12 to $25. Information: (718) 636-4117.

title: LGS Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title:
Renovated Urban Apartments;
Taking a Risk on Face Lift for Rent-Regulated Building
description: A six-story rent-regulated apartment building here that slipped into decline in recent years has been given a face lift, restoring it to its original status as an attractive home for middle-class families.

title: Leucadia National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 212,000 in the quarter and income of $ 1,636,000, or 14 cents a share, in the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Pop/Jazz; Broken Barriers And Disk Generosity
description: Imagine a sweaty July Saturday in MacArthur Park in Los Angeles, sun burning the shoulders of a hundred neighbors cruising the strip, blurry heat rising from the hoods of slick custom cars. On a stage at the park's edge, a band builds a funk groove. The crowd sways and smiles, loving the familiar tunes.

title: ISM Information reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 146,000 and $ 20,841,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 2 Makers Seek Chip Standard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's third- and fifth-largest computer makers, today proposed a new standard for multimedia chip sets used for networked office computers.

title: Was Chambers Then the Victim of a Spy Sting?; Only the Truth to Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer's Gas reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in February.

title: Banks Increase Loans to Business In a Reversal of 2-Year Downturn
description: Bank lending to businesses has edged upward in recent weeks after a two-year decline that was widely blamed as a cause of the economy's downturn and weak recovery.

title: Wilson to Fill Big Shoes
description: RICK WILSON, a 39-year-old driver from Bartow, Fla., was named yesterday as the replacement for RICHARD PETTY, who is retiring after 35 years of racing.

title: Milgray Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 1,007,000 as part of a reorganization plan to eliminate the operating losses resulting from sales to European customers.c-Net lossYear-ago 9 months' results were not comparable; the company changed its fiscal year-end to Sept. 30 from Dec. 31.

title: Crown Heights Resolution Splits Council
description: New York City Council members traded heated words yesterday after a Jewish lawmaker passionately introduced a resolution condemning the jury that acquitted a black youth in the killing of a Jewish scholar in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last year.

title: Caldor Wins Bidding to Buy 6 of 11 Alexander's Stores
description: The Caldor Corporation, a major discount retailer, bid successfully yesterday to acquire and reopen 6 of 11 department stores in the New York area that Alexander's closed in bankruptcy last spring.

title: Review/Theater; Destroying Its People, A Nation Loses Its Soul
description: The horrors of Cambodia's killing fields are evoked with deep conviction in the musical "Cambodia Agonistes." With music by Louis Stewart and book and lyrics by Ernest Abuba, this is a collaborative undertaking of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater.

title: At the Bar; For those who knew him, a different Wachtler legacy for New York's top court.
description: There is a sad symmetry to Sol Wachtler's long tenure on the New York Court of Appeals. It ended just as it began: with an apology.

title: Charles (Honi) Coles, 81, Dancer; Known for Elegance and Speed
description: Charles (Honi) Coles, a virtuosic tap dancer who won a Tony Award for his performance in the Broadway musical "My One and Only" and whom Lena Horne once described as making "butterflies look clumsy," died yesterday at his home in East Elmhurst, Queens. He was 81 years old.

title: Legislators Form Panel On Car Theft In Newark
description: A day after four more Newark residents were killed as a result of the rising tide of car thefts in the city, New Jersey lawmakers announced a six-member task force to produce legislation intended to curb the problem.

title: No Headline
description: I'm having a wonderful time. -- PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON. [ A18:3. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President-elect Bill Clinton's statements on the military misidentified the law firm in which a Clinton adviser, Samuel R. Berger, is a partner. It is Hogan & Hartson, in Washington.

title: Lands' End reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Instrument Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 100,000 on the early extinguishment of debt.c-Included a gain of $ 870,000, or 3 cents a share, on the extinguishment of debt and a tax credit.

title: Teheran Journal; Dress Code by Mullahs, Head Scarves by Chanel
description: "Down With the U.S.A.," a fading sign still says. But the waiters at the Azadi hardly pay attention now, nor does the musician in the lobby playing Iranian tunes that haven't been heard for a decade, as the patrons have their afternoon tea and cakes.

title: hHED,35p9Rich in the 90's on Ideas Hatched in the 50's
description: It would be hard to find someone who looks more like a struggling garage-shop inventor than Jerome H. Lemelson, or to find someone who looks more out of place in this sun-and-ski resort for the chic and the rich.

title: American Science & Engineering Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 193,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 294,000, or 7 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-Net lossAmerican Science and Engineering said that the latest second quarter results included substantial revenue from the first CARGOSEARCH 2 X-Ray Inspection system funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. The system is scheduled to be fully operational in 1993.

title: Harry Cunningham, 85, Pioneer And Developer of Kmart, Is Dead
description: Harry B. Cunningham, who pioneered discount mass-merchandising in transforming Kmart Corporation into a retailing giant, died Wednesday night at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: First Central Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of about $ 100,000 from the redemption of convertible bonds for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Article 106592 -- No Title
description: All good businesses know that when you see an opportunity, you take it.

title: Guns Don't Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; If Only the Helpless Wanted to Be Helped
description: "The Giving," Eames Demetrios's aggressively earnest film about a Los Angeles yuppie who changes his life to help the homeless, is literally and figuratively in black and white. Shot in the stagy, soliloquy-filled style of a student film, it presents the tremulous white banker Jeremiah Pollock (Kevin Kildow) and the caustic black firebrand named Gregor (Lee Hampton), who regards Jeremiah's charitable efforts with suspicion. The arguments between Jeremiah and Gregor's radicalized band of street people have a stubbornly polemical flavor. Watching Jeremiah being forced to rethink his notions of generosity suggests what it might have been like to spend an hour and a half being browbeaten by the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: Abroad at Home; Humanity Won't Wait
description: At his first press conference since the election Bill Clinton was asked what his priorities would be in foreign policy. He listed a multi-year defense budget plan, nuclear weapons reduction, continuation of the Middle East peace process and global economic arrangements.

title: Burger King Selects Agency for Europe
description: The Burger King Corporation has named D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in London as the fast-food chain's first multinational agency for Continental Europe. The account, with billings estimated to exceed $10 million, had been divided among various local European agencies.

title: Restaurants
description: The brisk, spontaneous nature of French brasseries seems so well suited to the Manhattan life style that one can't help wonder why dozens do not already exist. This notion is underscored by the rousing success of Brasserie des Theatres in the Paramount Hotel, which is the most authentic example of the genre to date.

title: The Spoken Word
description: SYMPOSIUM ON INDIA, Columbia University, Kellogg Conference Center, School of International and Public Affairs, 420 West 118th Street, 15th floor. "Looking for India, 1492," a weekend series of lectures focusing on the history, religion and culture of India; with scholars from the United States and Portugal, Italy and Australia. Today's topics are "India in the European Imagination" from 9 A.M. to noon and "The Northern Indian Reality" from 2 to 4 P.M. Tomorrow the lectures will be on "European Experiences of India" from 9 A.M. to noon and "The Southern Indian Reality" from 2 to 4 P.M. Sponsored by the Southern Asian Institute at Columbia University. Free. Information: (212) 854-3616. STEINEM LECTURE, New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street, SoHo. Gloria Steinem, whose most recent book is "Revolution From Within: A Book of Self-Esteem," will speak about self-esteem. Today at 8 P.M. Admission: $12. Information: (212) 219-2527.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon. Closing This Weekend

description: b-Included gains of $ 23,249,000, partly from the company's sale of its stake in Cominco Ltd., in the quarter and 9 months.Higher revenues reflected the acquisition of control of Minnova Inc. in July.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Columbia Gas System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 39.2 million after-tax increase in the reserve established for environmental costs, a $ 24.2 million after-tax writedown of previously capitalized gas costs, and a $ 39.7 million after-tax charge from Columbia LNG Corp.'s business plan for Cove Point, Md., terminal, in the quarter, and the 9 months included charges and accounting changes of $ 92.3 million.c-Included $ 118.5 million charge, including after-tax writedown of $ 98.7 million for gas supply costs in the quarter, and the 9 months included charges and accounting changes of $ 797.1 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the Matsushita Electric Indusrial Company's agreement on its American taxes described other companies that owe taxes incorrectly in some copies. The Internal Revenue Service's contention that $32 billion in taxes is owed by companies that have shifted profits offshore includes American multinational corporations as well as foreign corporations.

title: Stock Offering By McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of as much as $500 million in preferred stock.l

title: Art in Review
description: Frederick Sommer Pace/MacGill Gallery 32 East 57th Street Through Nov. 28

title: Pay Toilets, an Unqualified Success
description: New York City's four-month experiment to test a French company's street toilets worked beautifully. But there will be no permanent program unless the Dinkins administration pushes it aggressively through red tape and political barbed wire thrown up by groups representing the disabled.

title: A.T.& T. TO BUY 25% STAKE IN UNDERSEA NETWORK
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would buy a 25 percent stake in an undersea fiber-optic network for $360 million. The Columbus II network, scheduled to be ready for service in December 1994, would transmit voice, data and video signals between the United States, Europe and Latin America. The network would be able to transmit 325,000 phone calls simultaneously and would complement the existing Americas-1 fiber-optic system.

title: Greyvest Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PHLCorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ukraine Asks Aid for Its Arms Curb
description: Ukrainian leaders have threatened to hold up approval of the treaty sharply reducing intercontinental nuclear missiles unless their new nation receives a substantial boost in Western aid.

title: Post Owner Nears Deal With Private Investor
description: Peter S. Kalikow, the owner of The New York Post, is nearing a multimillion-dollar deal with a private investor that would give new life to The Post, New York newspaper industry officials said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Assigning Blame and Taking No Responsibility
description: A Nation of Victims The Decay of the American Character By Charles J. Sykes 289 pages. St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

title: Ex-Retail Executives Are Charged in Fraud
description: Until its collapse almost a year ago, Cascade International Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., was viewed on Wall Street as a nationwide women's apparel chain -- a bright prospect to its fans, a wildly inflated speculation to its critics, but a business, in any case.

title: I.C.H. Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 714,000, which included after-tax charge of $ 19.6 million for writeoff of mortgage-backed securities investments in the quarter and an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 3,230,000 in the 9 months.c-Included a charge of $ 48.9 million for the writeoff of mortgage-backed securities investments and a reserve of $ 11.7 million for litigation settlements.d-Net income and included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 8,783,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Woodforde Beats Lendl Ivan Lendl, a five-time winner of the tournament, was soundly beaten by Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in the biggest upset at the European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. John McEnroe, a three-time winner, also lost, beaten in straight sets by Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-4. Top-seeded Jim Courier cruised along, getting past Javier Sanchez of Spain, 6-3, 6-3, to join Woodforde and Korda in the quarterfinals of the $1.11 million event. (AP) Cherkasov Stops Wheaton: Andrei Cherkasov of Russia kept alive his hopes for winning a third straight Kremlin Cup in Moscow by beating David Wheaton of the United States, 6-4, 7-6 (7-2), yesterday to move into the quarterfinals. Wheaton was the last American in the singles draw. (AP) Graf Coasts in Philadelphia: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of Germany easily beat fifth-seeded Conchita Martinez of Spain, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $350,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia tournament. Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina was to face a wild-card entry, Lisa Raymond of Wayne, Pa., the 1992 National Collegiate Athletic Association singles champion, in a quarterfinal last night. In second-round matches, Natalya Zvereva of Belarus upset sixth-seeded Mary Pierce of France, 7-6 (7-4), 6-2. Eighth-seeded Lori McNeil survived a strong comeback by Gigi Fernandez to win, 6-2, 7-5. McNeil will play fourth-seeded Jennifer Capriati and Zvereva will play third-seeded Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in today's quarterfinals. (AP) HORSE RACING Deputation Is Winner Deputation disposed of an early challenge from Wiggles Law and went on to a six-length victory yesterday in the $47,000 Expressive Dance Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Low Tolerance was second in the six-horse field with Maxamount one-half length further back. The victory was the third in eight starts this year for Deputation, who covered a mile and an eighth in 1:511/5 and paid $2.60, $2.40 and $2.10 for $2 across the board. (AP)

title: Small-Change Donations Going to Vendors, Not Charities, Abrams Charges
description: The New York Attorney General charged yesterday that hundreds of honor boxes and candy-gum vending machines found near cash registers in businesses across the state, with messages seemingly soliciting small-change donations for national charities, are part of a fraudulent and deceptive marketing scheme.

title: Two Faces of Exxon Chief's Kidnapper
description: Two starkly different portraits emerged today of Arthur D. Seale, the man who admitted kidnapping and killing the Exxon executive Sidney J. Reso last spring.

title: Dell to Offer 4 Million New Shares
description: The Dell Computer Corporation said today that it planned to offer approximately four million new shares of its common stock for sale to the public in early December.

title: Maybe Knick on Ice Could Spur Rangers
description: This season, they called me in early. Come up to Playland; tell us what to do: Team lost two in a row at home, booed in the Garden, maybe a power struggle between the Captain and the Coach. I hustled up I-95 and delivered the word -- Ice, baby. Let it melt. No big deal. Nada prob.

title: Arbitrator Puts Howe Back in Major Leagues
description: The troubled career of Steve Howe took another twist yesterday when George Nicolau, baseball's arbitrator, overturned the lifetime ban that was imposed against Howe last summer for repeated problems with drugs.

title: KISSINGER ISSUES WIRETAP APOLOGY
description: After more than two decades, Henry A. Kissinger has apologized for his role in wiretapping the home telephone of Morton H. Halperin, was was then a White House aide.

title: Bowe's Task Is to Prove His Heart Is in Ring
description: When Riddick Bowe was an amateur heavyweight, headed for the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, Butch Lewis was one of several promoters who were considering signing Bowe to a professional contract.

title: Washington Memo; Insider Paving Way for an Outsider
description: Still playing the outsider, President-elect Bill Clinton asked the other day whether there was a McDonald's near the White House.

title: Executive Changes
description: ARTISTIC GREETINGS INC., Elmira, N.Y., which sells personalized products like address labels and greeting cards, appointed David C. Lee executive vice president and chief operating officer. KEMPER SECURITIES INC., Chicago, named Mark Luftig senior vice president and senior analyst for the electric utilities industry.

title: Cable Expectations Are High
description: While advance pay-per-view purchases of TVKO's Evander Holyfield-Riddick Bowe might not presage a blockbuster, the fight's distributor indicates that tonight's heavyweight title bout will probably exceed the estimated 735,000 purchases for Holyfield's June defense against the former champion Larry Holmes.

title: Entergy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Art in Review
description: Ken Buhler Michael Walls Gallery 156 Wooster Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Romantic

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CEPHALON INC., Horsham, Pa., has entered into an agreement to acquire the manufacturing operations of Bio Science Contract Production Corp., Beltsville, Md., for approximately $14 million. COGNEX CORP., Needham, Mass., a supplier of machine vision systems, has entered into a purchasing agreement with Adstar Tape Products , San Jose, Calif., a subsidiary of I.B.M. Corp.

title: Review/Film; Coppola's Dizzying Vision Of Dracula
description: LITTLE did you suspect that the world has been dying for yet another film variation on "Dracula," Bram Stoker's classic of 19th-century gothic fiction. Yet Francis Ford Coppola's new extravaganza, suitably titled "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " to separate it from all others, is such a dizzy tour of movie-making forces that it comes close to overwhelming all reasonable doubts.

title: Federal Loans to Aid Nonprofit Theaters
description: More than 140 Off and Off Off Broadway nonprofit theaters may be able to renovate their theaters or purchase larger quarters with their shares of a $1.5 million low-interest loan program of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Clinical Data reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Orchestra From Ottawa
description: The National Arts Center Orchestra of Ottawa is to present a concert at 8 P.M. on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. Trevor Pinnock, the orchestra's artistic director, is to conduct the program, which features the American premiere of Linda Bouchard's "Ressac for Orchestra" and Bruch's Violin Concerto No. 1 with the violinist Dmitri Sitkovetsky. Also on the program are Prokofiev's First Symphony ("Classical") and Mendelssohn's Third Symphony ("Scottish"). Tickets are $12 to $50. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Buckle Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Ford Official Is Put in Line For Top Job
description: The Ford Motor Company promoted Alexander J. Trotman yesterday to president and chief operating officer of Ford's worldwide automotive group, putting him in line to succeed Harold A. (Red) Poling next year as chief executive.

title: Review/Art; A Tragic Harbinger of the New
description: ONE of the first paintings to be seen in the fine retrospective of Frederic Bazille opening today at the Brooklyn Museum is not especially fine. The stiffness of the figures in a copy of Veronese's "Mystic Marriage of St. Catherine" betrays the gropings of a young painter.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 'Angels,' Downtown or on Broadway?

title: Alba-Waldensian reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time insurance gain of $ 160,000 and a reversal of unused mark-down reserves of $ 378,000.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball MLB -- Announced that Steve Howe, pitcher, has been reinstated from a drug suspension by arbitrator George Nicolau. American League

title: CHRONICLE
description: Forty-three years ago, KIRK BROWNING was perfectly content to be a chicken farmer in Ridgefield, Conn. -- or so he thought. Then he was routed into television by a favorite egg client. On Monday evening Mr. Browning, director of the "Live From Lincoln Center" broadcasts, will add to the list of accolades that have been showered on him over the years.

title: Grim Lifeline for 700,000 Bosnians: 60 Miles of Mud
description: "This must be the longest horror film in history," said Mohammed Avdagic, a 26-year-old medical technician here. "There is almost nothing in the regular stores except salt and, at times, canned food."

title: Interest Rates Cut in Europe
description: Italy's central bank cut interest rates by one full percentage point today, to 13 percent, as the Government forced harsh austerity measures through Parliament.

title: Gay Sailor, Blazing Path for Others, Returns to Base After Court Order
description: Keith Meinhold returned to work here this morning at the Moffett Field Naval Air Station, reinstated by a court order and determined to be a pathfinder for uncounted thousands of military personnel who are secretly gay.

title: It's the Bully Pulpit Again; America, and White Bread
description: Why did George Bush lose? An intimate of the President gave one answer last week talking to Maureen Dowd of The Times: "He was only comfortable with a damn white-bread crowd, a bunch of white male Protestant number-crunchers and bean counters."

title: Lee Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Lee Enterprises said that year-to-year and quarterly revenue results are not comparable because of the purchase of New Mexico Broadcasting Co., which was not fully reflected in last year's figures.

title: G.M. Expects End to Losses By Next Year
description: The General Motors Corporation's new management team told financial analysts and reporters in New York yesterday that cost-cutting in G.M.'s troubled North American operations was running ahead of schedule, prompting a forecast that losses would be plugged next year.

title: Oneita Industries reports earnings for Year Sept 30
description: Per share information is adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend declared in February.

title: 30-Year Bond Auction Sets Off Rally
description: In what some traders called a short squeeze, a few dealers bidding cleverly at the Treasury auction yesterday forced a lot of other dealers to pay dearly after the auction. The byplay sent the 30-year bond price sharply higher, and it gave a lift to the rest of the Treasury market.

title: 'Foxfire Book' Teacher Admits Child Molestation
description: Eliot Wigginton, the Georgia school teacher whose students produced "The Foxfire Book," an acclaimed series of journals about their surroundings and local culture, surrendered to the authorities today, one day after pleading guilty to child molestation.

title: Conservatives Set for Fight on Judicial Nominees
description: For more than a decade the combat roles in judicial nomination fights were clear and unvarying. A conservative White House under either Ronald Reagan or George Bush would nominate a conservative candidate, and liberal groups would scrutinize, criticize and mobilize to try to stop Senate confirmation.

title: Review/Music; Connecting Diverse Styles
description: The American Composers Orchestra can usually be counted on to remind its listeners of the diversity of styles and goals that continue to evolve within the American compositional world. Of the four pieces that Dennis Russell Davies and his orchestra presented at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, three -- works by Andrew Imbrie, Richard Wernick and Robert Beaser -- had points of confluence, yet mostly went their own ways. The fourth, one of John Cage's last works, stood resolutely apart.

title: INSIDE
description: An Apology From Kissinger

title: Review/Film; Not Living Happily Ever After, After All
description: In Barcelona in the early 1940's, adolescents whose parents were too poor to buy them toys used to entertain themselves by sitting around in groups and telling stories, explains the prologue for Vicente Aranda's film "Aventis" ("Stories"). Their tales typically interwove current events, neighborhood gossip and fantasy into surreal little scenarios, infused with sex and high adventure, in which the line between real and imagined events often blurred.

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Room' Joan T. Washburn Gallery 20 West 57th Street Through Dec. 5

title: On My Mind; The Secrecy Game
description: Lucky Bill Clinton. He wants change. All right -- all by himself he can bring about one historic change that touches on war and peace.

title: Mirage Resorts Offers Plan for Gambling on the Bridgeport Waterfront
description: Mirage Resorts today presented a plan for a casino and gaming center on this city's waterfront that, at first sight, looked no more implausible than the dolphins and rain forest at the Mirage desert resort on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Miscellany
description: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said magazine advertising pages in October rose two-tenths of 1 percent from October 1991, to 16,237.5. For the year to date, pages rose 2.85 percent, to 132,270.9.

title: Toys 'R' Us and China
description: Toys "R" Us may set up one of its giant stores in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, The South China Morning Post said today. The store, which would be set up in cooperation with the trading company Li & Fung here, would be the United States toy retailer's first in China.

title: It's the Bully Pulpit Again; The President-Elect: Leading by Explaining
description: Listening to Bill Clinton's news conference yesterday brought a surprising sense of relief and respect.

title: 'Some Relief' In U.S. Plan On Air Noise
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today published a long-awaited study of options for reducing air traffic noise over New Jersey, calling it a step toward providing "some relief" to residents who have complained about noise since air routes were shifted five years ago.

title: Hughes Supply reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: At Time Inc.'s Magazines, Speculation on Top Changes
description: The Time Inc. magazine empire was engulfed in speculation yesterday that major executive changes involving several top executives were imminent. Editorial employees huddled in the halls and traded reports over the telephone all day.

title: THE TRANSITION: The President-Elect; CLINTON, SKETCHING PLAN FOR ECONOMY, COUNSELS PATIENCE
description: Echoing a campaign rich in promises, President-elect Bill Clinton sketched out a plan today for his Administration's first months, incorporating elements ranging from the creation of investment tax credits for job growth to the loosening of immigration policies barring most Haitian refugees.

title: Without Dire Steps, New York Finds Air Is Cleaner
description: To meet clean air requirements, New York City officials have, over the years, considered banning trucks from midtown Manhattan, placing tolls on East River bridges and insisting on "no drive days," when commuters would be barred from driving into the city more than four days a week.

title: What Mothers and Babies Decide to Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Oceaneering International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 1.2 million for the acquisition of Eastport International Inc.Year-ago periods were restated to account for Eastport acquisition.

title: Hornets Sign Mourning Without Making Any Trades
description: One week into the National Basketball Association season, ALONZO MOURNING ended his holdout yesterday and agreed to a six-year contract with the Charlotte Hornets reportedly worth $26.25 million.

title: THE TRANSITION: News Analysis; In Command Of Language
description: Words are George Bush's enemies; President-elect Bill Clinton showed today that they can be his friends.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Georgia Housing and Finance Authority is tentatively offering $80 million of home-ownership opportunity-program bonds with a maximum yield of 6.60 percent for an issue due in 2023 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Serials yield from 2.95 percent in 1993 to 5.85 percent in 2003, with another long maturity due in 2011 priced to yield 6.50 percent. A bond due in 2010 featuring sinking-fund payments that give it an average life of 3.75 years is priced to yield 5.75 percent. Underwriters expect the financing to be rated AA by both Moody's and S.& P.

title: Study Cites Role of Biological and Genetic Factors in Violence
description: In a sharp departure from traditional criminology, the National Research Council has found that biological and genetic factors should be considered along with environmental problems like poverty in efforts to understand the causes of violence.

title: Critic's Choice; An Opera In Chinese, With Titles
description: Probably every New Yorker has at some time, somewhere in the city, felt like a stranger in a foreign land. At the Chinese opera, for example. For years, any Westerner who attended its infrequent presentations and who did not understand the language and conventions of the genre was decidedly an outsider, not necessarily welcomed.

title: Accounts
description: * Bacardi Imports Inc., Miami, to Ahern New York, to handle a creative assignment for unspecified new products. Billings were not disclosed. * Carnival's Crystal Palace Resort and Casino, Nassau, the Bahamas, to Robinson, Yesawich & Pepperdine, Orlando, Fla., to handle its account, with billings estimated to exceed $3 million, previously at McFarland & Drier, Miami.

title: Review/Film; All You Need Is Love, Plus a Good Antidote
description: Dale Launer, the man who wrote the hilarious "Ruthless People," "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels" and "My Cousin Vinny," makes his debut as what Hollywood calls a "hyphenate" (writer and director) with "Love Potion No. 9," the kind of comedy you can outrun at a walk. Given the premise, which is said to be inspired by the song by Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, virtually everything that happens can be predicted from the opening frame.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday about a failed evacuation effort in Sarajevo gave an incomplete account of an action by Maj. Sefer Halilovic, the Bosnian Army commander. The last sentence should have said, "On Monday night, Major Halilovic issued an order forbidding the Red Cross to continue the evacuation effort, which was to have carried 6,000 people, 4,000 Muslims and Croats and 2,000 Serbs, across the siege lines."

title: Review/Film; Delving Into the Mysticism of Music
description: Taking his cue from his subject -- a Baroque composer and violist da gamba known only for his reticence and the mournful beauty of his music -- the French film maker Alain Corneau has fashioned a reserved and elegant portrait colored by dark, romantic longing. Where the film embroiders the sketchy biography of the 17th-century musician called Monsieur de Sainte Colombe (even his first name is unknown, as are the dates of his birth and death), it remains utterly true to the spirit of his work. Music is so effectively used, and so central to the film, that "Tous les Matins du Monde," a big hit in France and a winner of seven French Cesars last year, has since prompted its own Baroque music revival.

title: ZENITH DATA SYSTEMS TO INTRODUCE ULTRALIGHT PC
description: Zenith Data Systems, a subsidiary of Compagnie des Machines Bull of France, will introduce a 3.9-pound personal computer Monday with a list price of $1,899, which the manufacturer calls its first "sub-notebook" PC. Zenith Data, of Buffalo Grove, Ill., plans to display the Z-Lite 320L Model 60 and Model 60 W, which carries a $2,199 list price, at the Comdex computer trade show. The new Zenith PC's are built around the Intel Corporation's 386 SL microprocessors, which consume 3.3 volts of power, rather than older 80386 devices that consume 5 volts.

title: Review/Photography; Physical Disabilities And Courage Facing Them
description: In his current exhibition of photographs at the Zabriskie Gallery, Nicholas Nixon continues his investigation of people with severe physical problems. In earlier projects, Mr. Nixon studied people facing the deterioration of old age or AIDS; this time he deals with blind children. All of this might have been treated sensationalistically or bathetically, but his dispassionate black-and-white images are so unlike most journalistic approaches that they seem shockingly honest and fresh.

title: Nymagic Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charges of about $ 2,360,000 from hurricanes Andrew and Iniki, and charges of about $ 2,400,000 from the company's abandonment of its lease for office facilities.

title: ITT, INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO CLOSE MILL, LAYING OFF 628
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that a paper mill it owns jointly with the International Paper Company in Hoquiam, Wash., would close, after a weak paper market produced $11 million in losses this year. All 628 workers are to be laid off, ITT said. The company said it would post a charge of $115 million, or 87 cents a share, in the fourth quarter to pay for closing the complex, which has been idle since Nov. 3.

title: Gap Profits Down by 12.4% in 3d Quarter
description: Gap Inc. announced yesterday a 12.4 percent drop in its third-quarter profits, shrinking gross margins and the failure of its latest television advertising campaign.

title: Associations Form Brand-Equity Group
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers have joined nine media associations to form an organization to help make the case for building strong name-brand products.

title: In NATO, Only U.S. and British Ban Gay Soldiers
description: If President-elect Bill Clinton goes ahead with his promise to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military, Britain will become the only member of NATO still maintaining a strict policy of excluding gay men and lesbians from its armed forces.

title: Tallahassee, Fla., Prices Bonds
description: The city of Tallahassee, Fla., has tentatively priced for offering to the public $117.8 million in tax-exempt electric revenue and refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 6.30 percent for a bond due in 2012 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Dekalb Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,050,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: The total assets of the nation's 616 retail money market mutual funds decreased $1.61 billion, to $388.26 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: The Art Market
description: A Cezanne Moves West

title: Review/Art; Coexistence in Medieval Spain, at Least Until 1492
description: The year 1492 was busy for Ferdinand and Isabella. On Jan. 2 they took the keys to the city of Granada from the last Muslim ruler on the Iberian Peninsula. On March 31 they set in motion a nationwide expulsion of the Jews. Thus, only months before Columbus's arrival in America, the multi-cultural fabric that had been Spain for nearly 800 years was officially unraveled.

title: Cuomo Submits List Of Choices for Judgeship
description: Emphasizing that he wants to appoint a new chief judge of the New York State Court of Appeals as soon as possible, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today gave the commission that nominates judges a list of seven or eight potential candidates for the job.

title: Blackman to Test Leg Today
description: Rolando Blackman, who has a strained left calf muscle, did not practice today, but he will travel with the Knicks for their game Friday night against the Washington Bullets in Landover, Md. Blackman will test his left leg Friday before deciding whether to play. Greg Anthony, who has a sprained right ankle, practiced today and plans to play Friday.

title: THE TRANSITION: The New Team 1; Clinton Selects Diverse Team of Advisers
description: President-elect Bill Clinton today named a transition team notable for its diversity in age, sex and ethnic background that will help Mr. Clinton shape the initial economic, foreign and social policies of his Administration.

title: Sports of The Times; Champ Diet: Sandwiches Or Seaweed?
description: IF you are what you eat, the survivor of tonight's world heavyweight championship fight will have been nourished either by sandwiches or seaweed.

title: Subaru Maker Posts Profit
description: Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes Subaru-brand passenger cars, posted a profit of 224 million yen, about $1.8 million, in the half-year through Sept. 30, returning to the black for the first time in three years.

title: Harsha V. Oesman; Architect, 37
description: Harsha V. Oesman, an architect, died on Oct. 31 in Hong Kong, where he lived. He was 37 years old.

title: Insituform Mid-America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGES RULING MAY FORCE THOUSANDS OF RETRIALS

title: Sating the Eyes And Satisfying The Appetite
description: YOU'VE seen the lines around the block at the Museum of Modern Art and snaking out the door at the Guggenheim; the throng taking over the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the busloads of children disembarking at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Mexico's Little Airline That Could
description: When Alberto Abed was 14 years old his father died. The teen-ager dropped out of school and learned to fly planes to help support his family.

title: It's the Bully Pulpit Again; Vernon Jordan's Integrity
description: An editorial yesterday about Vernon Jordan, chairman of Bill Clinton's transition organization, came out subject to a harsher reading than was intended.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mercantile Exchange to Stay in New York City
description: Ending years of indecision over whether the New York Mercantile Exchange would leave lower Manhattan for Jersey City, the exchange's board of directors voted late Wednesday night to remain in New York, exchange officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the takeover strategist behind the proposed merger of Air Canada and Continental Airlines misstated part of the terms under which an investment group led by the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass acquired the American Savings and Loan Association of California. A $1.5 billion credit line was proposed as part of the deal, but later dropped.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Senior East Germans Go On Trial; Critics Ask if Such a Case Is Just
description: The most sensational political trial in Germany since the Nuremberg war crimes trialsopened today, but doubts lingered whether the manslaughter case against Erich Honecker, the former East German leader, and five close aides would be able to proceed.

title: For Filipino New Dealer, a Hard Road to Recovery
description: Newspapers have begun referring to President Fidel V. Ramos in headlines by his initials -- F.V.R. -- and when Mr. Ramos gave a televised speech to the nation shortly after marking his 100th day in office last month, his aides described it as a "fireside chat without the fireside."

title: Today's TV Listings
description: Television and radio news, listings and advertising, normally found in Weekend, appear today on pages B14-15.

title: Inquiry Is Planned on Fund-Raising Groups
description: New York State is opening an inquiry into the fund-raising practices of the United Seniors Association and other groups that solicit money from the elderly and have connections with Richard A. Viguerie, the conservative direct-mail expert, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Ruling in Minor Trial Imperils Some Big New York Verdicts
description: When New York State's highest court ordered a new trial for a defendant in a minor drug case last week, the judges threw into doubt convictions in thousands of criminal cases, including some of the most notorious trials of recent years, legal experts said yesterday.

title: Police Questioning 3 in Officer's Killing
description: Investigators were questioning three men early this morning who had been seen with an off-duty police officer before she was shot to death on Wednesday and her body dumped in a marshy lot near Kennedy International Airport, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Lowe's Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 26.

title: Review/Art; One Brief and Shining Cubist Moment
description: Truncated achievements and traveling exhibitions don't always mix, as is demonstrated by the disappointing survey of Max Weber's 10-year Cubist career at the Brooklyn Museum. Weber, who was born in Russia in 1881 and emigrated to New York City with his family at the age of 10, was fleetingly considered one of the leading modern artists in America. He was, for example, among the first Americans to exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art, in 1930.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Army In its 68 years, Michie Stadium has had many a memorable running back scamper over its turf, and another one will be there tomorrow: LeShon Johnson of Northern Illinois, who has advanced from 33d to third in Division I-A rushing totals over the last eight games.

title: People
description: * Howard Mandel was named to the new position of senior vice president and management supervisor of new business development at Goldberg Fossa Seid Advertising, New York. He previously held the corresponding position at MacNamara, Klein & Solin, New York. * Jayne Jamison, advertising sales director at American Health magazine, New York, was promoted to publisher, succeeding Susan Baron, who continues as group publisher at the parent Reader's Digest Special Interest Magazines, New York.

title: The Giants' Plan: Don't Let Elway Disappear in Thin Air
description: He's probably the most dangerous quarterback in the National Football League. He has Randall Cunningham's ability and willingness to scramble, but he's a better passer. In his 10 pro seasons, he has steered 31 game-saving drives in the fourth quarter, resulting in 30 victories and a tie.

title: Review/Film; About Arts, Reporters And Censors
description: "Damned in the U.S.A," opening today at the Quad Cinema in Greenwich Village, was originally made as a television documentary for England's Channel 4, being a report on the state of the arts in this country with special emphasis on pornography and censorship. The news peg was the Cincinnati obscenity trial involving the exhibition of explicity sexual photographs, taken by Robert Mapplethorpe, at the Contemporary Arts Center there.

title: Islanders Lose Fifth Straight
description: The steam coming from the Islanders' locker room at the Spectrum tonight wasn't from the shower. For 30 minutes after the game, the players kept their skates and uniforms on their sweaty, beaten bodies. The door was guarded by a security man. The hot vapor came from a players-only meeting, called by team captain Patrick Flatley after the Islanders dropped their fifth consecutive game, this one by 8-5 to the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Expo for Pets and Their Companions
description: HERE'S the ideal weather report for this weekend by Rick Stuts: A 100 percent chance of overcast with a perpetual mist escalating to steady drizzle (but not a downpour), continuing without pause until 6:01 Sunday evening, give or take a minute.

title: Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Farm Credit System said its operating income rose 32 percent to $ 296 million for the latest third quarter, compared with the year-ago period of $ 225 million.

title: Perrigo Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: TV Weekend; Portrait of Michael Jackson's Family
description: First, earlier this week, CBS's "Sinatra"; now ABC's "Jacksons." November, a month when advertising rates are adjusted to reflect ratings, has taken a fancy to five-hour mini-series about pop-music icons. Both, as it happens, are family affairs carefully built from the inside for maximum image control.

title: John L. Bainbridge, Author, Is Dead at 78
description: John Lakin Bainbridge, an author and longtime staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, died yesterday at the Albany Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Schoharie, N.Y.

title: Furor on Exhibit at Law School Splits Feminists
description: The closing of an art exhibit on prostitution two weeks ago has plunged the University of Michigan law school in Ann Arbor into an angry debate about free speech, feminism, pornography and censorship.

title: Canada Malting reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said share earnings reflected the 3-for-2 stock split approved in May.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Quaker Oats Spotlights Vigorous Elderly
description: For the last five years, Wilford Brimley has served as a phlegmatic, even lethargic, spokesman for Quaker Oats. "It's the right thing to do," the veteran character actor declared earnestly in low-key ads aimed at older consumers.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about a lawsuit seeking to end the Government's ban on interviewing Haitian refugees at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba misidentified a plaintiff. It is Fairness and Accuracy in Media, a group that monitors news coverage, not Accuracy in Media, another such group.

title: Too Late, if Not Too Little, for the Nets
description: It was hard to tell the fourth-year expansion team from the supposedly rising power tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, where Chuck Daly's home debut as coach of the Nets began in celebration of a dreamlike summer and ended with visions of a nightmarish winter.

title: Chambliss Is With Cards
description: Former Yankees first baseman CHRIS CHAMBLISS was hired yesterday as the Cardinals' hitting instructor. He replaces DON BAYLOR, who was named manager of the Colorado Rockies.

title: Media-Only Services Focus of Grey Unit
description: Grey Advertising in New York said yesterday that it had formed a unit, called Media Connection, specializing in media-only services like consulting, research, and planning and buying.

title: U.N. SOMALIA ENVOY DISMAYED OVER AID
description: The new United Nations special representative to Somalia made his first visit into the famine zone today and immediately expressed dissatisfaction with United Nations efforts to relieve the suffering in this bush town.

title: MacPherson to Have Surgery
description: New England Patriots Coach DICK MacPHERSON was scheduled to have surgery today because of a serious intestinal condition that has caused him to be hospitalized since last week.

title: Charles Fraser-Smith, Mr. Gadget For James Bond Tales, Dies at 88
description: Charles Fraser-Smith, the gadget-designing genius on whom the character "Q" in the James Bond novels and movies was modeled, died on Monday at his home in Bratton Fleming, in southwest England. He was 88 years old.

title: Newark Jazz Festival
description: Tony Bennett, Nancy Wilson, Billy Taylor and Jimmy McGriff are among the artists set to take part in the second Newark Jazz Festival, which opens tomorrow and continues through Nov. 22 at various Newark sites. Concerts, a symposium on jazz history, films and daily live broadcasts on WBGO-FM are scheduled. Some events are free. Mr. Bennett, Ms. Wilson and the Gail Allen Quartet are to appear next Friday at 8 P.M. at Symphony Hall; tickets are $25 to $35. Information: (201) 643-3605.

title: The Real Tragedy of Judge Wachtler
description: The reaction to the criminal charges against Sol Wachtler, former chief judge of New York's judicial system, puts into bleak perspective the anniversary reviews of the lessons of Anita Hill. The unmistakable conclusion is that established institutions of our society, most dismayingly the judiciary, still do not get it.

title: Report Details School Fraud By Custodians
description: The Board of Education has permitted its school custodians to operate under so few controls that they have managed second careers on school time, fabricated ghost employees on their payrolls and hired helpers with criminal records, according to an investigative report.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Profits Rose in Quarter
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that it had earnings of $:783 million ($1.2 billion) on a historic cost basis in the third quarter, up from $:569 million a year earlier.

title: Owners Predict Chaos; Players Call for Justice
description: After hearing arguments today on the potential merits and disasters of granting free agency to more than 600 National Football League players when their current contracts expire on Feb. 1, United States District Judge David Doty took the case under advisement. He was expected to offer a ruling next week.

title: Gap Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New Talks On Europe Trade Set
description: The top American and European trade and agriculture officials will meet here next week in yet another effort to tiptoe back from the brink of trade war, American officials said today.

title: Charles W. Charny, 90, Urologist Who Led Study of Male Infertility
description: Dr. Charles W. Charny, a urologist who helped his peers become aware of the existence and nature of male infertility, died Tuesday at the Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 90 years old.

title: Step Toward Independent Counsel Is Taken in the Iraq Bank Inquiry
description: The Justice Department has taken the first step toward appointing an independent counsel to investigate the Government's handling of a politically sensitive bank-fraud case involving Iraq, the official leading the department's internal inquiry said today.

title: Art in Review
description: Sonia Delaunay and Charmion von Wiegand Marilyn Pearl Gallery 420 West Broadway (at Spring Street) SoHo Through Dec. 19

title: For Children
description: 'Dame of the Narrows' The Brooklyn Museum 200 Eastern Parkway At Prospect Park (718) 638-5000 Recommended for all ages Through November 1993

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Bechtle O. K. Harris Gallery 383 West Broadway (near Broome Street) SoHo Through Nov. 28

title: Sears to Test Use of Other Credit Cards
description: Giving a long overdue nod to nearly four decades of consumer finance, Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it would begin accepting Visa, Mastercard and American Express credit cards in 140 stores in six markets on a test basis.

title: St. Patrick's Day Parade Ruling Saw Through Bigotry's Ruses
description: To the Editor:

title: Our History vs. Clinton's Covenant
description: It has taken two centuries of struggle for America to remedy the egregious compromises that made its Constitution possible. The election of Bill Clinton, along with his running mate, another young Southerner, may mark a watershed in this historic remedy, one that holds special hope for African-Americans, for women and for all who now feel insecure and alienated from the American dream.

title: Militant Killed in Lebanon Zone
description: One Muslim fundamentalist guerrilla was reported killed, another wounded and captured, and three Israeli soldiers wounded in a guerrilla attack today in the Israeli "security zone" in southern Lebanon.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Big Band in Town

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Wallace Hoggson, a retired businessman and a decorated World War I pilot, misidentified his wife, to whom he had been married for 42 years at her death in 1974. She was the former Cornelia Van Siclen.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Thanksgiving Out

title: Now Let's Put Limits On Campaign Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Espey Manufacturing & Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Art in Review
description: Miquel Barcelo Leo Castelli Gallery 420 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Out of the Race
description: Forty runners have been disqualified from the New York City Marathon for various infractions, according to the race director, FRED LEBOW.

title: Filene's Basement reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from debt repurchase of $ 548,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.c-After an extraordinary charge from debt repurchase of $ 104,000 in the quarter and $ 1,162,000 in the 9 months.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Babbage's reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Militants Press Attacks on Tourists in Egypt
description: Continuing their drive to cripple the tourist industry, Islamic militants fired on a bus in southern Egypt today, wounding at least five Germans and two Egyptians, officials said.

title: Review/Dance; Four-Way Quest For Inner Truths
description: The program that the Barbara Chang Arts Ensemble presented on Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio may have been called "Heart Matters," yet its choreographers sometimes failed to scratch beneath the surface of the themes they chose.

title: Alfin Inc. reports earnings for Year to July 31
Qual-Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Qual-Med is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 SKINHEAD VIOLENCE IN EUROPE All over Eastern Europe the Communists left bleak places that are breeding grounds for unrest in which skinheads attack immigrants, who have become scapegoats for all the troubles in the region. A1 IRAQ INQUIRY GAINS FORCE The Justice Department moved closer to naming an independent counsel to investigate the Government's handling of a bank fraud case involving Iraq. It is a move that has been resisted by the Administration. A1

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was not enough to appear before the nation at the Democratic National Convention talking about her personal odyssey with AIDS, ELIZABETH GLASER said yesterday. The effort must be ongoing.

title: Nagle to Appeal N.F.L. Fine
description: Quarterback Browning Nagle of the Jets says he will appeal the $2,000 fine imposed on him by the National Football League for his involvement in a fight with defensive end Bruce Smith of the Buffalo Bills near the Jets' bench during a game at Giants Stadium on Oct. 26. Nagle said he was trying to get Smith off his legs when Irv Eatman, a Jets offensive tackle, dived and hit Smith.

title: Frederic Warriner, 76, an Actor Who Specialized in Shakespeare
description: Frederic Warriner, a versatile character actor on the New York stage who specialized in Shakespeare and Shaw, died on Tuesday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 76 years old and lived in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Trying to Revive the Waning Business of Interment
description: There are no ashes. This is a fact of life to the people who work in cemeteries and crematories. All that remains of a person, after cremation, is fragments of bone. How those become "ashes" in an urn is, well, their business.

title: O'Neal Is Mightier Than Bullets
description: Magic 127, Bullets 100

title: Publisher Plans To Step Down
description: After 43 years in the newspaper business, The Kansas City Star's publisher, James H. Hale, will retire Dec. 31.

title: A Matisse Painting Sells For a Record $14.5 Million
description: The art market got a stunning shot in the arm on Wednesday night at Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculpture. Much to even the experts' surprise, Matisse's "Harmony in Yellow," from 1927-28, which was being sold by Dr. Philip Sandbloom, a Swedish collector, set a record price of $14.5 million. The previous record for the artist, in 1989 at the height of the market, was $12.4 million when "Woman With a Red Umbrella Seated in Profile" (1919-21) sold at Sotheby's in New York.

title: Caldron of Hate -- A special report.; East Europe's Frustration Finds Target: Immigrants
description: All over Eastern Europe, the Communists left bleak places like the south side of Greifswald: row after row of instant slums, six-story prefabricated concrete housing with hardly a shop or a cafe to break the monotony.

title: Fabri-Centers of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 2,052,000, or 22 cents a share, for both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net income

title: Rangers Have Four Lines And Several Wavelengths
description: For almost a year, Mark Messier and Roger Neilson have danced around each other, and around the big power question:

title: Indians Sign Plunk
description: ERIC PLUNK yesterday became the first of the 153 free agents to sign a new contract, deciding to return to the Cleveland Indians for two years and $1.25 million.

title: Was Chambers Then the Victim of a Spy Sting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Howe's Endless Game of Chance
description: The last chance Steve Howe received when he was permitted to return to baseball in 1990 now turns out to have been his next-to-last chance. On the other hand, if he can keep producing medical or psychological reasons for the problems he has had with cocaine, his chances may be unlimited.

title: Nervously, Gratefully, Sarajevo Takes a Stroll
description: Encouraged by the first cease-fire to show any sign of lasting, thousands of people in this capital went for a stroll today in neighborhoods that have been virtually off limits since the war began seven months ago.

title: Zero Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vehicle Sales Rise Brisk 21.6%
description: Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 21.6 percent in early November, with light trucks accounting for most of the increase.

title: Bridge
description: A hybrid form of the game is popular among experts at some New York City clubs. A pool of at least 8 players form themselves into two teams by cutting, and play a short match for a money stake measured in imps, with a bonus for winning the match. Then they cut again. Some of the country's best players, continuing a tradition of the deceased Cavendish Club, gather for this purpose each Monday night at the Young Men's Philanthropic League, 4 East 80th Street.

title: Nets' Bowie Gets Set for Trial by O'Neal
description: As if he didn't have enough problems trying to please a highly suspicious new coach, Sam Bowie, whose body is held together by a variety of fragile bones and surgically implanted screws, will have to hold off a 7-foot-1-inch, 303-pound wall of muscle tonight.

title: What's the Rush on Health Care?
description: Should President-elect Bill Clinton stick to his campaign promise to send Congress a health-care reform plan in the first 100 days of his Administration? Or should he pursue a more measured course? While establishing political momentum is important for a new administration, trying to do so by honoring such a pledge would be ill-advised.

title: Trans-Atlantic Sailor Missing After Tracking System Fails
description: One of the world's most experienced long-distance sailors, Mike Plant, is missing at sea, and the American's inexplicable failure to register his boat's emergency tracking equipment appears to have seriously jeopardized his chances of being rescued in the Atlantic Ocean. The mystery of his whereabouts has underscored the absence of a fail-safe system to protect sailors on oceanic crossings.

title: 70 Months For Lawyer In Tax Fraud
description: Harvey Myerson, a flamboyant lawyer known for his expensive tastes and bitter controversies, was sentenced last night to almost six years in prison for defrauding clients and filing a false tax return.

title: The Latest Party Zone
description: It was time for another drink on the Upper East Side, which for Ronald Then involved pressing his lips against a sloped, two-foot slab of ice as two flavors of liquor, in this case tequila and Jagermeister, sloshed into his mouth. This is called a slalom shot. Mr. Then, a 22-year-old student from Washington Heights, said it was one of many reasons he traveled south to drink.

title: Bowe Pounds Title Away From Holyfield
description: Riddick Bowe, the 25-year-old challenger from Brooklyn, outgunned Evander Holyfield through 12 gritty rounds tonight to win the undisputed world heavyweight title on a unanimous decision at the Thomas and Mack Center.

description: The path of economic recovery brightened today as the Government reported that retail sales rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month and pollsters at the University of Michigan found consumer confidence soaring in the first half of November.

title: Jailers Charged With Sex Abuse Of 119 Women
description: Fourteen former employees of the Georgia women's prison here were indicted today on sexual abuse charges, including rape and sodomy, in what is being called one of the worst episodes of its kind in the history of the nation's women's prisons.

title: Now May Be the Time To Pay Insurance Loans
description: THERE was a time, not long ago, when the cheapest place for Americans to borrow money was from their own life insurance policies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the change of name of the Custer battlefield to the Little Bighorn National Battlefield referred incorrectly in some copies to the rank that George Armstrong Custer held at his death at the Battle of the Little Bighorn. Custer attained the rank of major general of volunteers in the Civil War. In the reorganization of the Army after the war, he was assigned the rank of lieutenant colonel in the Seventh Cavalry.

title: Let Women Prove They Can Fight
description: President-elect Clinton's announcement this week that he will lift the ban on gays in the military raises hopes for more changes in the armed forces. Next he should repeal the policies keeping women out of combat.

Q & Q
description: Housing for a Daughter

title: Slow Down, Mr. Trump
description: Donald Trump's proposed Riverside South development has the blessing of the City Planning Commission and is now before the City Council. Next come the lawsuits. As many critics at yesterday's public comment hearings told the council, the project has serious problems. In its present form, it probably cannot be built and won't pass environmental muster.

title: Man on Parole Is Charged in Killing of Off-Duty Officer
description: A 24-year-old Queens man serving parole on a drug conviction was charged yesterday with murdering an off-duty police officer whose naked body was found on Wednesday in a marshy lot near Kennedy International Airport.

title: Delors Has Become the Odd Man Out in Europe
description: It has been a very bad year for Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, the executive body of the European Community. Lauded until recently as the man who galvanized Europe and put flesh on the frail outline of European integration, he has now become the squinting symbol of Europe's disarray, a focus of criticism, insult and ridicule.

description: All per-share figures reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid on Jan. 27 and a 20 percent stock dividend paid on Aug. 7.

title: Prejudice on Parade
description: The haters of homosexuals lost last week in Oregon and in Portland, Me., but they'll be back. Buoyed by the distressingly strong showing for anti-gay initiatives in those states, and the approval of anti-gay measures in Colorado and Tampa, Fla., conservative Christian groups are already planning their next round of gay-bashing proposals.

title: Public School Choice, Perfected
description: Some members of New York City's Board of Education are questioning a plan by Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez to promote parental choice in public schools. These questions can help fine-tune a proposal that deserves to go forward.

title: Surprise in Abuse Trial Appears to Contradict Defense
description: The mildly retarded woman in the Glen Ridge sex assault case once told a close friend that her 1989 sexual encounter with former schoolmates was a "terrible thing" that physically "hurt" her, the friend testified today.

description: b-Net income and included a $ 2.3 million gain on the sale of a gas storage facility. title: Review/Music; From One End of the Keyboard to the Other
description: When tonality went into its celebrated coma some 80 years ago, music became obsessed by procedure. With accepted rules of discourse discredited and with the last vestiges of a musical lingua franca divided into competing dialects, composers had to find new ways of making sense, the ways often taking precedence over the sense.

title: Bit of West Bank's Future in Smooth Campus Vote
description: At a time when Palestinians are being challenged to show they are ready for self-rule, students at the West Bank's elite university have held a politically charged but peaceful campus election that is being cited as proof that the occupied territories are ready for democracy.

title: Hughes Names 2 for New Ventures Abroad
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it had appointed two longtime executives to head two new overseas ventures charged with developing more foreign business.

Run It Up the Flagpole And See if Anyone Buys
description: CONSIDERING all the fuss about trade wars, an investment strategy with a long dash of jingoism doesn't sound like a bad idea. Buy American with your investment stash and do your bit to further the flag-waving cause.

title: 2 Airline Workers Arrested in Threat
description: A former airline worker and a passenger service employee have been charged with trying to extort $600,000 from United Air Lines by threatening to blow up one of its planes, the F.B.I. announced yesterday.

title: THE TRANSITION: Packaging the Candidate; The Making of a First Family: a Blueprint
description: In late April, the political professionals working to make Bill Clinton President realized they had a potentially fatal problem: at least 40 percent ofthe voters did not much like Mr. Clinton. They saw him as a "wishy-washy," fast-talking career politician who did not "talk straight."

title: FANNIE MAE AGREES TO BUY R.T.C. PROPERTIES
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, a Government-sponsored enterprise, agreed to buy up to $100 million in mortgages for the Resolution Trust Corporation apartment buildings. The R.T.C., the nation's savings and loan cleanup agency, has an inventory of almost 300 apartment buildings containing about 25,000 units it obtained from seized savings and loans. Fannie Mae buys mortgages from banks, savings and loans and other originators. At least 35 percent of the units in the R.T.C.'s apartment buildings will be set aside at restricted rents for low-income families.

title: Prof. Arpad E. Elo Is Dead at 89; Inventor of Chess Ratings System
description: Prof. Arpad E. Elo, a physicist and astronomer who devised the system that ranks the world's chess players, and a founder of the United States Chess Federation, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Milwaukee. He was 89 years old.

Howe's History May Not Cut Price
description: The agent for Steve Howe said yesterday that the Yankees would be given the first chance to sign the reinstated free-agent pitcher, but there are indications that they may have to offer him a lucrative contract to bring him back to New York.

title: European Community Finds Its Unity Plans Under Threat
description: A month before a summit meeting of the European Community that is intended to set the stage for ambitious expansion, the goal of economic and political unity among the existing 12 members seems farther away than it was a year ago.

title: EMPLOYEE STOCK PLAN GAINS 8.6% STAKE IN TENNECO
description: Tenneco Inc. recently sold 12 million common shares to its stock employee compensation trust for $432 million. The trust holds 12 million Tenneco shares, representing about an 8.6 percent stake in the Houston-based diversified industrial company, making it one of Tenneco's largest shareholders, according to a 13-D filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Selling shares to the employee trust allows Tenneco to raise money without having to pay underwriter fees, said Gary Hovis, industry analyst at Argus Research.

title: JAPANESE MAY CUT ATOMIC SHIPMENTS
description: Yielding to the storm of international protests surrounding their shipment of plutonium from Europe, Japanese officials hinted today that they might scale back plans for 30 more shipments of the nuclear fuel in the next decade.

description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the conglomerate headed by the noted investor Warren E. Buffett, reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings had dropped nearly 60 percent, mainly because of insurance losses from Hurricane Andrew.
