The move lifts the buyback to 9.6 percent, or 11.4 million shares, from 1.2 percent, or 1.4 million shares. The 1.4 million shares remain from a previous authorization, Apple said yesterday. At its Sept. 25 fiscal year-end, Apple had 118.5 million shares outstanding. Based on yesterday's closing price of $57.75, up $2.50, in national over-the-counter trading, the total buyback is valued at $658.4 million. The buybacks are intended to offset the impact of shares issued for stock options that are exercised and for employee share plans, a spokesman said.

title: Allied-Signal Sells Stake in Union Texas
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 33.3 million common shares of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings for $585 million, ending a relationship with the oil and gas exploration company that began three decades ago.

title: After 17 Shots, Officers Find Own Colleagues Were Target
description: A detail of three New York City transit police officers on an anti-crime patrol had stumbled upon an all-too-common situation outside a Brooklyn subway station Tuesday evening: two shabbily dressed men, one with a drawn gun, menacing a woman.

title: Save the Peace Dividend
description: President-elect Bill Clinton deserves high marks for aggressively addressing a number of important issues during the transition period. But as was the case during the campaign, the most important issue since the end of World War II has received minimal attention.

title: New York's Finest, Embarrassed
description: The Suffolk County police embarrassed the New York City police last spring when they arrested six city officers on drug charges. Why hadn't the city's famous Internal Affairs Division detected so grievous a violation of law and public trust?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING A.P. Indy and Piggott Earn Top Honors

title: Growing Up Under the Eyes of a Probation Officer
description: It only took 15 minutes for Jacqueline McDonald, a probation officer, to decide that things were going badly for Montel B., the 15-year-old under her supervision.

title: The Challenge of Fish-Keeping
description: BRIGHTLY colored fish swim by with effortless grace, cruising amid calmly waving plants and artistic rock formations. Yes, a home aquarium can be beautiful and fascinating, but an informed dealer and a well-planned, well-maintained tank can mean the difference between serene beauty and lots of dead fish.

title: Richard Nixon's Unjust Reward
description: A Federal Court in Washington adds injury to insult by ruling that Richard Nixon is entitled to payment for documents seized when he was forced from the White House, including the notorious incriminating tapes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 NATO BACKS YUGOSLAV BLOCKADE NATO agreed to enforce a United Nations-backed naval blockade to tighten the trade embargo against Yugoslavia and ordered its military experts to work out operational details by Friday. A1 U.S. PRESSES FOR SERB'S OUSTER Having failed to budge President Slobodan Milosevic from his position as Serbia's strongman with economic and political sanctions, the United States is now trying to increase pressure for his ouster by supporting Serbian opposition to him, especially on Yugoslav television. A11

title: Egghead Software reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
BASEBALL;
description: The good news for major league club owners: The number of players earning between $1 million and $2 million continued to drop this year.

title: Market Place; Westinghouse Reported To Want Broadcast Sale
description: Pressed by financial troubles, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has approached Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York buyout firm, about buying its broadcasting operations, one of the conglomerate's crown jewels, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Dockers Footwear To Foote, Cone
description: Johnston & Murphy of Nashville said yesterday that it had moved its Dockers Footwear account, with billings estimated at $4 million, to Foote, Cone & Belding in San Francisco from Griffin Bacal in New York.

title: Common Folk, Too, Can Have Mattress Trouble
description: ONCE upon a time there was a princess who slept on a pea. Though there were 20 mattresses and 20 featherbeds on top of it, the pea made her black and blue. But she had it easy; she never had to go mattress shopping.

title: Tiles That Dazzle
description: To The Home Section:

title: Home Video
description: New films get the hype, but occasionally there are fresh reminders of vast other worlds on tape. One such is the annual catalogue from Movies Unlimited of Philadelphia. The 1993 edition has more than 30,000 titles in 23 categories, including action, cult classics, documentaries, musicals, performing arts, silents and religion.

title: Alaska to Kill Wolves To Inflate Game Herds
description: Trying to tip the balance of nature in favor of moose and caribous, wildlife officials have decided to start shooting wolves from airplanes over a huge portion of the Alaska wilderness.

title: With Taylor Gone, Defense Is Cautious
description: The Giants miss Lawrence Taylor in more ways than you might think. With him, they had the greatest pass-rushing outside linebacker ever. Even at the age of 33, he was still a threat to opposing quarterbacks. Without him, they have reverted to a tentative and cautious defense.

title: Trump Taj Mahal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $ 259,618,000 from plan of reorganization, in the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomeThe company's net income figures are after unpsecified charges from interest, depreciation and amortization and restructuring.Trump Taj Mahal in the latest periods had income from operations of $ 34.9 million in the quarter and $ 79.4 million in the 9 months, compared with $ 37.4 million and $ 73.7 million in year-ago periods, respectively.

title: The Government's Big Designs
description: FOR many people, the relationship between the Federal Government and the world of design is not clear at all. A new exhibit, "From Mars to Main Street: America Designs, 1965-1990," opens today and explores the way the Government responds to design issues and develops design products and projects.

title: Tyson Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Joseph Kaliff, 80, Dies; Caricatured Celebrities
description: Joseph Kaliff, a caricaturist and syndicated Broadway columnist, died on Friday at the Veterans Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Salsa Meets Jazz Village Gate

title: Trade by Mets Puts Reed Back Where He Started
description: The Mets, turning the kind of management double play that is all the rage in baseball, yesterday added to their bench power while slashing their payroll with the reacquisition of outfielder Darren Reed.

title: Sears Is Hoping to Repeat Success With Cuddly Alien
description: ONE reason Sears, Roebuck & Company decided that for a second consecutive year its crucial Christmas shopping season promotional program would center on "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" is the overwhelming popularity of that film, the highest-grossing in Hollywood history. Another, more subtle, reason might be that in many ways the story that the movie tells echoes the retailing giant's recent travails.

title: India's Little Airlines Battle a State Monopoly
description: When pilots from the state-run Indian Airlines began another job action this week, disrupting schedules and causing delays, thousands of frustrated travelers did something that had not been possible a year ago: they flew on a competing airline.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Strike Hits Tobacco Industry, And 13 Million Italians Suffer
description: In a recent rash of strikes, just about everyone here stopped work for one reason or another, and the events drew no more than a shrug and the sense that, well, in Italy, strikes are non-business as usual.

title: Clinton Should Make Gore Chief of Staff; Willkie Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Appointment At Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had named Richard B. Waugh, 49 years old, to be its new chief financial officer, effective Jan. 2.

title: Heating Oil Prices Tumble On News of Ample Supplies
description: Heating oil for delivery in December tumbled yesterday to its lowest level since early March, in reaction to further evidence that winter supplies are ample.

title: Cuomo Plans Bills On Campaign Laws
description: Complaining that legislation enacted in New York State last spring did not go far enough, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he would introduce a new package of bills aimed at revamping the state's election laws and reorganizing its lower court system.

title: Israel Bars Immigrants Who Carry the AIDS Virus
description: The Government has announced that Israel is barring immigrants carrying the virus that causes AIDS, setting off an outcry here from critics who say the ban is discriminatory and contradicts the Israeli law that gives all Jews the right to settle in Israel.

title: Smucker (J.M.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Books of The Times; Being Beautiful, Being Practical
description: Looking Around A Journey Through Architecture By Witold Rybczynski Illustrated. 301 pages. Viking Penguin. $22.

title: National Book Award For Gay Autobiography
description: Paul Monette won the National Book Award for nonfiction last night for "Becoming a Man: Half a Life Story" (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich), an autobiography about his struggle to come to terms with his homosexuality, a work he said "literally kept me alive" after discovering he had AIDS.

title: Police in Crown Heights: 'A Holding Approach'
description: When violence erupted in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last year, the Police Department initially adopted "a kind of holding approach" that for three days failed to quell the disturbances, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. But at no time, he said, did the department receive orders from City Hall to show restraint in dealing with those who caused the unrest.

title: Goetz Will Join L.P.G.A. Tour
description: VICKI GOETZ, the United States Amateur and N.C.A.A. women's golf champion, said yesterday she would join the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour next summer. Goetz, 20 years old, a sophomore at the University of Georgia, will finish her amateur career with the N.C.A.A. tournament in May at the Georgia course. (AP)

title: NATO Agrees to Use Warships to Enforce Yugoslav Blockade
description: NATO agreed today to enforce a United Nations-backed naval blockade to tighten the trade embargo against Yugoslavia and ordered its military experts to work out operational details by Friday.

title: 'Nonpartisan' Is a Virtue at State Dept.
description: For almost 90 minutes this afternoon the State Department stopped.

title: Clinton Should Make Gore Chief of Staff
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Philip Palazzo Jr., executive vice president and chief financial officer at Ammirati & Puris, New York, was named to the additional new position of general manager. * Ian McGregor was named to the new position of executive vice president and managing director at Lintas Campbell-Ewald, Los Angeles. He was previously chairman and chief executive at Lintas South Africa, Sandown, South Africa.

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: OPPENHEIMER DROPS BUY RECOMMENDATION ON BORLAND
description: Elliot Prince, an Oppenheimer & Company analyst, dropped a "buy" recommendation on Borland International Inc. on concerns about a price war in data bases with the Microsoft Corporation. Mr. Prince, who now rates Borland "market performer," cut his earnings estimates for Borland, to $1.10 a share from $1.50 a share for the year ending March 1993, and to $1.90 from $2.50 for the 1994 fiscal year. On Monday, Microsoft released Access for Windows, its first data base program, and said it would charge about $200 less a copy for Access than what competitors have charged. Borland, which has dominated the data base market with Paradox and dBase, signaled it was willing to meet Microsoft's prices. "Even if Borland wins" the data base battle, it is "winning at lower price points," the analyst said.

title: 2 Sides Ask Flexibility As Trade Talks Begin
description: Each side called on the other to show flexibility today as top American and European officials gathered at the White House's sumptuous guest house to begin another round of meetings aimed at averting a trade war that links humble animal feeds and costly white wines.

title: R.O.T.C. USES OATH ON HOMOSEXUALITY
description: The Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps is requiring all R.O.T.C. midshipmen to sign a new affidavit saying they can be discharged and forced to pay back their scholarship if they are found to be homosexual.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: COMPANY NEWS: Touring the Federal Abyss; A Plan to Cut the Deficit For a Minute or So
description: As the owner of Special Expeditions Inc. of New York, Sven-Olof Lindblad has sent his clients out to track African wildlife, navigate the Amazon and dodge Arctic icebergs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They came to pay their respects yesterday afternoon in the conference room of DC Comics to the superhero who was faster than a speeding bullet, more powerful than a locomotive, who could leap tall buildings in a single bound. In the end, even Superman could not avert death at the hands of the monster Doomsday, after they had battled for weeks. So he died yesterday in the arms of Lois Lane, his perennial sweetheart and, at the end, oh sob, his fiancee.

title: MIDWEEK REPORT
description: Week 12

title: INSIDE
description: Japanese Trade Gap Widens

title: Bonds Now 2 for 3 in M.V.P. Titles for the 90's
description: No one ever confused Barry Bonds with Mr. October, but he has gained the right to be dubbed Mr. November.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They may seem like an unlikely trio, but Borough President RUTH MESSINGER of Manhattan is teaming up this weekend with EARTHA KITT and BIANCA JAGGER at St. Peter's Church on Lexington Avenue for "A Thanksgiving Celebration of Women's Music, Words and Crafts" for the benefit of Iris House, a planned center for women living with H.I.V., which causes AIDS.

title: CANADA WILL PAY 50's TEST VICTIMS
description: In a footnote to an unusual chapter of the cold war, Canada has agreed to compensate victims of psychiatric experiments carried out mainly in the 1950's and financed in part by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: G.M. to Curtail Dealer Financing and Drop Allante
description: In another move to shore up its sagging finances, the General Motors Corporation notified its 9,000 dealers today that its General Motors Acceptance Corporation unit would no longer provide wholesale and retail financing for non-G.M. models sold by dealers who also sell General Motors cars.

title: Medtronic Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $ 50 million initial payment from Siemens AG under a patent-litigation settlement; also reflected a $ 12 million commitment to the Medtronic Foundation, and an $ 18 million reserve to provide for accelerated amortization of certain intangible assets.c-Included a charge of $ 14,356,000 from an adjustment in accounting.Medtronic said that results for its first quarter have been restated to reflect a negative impact of 24 cents in that period from an accounting change.The company also said that it adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 109 and SFAS No. 106 in the second quarter, which changed the manner of accounting for income taxes and the cost of retirees' benefits, respectively.In adopting SFAS No. 106, the company chose to immediately record the transition obligation, which is the cost of postretirement benefits earned to date by current employees and retirees. Accounting principles require that such changes be made as of the beginning of the company's fiscal year. Accordingly, the company restated its first quarter results.

title: Sports of The Times Barry Bonds Checking Out Real Estate
description: THIS was during the National League championships in Atlanta last month. A man got into a taxi, and the driver said he had just taken Barry Bonds out to a swanky suburb where Whitney Houston and Bobby Brown, the singers, make their home. Bonds had not been indulging in some afternoon star-gazing, either. He had been talking to real-estate agents.

title: Needed: An Ambassador in Moscow
description: Just as the political struggle over reform in Russia is reaching a fever pitch, Ambassador Robert Strauss has decided to come home. Whatever his reasons for leaving Moscow, Mr. Strauss feels he can "do more good" for the Russians from his office in Washington.

title: An Insult'
description: To The Home Section:

title: Forget the Cliches About Motorcyclists
description: To the Editors:

title: Martin Segal Awarded Arts Medal of Honor
description: Martin E. Segal, the founder of the International Festival of the Arts and chairman emeritus of Lincoln Center, is the recipient of this year's medal of honor, given annually by the National Arts Club for significant contributions to the arts. Mr. Segal received the award at a ceremony last night, which was attended by those in the arts at the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park.

title: Southland Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe latest third quarter included a special charge of $ 41 million, before taxes, for expenses related to closing some distribution facilities.

title: MCDONNELL CUTS PRODUCTION ON TWO MODELS
description: Faced with continued weakness in the market for new passenger jets, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it would cut output of two models, the MD-80 and MD-11, next year and delay developing a third, the MD-95. McDonnell has borne the brunt of a price war that has caused huge losses at major airlines. The airlines responded by cutting spending on planes. In 1992, McDonnell expects to deliver 90 of its smaller MD-80 jets and 43 of its MD-11 wide bodies. But the St. Louis aerospace manufacturer reported that negotiations with bank lenders had progressed: the company received permission to sell assets and moved forward in efforts to obtain a new $400 million credit line.

title: Surviving in Sarajevo
description: There is a bleakness, but also a generous spirit and an occasional smile, for a Muslim family that is coping but also thinks about fleeing. Page A12.

title: Hancock Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 5,657,000.The company said share earnings for the year-ago 9 months does not total due to rounding.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Air Layering

title: Review/Television; On the Argentine Economic Miracle
description: Probably no one explains economics to the American public in simpler, more vivid half-hour television bites than Adam Smith. But simplicity seems to have worked against Mr. Smith in his latest effort, a two-part series that tries to explain Latin America's latest surge toward prosperity. The answer never quite emerges from the talking heads that he has chosen to interview or from his own narrative.

title: Graves Looks for Passing Grade Against Miami
description: Marvin Graves smiled earlier this afternoon when someone asked if he remembered his first game against Miami. How could he forget?

title: Yanks Still Smarting After Taking a Loss
description: Gene Michael stood outside a midtown hotel Tuesday night, eager to desert the premises and eat dinner. It was shortly after the National League expansion draft had stolen the Yankees' starting third baseman and two of their top prospects, and the general manager was still assessing the damage.

title: Leonard Salvato, 40, An Architect, Is Dead
description: Leonard Salvato, an architect credited with helping to rejuvenate the New Orleans warehouse district, died on Saturday in New Orleans. He was 40 years old.

title: Atlanta vs. Augusta on Golf Issue
description: The International Olympic Committee will not vote until next June at the earliest on whether to hold a golf competition at the Atlanta Summer Games in 1996, but the issue has already divided loyalties in Georgia.

title: Call Him Earvin: 'I Can't Be Magic'
description: IF ever there was a man of contradictions, it is Magic Johnson.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Airborne Freight Corp., Seattle, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million of debt securities through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: Trump Plaza Hotel & Casino reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $ 38,205,000 from restructuring plan.The company's net income figures are after unspecified charges from interest, depreciation and amortization and restructuring.Trump Plaza Hotel & Casino said that income from operations in the latest third quarter was $ 21,207,000, compared with $ 20,186,000 in year-ago period. The Plaza's latest 9 months' income from operations increased to $ 46,729,000 from $ 28,094,000 in year-ago period.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: OUT of sight is sometimes out of mind, and that may be one reason why small household repairs are often neglected. There are other reasons, too: the unavailability and high cost of professional services, and the way it seems harder to find time for small repairs than large ones, particularly if the way to proceed is not clear.

title: Refilling the Molds Of a Silversmith
description: SHORTLY after William Spratling, an American architect, settled in Taxco, Mexico, a small mining town near Acapulco, in 1929, he opened a silver studio. The studio produced table-top items, candlesticks, platters and the jewelry for which he became well known. One of the first to combine pre-Columbian motifs with Art Deco designs, Mr. Spratling revived what had been a nearly forgotten craft in that region.

title: THE TRANSITION: Reconciliation; Bush and Clinton Proclaim End to the Election's Rancor
description: President Bush and his successor, President-elect Bill Clinton, today declared a peaceful end to a rancorous campaign year, smiling, shaking hands and chatting about world and domestic affairs at the White House.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the credit markets misstated the change in the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond. On Thursday, a new 7.625 percent bond due in November 2022 was auctioned by the Treasury. In trading on Friday, the price of the new 30-year bond fell 5/32 point. The yield on this issue, however, remained at 7.57 percent, unchanged from pre-auction trading on Thursday. The yield on the old 7.25 percent 30-year bond due in August 2002 was 7.59 percent.

title: Washington Greets Clinton With Open Arms
description: President-elect Bill Clinton walked into Washington's open arms today, gliding from the campaign he just won into the campaign he has just begun. In a sneak preview of the style and symbolism likely to mark the Clinton Presidency, he moved quickly from the august confines of the White House to the storefronts of Georgia Avenue, seeking wisdom from the President and from the people.

title: Judge's Ouster Sought in Rerun Suit
description: Hoping to overturn a Federal court decision that opened the way for television networks to own the lucrative rerun rights to popular prime-time programs, Hollywood movie producers and their allies demanded today that the Federal appeals judge who wrote the decision disqualify himself.

title: No Sweat
description: To The Home Section:

title: Fed Chief Links Tight Credit to Slowdown
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that a strong economic recovery remained elusive as long as banks were reluctant to lend and businesses were reluctant to borrow.

title: New Test to Emphasize Problem Solving
description: Disenchanted with multiple-choice tests, the New York City school system will introduce new citywide tests that emphasize the ability to solve problems rather than choose the right answers, starting with a mathematics examination for seventh graders in the spring.

title: Simms Is Throwing Again
description: Phil Simms, who began the season as the Giants' starting quarterback, threw a football today for the first time since he injured his passing elbow on Oct.4. If the elbow reacts well, he may be activated for the Dec. 6 game at Giants Stadium against the Washington Redskins, although Jeff Hostetler will probably remain the starter.

title: 2 Killings Tied to Feud Over Loot
description: At first, the lethal gunfire had all the earmarks of another battle between two factions in the Mafia's Colombo crime family. A 50-round fusillade fired by a masked gunman from a hand machine gun killed two men and wounded three people Tuesday night in a social club in Red Hook, Brooklyn, long a stronghold of the Colombo family.

title: Hong Kong Gets a Taste of Radical Chic
description: WHEN Polam Lau, the owner of Le Cadre, a tiny and spare home furnishings shop in Hong Kong, arranges an opening for a one-week show, he sends out 500 invitations.

title: Jets Say Secondary Deserves Limelight
description: No secondary in the league this season has faced a group of quarterbacks stronger than the last four the Jets' secondary has just gone through.

title: POLITICAL MOTIVE CITED IN SCRUTINY OF PASSPORT FILES
description: The State Department's internal investigator said today that he suspected that the White House was aware of what he called a "politically motivated" search through Bill Clinton's passport records while it was under way. But he said there was no evidence that the White House had instigated the search.

title: LOCKHEED UNIT GETS NASA PACT OF UP TO $1.9 BILLION
description: The Lockheed Corporation's Space Operations unit received a contract from NASA of as much as $1.9 billion over 10 years. Lockheed will provide ground services at the Kennedy Space Center launch site for the space shuttle. The duties include firefighting, security patrols, supporting the space center's computers and running its health center. Lockheed has 6,200 people working at the space center, preparing shuttles for their next missions after they return from space. The contract will result in few new Lockheed employees at the space center, though. Lockheed intends to subcontract its new responsibilities to 3,000 employees of EG&G, the company that is currently handling the space center's support operations.

title: U.S. Is Backing Serbian President's Internal Foes
description: Having failed to budge President Slobodan Milosevic from his position as Serbia's strongman with economic and political sanctions, the United States is now trying to increase pressure for his ouster by supporting Serbian opposition to him, especially on Yugoslav television.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY SHOCK AND CAUTION AFTER A SHOOTING

title: Populist Clinton Begins the Shift to President Clinton
description: President-elect Bill Clinton set out today on the politically perilous journey from outsider to insider.

title: RETRIAL NEAR END IN CONTRA AFFAIR
description: The second trial of Clair E. George, a former top official of the Central Intelligence Agency charged with lying about the Iran-contra affair, is lurching to an end, drained of most of its drama and suspense.

title: Victor Bernstein, 87, A Retired Editor, Dies
description: Victor H. Bernstein, a retired editor and writer who covered Nazi Germany and the Nuremberg trials, died on Tuesday at Yale-New Haven Hospital in New Haven. He was 87 years old and lived in New Milford, Conn.

title: An Anxious Israel, 2 German Visitors and a Riveting Tableau
description: In this country that was born in the pain of Nazi Germany's horrors, leaders of the new Germany have arrived this week, reassuring their sensitive hosts that there will not be another fire this time.

title: Marathon Winner Made Headlines Back Home in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Redoubling the Efforts At Teaching Geography
description: Students in Allyson Geary's ninth-grade class at Central High School in Independence, Ore., watch the Los Angeles Dodgers on television at home. But when Ms. Geary asked them in September where Los Angeles was, most responded with blank stares.

title: Topics of The Times; A Star Is Born
description: He doesn't look like Madonna -- although, given her infinite variety, she may choose one day to look like him. He doesn't sing like Madonna, dance like Madonna, strip like Madonna or propose to free Americans of their Puritan heritage like Madonna. Never mind. Socks Clinton is a star.

title: Italian-American Institute Wins Round Against City University
description: Italian-American faculty members and their supporters won a legal round against the City University of New York yesterday when a Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction aimed at settling allegations of bias against the university.

title: Westvaco Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 25 million from cost-cutting programs, as well as nonrecurring gains of 13 cents a share.

title: Hadassah Dies at 83; Dancer and Instructor
description: Hadassah, a pioneer of Israeli and Indian dancing in America, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge
description: When it starts to get cold in New York City, many bridge experts head south, and some go farther than Florida. A month ago a group including Alvin Roth and Zia Mahmood, both of Manhattan, and Mark Molson of Fenton, Mich., were in Barbados playing in a sociable tournament. The diagramed deal from the team event, with Roth sitting East and Molson West, featured some interesting defense.

title: Hartford Legislators Focus of U.S. Inquiry Over Banking Votes
description: Federal investigators have questioned at least 18 present and former Republican state lawmakers and searched the home and office of the state's Republican Party chairman in an inquiry into a series of 1989 votes about allowing out-of-state banks to operate in Connecticut.

title: Hewlett-Packard reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included special charges of 36 cents a share for voluntary employment reduction programs, relocations and related facilities consolidations in both the quarter and year; the year also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 332,000,000.c-Included special charges of 40 cents a share for voluntary employment reduction programs, relocations and related facilities consolidations in both the quarter and year.The company said the accounting adjustment in fiscal year 1992 reflected the adoption of new standards that accounted for nonpension postretirement benefits, such as retiree medical benefits.

title: Breast Cancer Research Must Have the Funds; Projects Lack Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooper Cos. Executive
description: A Federal judge has signed an order freezing the assets of Gary Singer, former co-chairman of the Cooper Companies, a New York-based contact lens maker. Mr. Singer was indicted last week; prosecutors charged that he traded junk bonds using confidential information provided by a former bond analyst at the Keystone Group Inc. The order, signed Friday by District Judge Milton Pollack, also freezes the assets of Mr. Singer's brother, Steven, Cooper's chief operating officer, executive vice president and assistant general counsel. The assets of Gary Singer's wife, Karen, were also frozen.

title: Calendar: Fine Crafts From Around the World
description: An Austrian Designer I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, 590 Madison Avenue at 57th Street; (212) 745-3500.

title: 2d Casino Operator Woos Bridgeport in Gaming Bid
description: A second major casino operator, Harrah's Casino Hotels, made a presentation to Bridgeport business and political leaders today, making it likely that casinos will compete to open in this depressed industrial city if Connecticut legalizes casino gambling.

title: Colonel in Hanoi Tells Senators How 4 M.I.A.'s Died in a Battle
description: Documents and wartime artifacts released this week by the Vietnamese Government have allowed American investigators to determine that four soldiers listed as missing from the Vietnam War did in fact die, the chairman of a Senate investigating panel said today.

title: New Editor for Fitness
description: Rona Cherry, the former editor in chief of Longevity, has been named editor in chief of Fitness. Ms. Cherry helped to start Longevity in 1988 and was editor in chief for more than three years. She also served as vice president of new magazine development for General Media International, which publishes Longevity. Ms. Cherry has also been a reporter with The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal and an associate editor at Newsweek. Fitness, which is published by The New York Times Company Women's Magazines, was started in 1987 as part of Family Circle's Great Ideas series. It became a quarterly magazine in January.

title: Benjamin R. Raphael; Lawyer, 80
description: Benjamin R. Raphael, a former president of the Brooklyn Bar Association who practiced law in New York City for more than four decades, died on Friday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami. He was 80 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: 34 Indicted in a 3-Month Sting On Theft and Insurance Fraud
description: Posing as brokers for stolen cars, Suffolk County authorities recovered 42 cars and a cache of weapons in an elaborate three-month sting operation in which 34 people were indicted on theft and fraud charges.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Boukman Eksperyans S.O.B.'s

title: Transcripts Show Confusion in 1989 Oil Spill
description: Newly released transcripts of phone conversations in the hours after the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill paint a picture of disarray and confusion as oil industry officials struggled frantically to grapple with the nation's worst environmental disaster.

title: Treasuries and Municipals Gain
description: Prices rose and yields fell yesterday across the board in the Treasury market. The municipal bond market also gained as investors bought up $1.26 billion in North Carolina power bonds.

title: Events: Antiques Expo And Christmas Fairs
description: Antiques on the Hudson Piers 88, 90 and 92, 12th Avenue between West 48th and 52d Streets; (201) 384-0010.

title: Dow Posts 14.05 Gain; Volume Up
description: A powerful rally in Tokyo spilled over to the United States yesterday, where a snapback in oil and technology stocks enabled the market to rebound from Tuesday's losses.

title: Slim Crowd Not Neutral To Devils
description: Devils 3, Sabres 2

title: CHRYSLER TO PRODUCE LH CAR AT NEWARK, DEL., PLANT
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it would invest $137 million to add production of its new LH sedans to its Newark, Del., assembly plant by fall 1993. Chrysler will initially build the Dodge Intrepid version of the LH at the plant after adding a body shop and using part of the existing final assembly line. Newark now makes the Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim sedans, as well as the Chrysler LeBaron sedan, coupe and convertibles. Production of the Eagle Vision and Chrysler Concorde versions of the LH sedans could be added at Newark later, the company said. All three LH cars now are assembled only at its Bramalea, Ontario, plant. Chrysler will be able to produce an additional 90,000 LH cars a year from Newark, compared with only 66,000 more cars if a third shift was added to Bramalea. Separately, Moody's said it was reviewing Chrysler's debt for possible upgrade.

title: Tallaght Journal; Ireland's New Job Seekers: Can You Spare a Vote?
description: In his 46 years, Michael Keating has been a high-school English teacher, Lord Mayor of Dublin, Member of Parliament, Minister for Youth and Sport, novelist and, most recently, a county councillor for this suburban district on Dublin's southwest edge.

title: Refunding Bonds Priced by Texas
description: A $250 million offering of general obligation refunding bonds was priced yesterday by the Texas Public Finance Authority to yield a maximum 6.35 percent for securities due in 2020.

title: Under Siege: A Muslim Family Survives, With Fear and Grace, in Sarajevo
description: It is cold now at the home of Amra and Sakir Dzirlo, bitterly so when the winter wind beats against the plastic sheeting that has replaced window glass broken by exploding shells. But the chill that pervades 27 Marshal Tito Street is deeper than the physical hardships of the Sarajevo siege.

title: Mickey and Bambi, Meet Mandy and Billy
description: IT may be hard to believe, but some people can just never get enough of those oh-so-cute Disney characters. That's what the Disney Consumer Products company is wishing very, very hard upon a star. The company has just introduced "A New Generation of Disney Babies," a mind-boggling array of products.

title: Egghead Net Plunges 75%; Official Quits
description: Egghead Software Inc. reported today that quarterly earnings had plunged 75 percent and cited intense competition and price-cutting in software retailing.

title: Longs Drug Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Caesars World Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Jacobs Engineering Names New Chief Executive Officer
description: Joseph J. Jacobs, the 76-year-old founder and chairman of the Jacobs Engineering Group Inc., said today that he was turning over the chief executive reins to a successor before ill health or a crisis forced him out.

title: Former Aide to Milken Avoids Prison Term
description: In a case in which Michael R. Milken gave his account of wrongdoing at Drexel Burnham Lambert during its heyday, a Federal district judge ruled in Manhattan yesterday that a former protege of Mr. Milken would not go to prison for paying a kickback to a Drexel customer.

title: Dorothy Kirsten, a Lyric Soprano, Is Dead at 82
description: Dorothy Kirsten, an American lyric soprano who sang leading roles at the Metropolitan Opera for 30 years and was particularly renowned for her performances of Puccini heroines, died yesterday morning at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 82 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Topics of The Times; Correction on Mara Letica
description: An item in Topics of the Times on Nov. 2 incorrectly described Mara Letica, President Bush's nominee for ambassador to the former Yugoslav state of Croatia.

title: Intermark Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 4,622,000, or 26 cents a share.c-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 1,664,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 10,498,000, or 60 cents a share, in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,367,000, or 7 cents a share.Intermark said that its revenue decline was due principally to reduced sales at its Partner Co. Liquor Barn as a result of 16 retail store closures late last year.The company also said it recognized a $ 2.7 million improvement in the latest quarter in its Triton unit's equity in earnings of its 26.2 percent investment in Fuqua Industries.

title: Gretzky Says He's Improving
description: Wayne Gretzky, idle this season with an upper-back injury, said yesterday that he is feeling better and might begin skating "by late in the season, maybe February."

title: Baker Hughes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 79.2 million.c-Included charge of $ 62.9 million for restructuring and litigation and insurance claims, and a gain of $ 56.1 million from the sale of BJ Services common stock.Latest quarter and year's share earnings are after $ 3 million and $ 5.3 million, respectively, for dividends on preferred stock.

title: CHEVRON REALIGNS TOP MANAGEMENT AFTER JOB CUTS
description: The Chevron Corporation said it would realign responsibilities for top executives as part of a corporate evaluation that resulted in 1,500 jobs being cut last week to save $235 million. A key change: the realignment of two vice chairmen to head separate divisions that will include all company operations in specific business areas. Previously, operations were separated by United States and overseas divisions rather than by business operation. Dennis Bonney will head all oil, natural gas and coal exploration and production. Jim Sullivan will head all refining, marketing and chemicals operations.

title: Essay; Eight Rounds To Go
description: Having inundated journalists with misinformation for more than a decade, James Baker and his amazing leakage machine are down to their last piteous squirt: that the cause of Middle East peace would best be served by appointing Baker and his "strongly-condemn-Israel" crowd asspecial envoys. He even sounded out the Israelis to see if they would object.

title: Tax-Exempt Yields Off a Bit While Taxables Are Flat
description: Yields offered by tax-exempt money market funds moved slightly lower in the latest week, while taxable funds were unchanged, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, which surveys more than 850 funds.

title: Review/City Ballet; New Faces, More 'Nutcrackers'
description: The more things change the more they are not the same, as the French don't say. It could have been just another opening of the New York City Ballet, but Tuesday night's gala benefit with its Russian theme ushered in a fall-winter season that includes some new wrinkles: there will be unfamiliar faces, especially among the men, and more "Nutcrackers."

title: Without Firing Shot, Espanol Captures Belize
description: In 1796, when 32 Spanish ships of the line gathered offshore to take over an English loggers' outpost here, 240 men rallied to defend this nascent British colony tucked in a small corner of Central America.

title: A Retail Season of Hope and Caution
description: With their fingers tightly crossed and rabbits' feet stashed in their pockets, merchants are predicting healthy -- but not robust -- sales increases this holiday season.

title: Anne Wilder Memorial
description: A memorial service for Anne G. Wilder, the chairwoman of Playwrights Horizons, is to be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the Playwrights Horizons Mainstage Theater, 416 West 42d Street, Manhattan. Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright, and Andre Bishop, a former artistic director of the company, are to be among the speakers. Mrs. Wilder died on Sept. 26 at the age of 63. Information: (212) 564-1235.

title: Article 266292 -- No Title
description: The main lawyers, accountants and financial advisers of R. H. Macy & Company and its creditors have asked a Federal bankruptcy judge for $5.27 million in fees for the three months ended Oct. 31, according to court documents filed in United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. The firms also requested $436,175 in expenses.

title: Breast Cancer Research Must Have the Funds; Management Question
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 New Offerings Backed by Assets
description: The First Boston Corporation was the lead manager yesterday for two asset-backed deals totaling $914 million.

title: Britain Stays Firm on Hong Kong, But Calls for 'Calm' Negotiations
description: Britain today reiterated its plans to introduce more democracy to Hong Kong before returning the colony to Chinese rule in 1997, but called on China to bring forward counterproposals if it has objections.

title: Valvano Returns to Broadcasting
description: Five months after being diagnosed with cancer, the college basketball analyst JIM VALVANO returns to ESPN tomorrow night a more overtly spiritual person who vowed to spend considerable time raising money for cancer research.

title: An Architect's City In Black and White
description: SOMETIMES a few rooms of black-and-white photographs can evoke a whole era. And that is just the case at the Urban Center galleries, 457 Madison Avenue at East 51st Street, where the Municipal Art Society's "Stanford White's New York: A Celebration of the City" is on display through Dec. 4.

title: Eleanor Spencer, 97, Medieval-Art Scholar
description: Dr. Eleanor P. Spencer, a scholar of medieval art, died on Tuesday at Le Vieux Chateau, a retirement home near Paris. She was 97 years old.

title: Foote, Cone to Buy Mojo in South Pacific
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had reached agreement in principle with Chiat/Day Holdings Inc., parent of Chiat/Day/Mojo, to acquire the Mojo network in Australia and New Zealand, with billings of $180 million and 220 employees.

title: Lobbying Supporters; Mayor Seeks 'Responsible Voices' on Crown Heights
description: Over wine, crudites and lox on bread, Mayor David N. Dinkins briefed several dozen prominent Jewish secular and religious leaders in an unannounced meeting Tuesday night to galvanize what he has called "the responsible voices" who have been drowned out in the aftermath of the Crown Heights verdict.

title: Some Well-Dressed Walls of Yore
description: PEOPLE have decorated the walls in their homes for thousands of years, ever since prehistoric men and women first took charcoal to cave walls. An exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum explores a small part of this long history. "From Background to Foreground: Looking at an 18th-Century Wallpaper" begins Tuesday and continues through April 3.

title: Profits Fall, Hopes Rise At Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported today that its earnings for its fourth quarter fell 46 percent. But the company's stock surged more than $3 a share based on the company's report that its orders for the quarter were up 20 percent, to a record $4.4 billion.

title: Ross Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Foreign Affairs; Shoot to Feed Somalia
description: "If the Somali war chiefs read in the newspapers that U.S. or U.N. forces are coming to their country to blow their heads off, will they start slaughtering relief workers or start behaving?" asked a senior Bush Administration official. Neither he nor his colleagues have any idea. But they will soon find out.

title: U.S. Officials Defend Data On Economy
description: Still smarting from election-week attacks on the integrity of Government statistics, the Commerce Department today took the highly unusual step of inviting closer scrutiny of its methods for compiling reports on gross domestic product, the broadest gauge of American economic performance.

title: YELTSIN PLANS END TO A-SUB PROGRAM
description: Seeking to persuade South Korea of Russia's peaceful intentions in Asia and around the world, President Boris N. Yeltsin told the National Assembly here today that his country would halt the production of nuclear submarines in two or three years.

title: Olympia May Yield Real Estate
description: Warned by Canada's leading banks that its three-week-old plan to restructure debts would be rejected, Olympia & York is preparing sweeping new proposals that would allow its creditors to seize some of Canada's most prestigious office buildings, lawyers for the insolvent Canadian real estate giant said today.

title: Abroad at Home; Action or Death
description: "There are a lot of bad situations. This is the worst. It is a national disgrace, a world disgrace."

title: Review/Art; At the Armory, Abundance Without Great Peaks
description: Sometimes eclectic is just another word for nervous. At least that's how it looks at the seventh annual "Modernism" show at the Park Avenue Armory, where a predominance of cluttered, often scattershot displays suggests that dealers are anxiously trying to appeal to a wide range of tastes.

title: EXCEPTION BY U.N. TO BELGRADE CURBS
description: At American urging, a United Nations Security Council committee voted today to approve an exemption to the embargo against Yugoslavia to allow delivery of television equipment to an independent station in Belgrade.

title: Big Board Short Sales Continue Trend Upward
description: The latest increase is the eighth consecutive increase in short interest, which has risen a whopping 38 percent since mid-March.Up a Bit on the Amex

title: Mitchell Learning to Do His Talking on the Field
description: In his first pro season, tight end Johnny Mitchell of the Jets has learned a lot, such as proper blocking technique, how to run a precise pass route and how to deal with injuries.

title: United Way Says Slump and Scandal Are Bringing Sharp Dip in Donations
description: Wrestling with the effects of a sluggish economy and of the corrosive scandal at its national association this year, officials at the United Way say they fear that 1992 will bring the sharpest decline in donations in more than 40 years.

title: Review/Film; How a Sexy Lover Makes A Man Jealous of His Wife
description: Manuel Gutierrez Aragon's film "The Most Beautiful Night" should reinforce the impression that sex in the cinema of post-Franco Spain is different from the sex in movies that come from anywhere else in the world. As portrayed in the films of Pedro Almodovar, Vicente Aranda and others, it is usually tempestuous, often fraught with hysteria and surprisingly androgynous. This devil-may-care flaunting of eroticism suggests a head-on collision between traditional Roman Catholic notions of propriety and the rebellious spirit of a cinema still giddy from its liberation after years of oppression and censorship.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS, MCI AGREE ON PHONE-CARD SERVICE
description: The American Express Company's travel management services unit and the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that they would introduce a corporate phone-card service, called the Corporate Telecard, in the first quarter of 1993. Holders of the American Express Corporate Card could use their account numbers to make MCI long-distance calls. Card holders would be billed on their American Express statements at the applicable MCI rate.

title: Hayes Laments Lack of Yanks' Courtesy Call
description: Charlie Hayes of the Colorado Rockies is still waiting to hear from his old team, the Yankees. He does not expect an explanation as to why he was left unprotected during the expansion draft and, in the sometimes cold world of baseball, maybe he does not deserve one. Still, Hayes expected some gesture from the club.

title: U.N. in Bosnia War: Hope of Big World Role May Be a Casualty
description: The gunfire exchanged between French troops and Serbian forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina today was only the latest difficulty encountered by the United Nations in its attempt to deliver food and medicine to needy civilians trapped in the civil war in the Balkans. All the difficulties raise questions about the organization's ability to develop new and more ambitious roles for itself in the post-cold-war world.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Marines Find Racial Disparity in Officer Programs
description: The Marine Corps has discovered, virtually by accident, that minority members drop out of their officer training programs at higher rates than white candidates, and the service is baffled about why that is.

title: Washington Talk; In F.B.I. Agent's Novel, It's 'Humps' vs. 'Suits'
description: With a .38-caliber snubnose wedged into his ankle holster, Special Agent Mike Devlin of the Federal Bureau of Investigation catches fugitive killers and crooks in the grimy reaches of Detroit. But an invisible enemy stalks his trail: a suffocating law enforcement bureaucracy at the F.B.I.

title: What Did the White House Know?
description: The State Department report on the ransacking of Gov. Bill Clinton's passport file reaches a distressing but obvious conclusion: that the search was politically motivated, aimed at influencing the election.

title: Now, Jerry Della Femina Redux
description: When Clark Gable returned to movie-making after World War II, M-G-M crowed, "Gable's back and Garson's got him." Yesterday, the news was that Jerry's back and Newsweek's got him.

title: Term Limits Set Us on the Road to Democracy; Invisible in the East
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Financial Industry Protests Government's Role
description: Japanese depositors, concerned over the financial health of the nation's banks and insurance companies, are fleeing these institutions for the safety of the Government-controlled postal savings and insurance systems. Responding with an unusual display of anger, Japan's financial institutions held a public rally today to attack what they described as unfair competition.

title: Art in Review
description: A. R. Penck 'Drawings, a Retrospective' David Nolan Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: SMITHKLINE BEECHAM BUYS ICI's DENTAL BUSINESS
description: The consumer brands division of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said it had bought Imperial Chemical Industry P.L.C.'s dental business for an undisclosed amount. SmithKline Beecham said it had bought ICI's international Corsodyl business, a treatment for gingivitis, and the rights to a new polymer technology with oral hygiene applications.

title: For Children
description: 'One at a Time' Museum of Modern Art 11 West 53d Street Manhattan (212) 708-9400 Recommended ages: 5 and up Through May 1, 1993

title: Robert Duvall as Stalin, the Embodiment of Evil
description: "Stalin," the nearly three-hour HBO Pictures presentation having its American premiere tomorrow at 8 P.M., is a grandly ambitious and lavish project, much of it filmed within the Kremlin even as the Soviet Union was coming unglued in the final months of 1991. Robert Duvall plays the title role. The director is the Czechoslovak-born Ivan Passer ("Cutter's Way"); the director of photography is the Hungarian-born Vilmos Zsigmond ("Close Encounters of the Third Kind"). The supporting cast comes from an international A-list.

title: Rorem World Premiere At Richard Tucker Gala
description: Grace Bumbry, Ghena Dimitrova and Thomas Hampson are among the artists who are to take part in this year's Richard Tucker Music Foundation Gala, Sunday at 6 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The evening will also be the occasion of the world premiere of a song by Ned Rorem, commissioned by the foundation.

title: Art in Review
description: Andrew Lord 65 Thompson Street Gallery (near Spring Street) SoHo Through Jan. 9

title: INSIDE
description: President's Mother Dies

title: Will Dome Stifle Miami?
description: It wasn't all that long ago, Jan. 1, 1986, that a Miami football team experienced a deafening nightmare in an indoor stadium: Tennessee 35, Miami 7 in the Superdome, a loss in the Sugar Bowl that cost the Hurricanes a national championship.

title: Doubletree Puts Account in Review
description: The Doubletree Hotels Corporation in Phoenix said yesterday that it had placed its estimated $11.5 million account in review, anticipating the expiration in April of its contract with GBF/Ayer in Los Angeles. GBF/ Ayer has handled the lodging chain's account since February 1991.

title: Elliott B. Nixon; Lawyer, 71
description: Elliott B. Nixon, an expert in maritime law, died on Nov. 3 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Prices of Treasuries Move Lower
description: The bond market yesterday continued to sound its one sure theme -- volatility.

title: Shining Path Reeling in Wake of Chief's Capture
description: Two months after the capture of its leader, the Peruvian rebel group known as Shining Path is riven by dissent, betrayal and an internal power struggle, police officials say.

title: Audre Lorde, 58, A Poet, Memoirist And Lecturer, Dies
description: Audre Lorde, a black feminist writer who became the poet laureate of New York State in 1991, died on Tuesday at her home on St. Croix. She was 58 years old.

title: Compleat Eckersley: M.V.P. As Well
description: Benefiting from an abundance of talent in his right arm and an abundance of talent in Toronto, Dennis Eckersley registered his second post-season electoral victory yesterday.

title: East Europe Police Join to Fight Smuggling
description: With organized crime gangs smuggling drugs, cars and weapons across the newly porous borders of the former Soviet empire, senior police officials from Poland, Ukraine, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Russia and Belarus agreed this week to forge closer links.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 U.N. TROOPS ATTACKED IN BOSNIA U.N. troops got into an exchange of gunfire with Serbian forces while making their first overland deliveries of food to a besieged town in Bosnia and Herzegovina. A1 News Analysis: Doubts about the U.N.'s ability in meet new roles. A8

title: Lind Is Traded to Royals For Two Pitching Prospects
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates traded second baseman JOSE LIND to the Kansas City Royals yesterday for two pitching prospects.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY North Stars Prevail Goalie Jon Casey came within 7 minutes 51 seconds of his third shutout of the season as the Minnesota North Stars defeated the Tampa Bay Lightning by 4-1 last night in Tampa, Fla. Brian Bradley's unassisted goal foiled Casey's bid for the 12th shutout of his career. Bradley directed the puck through Casey's legs while falling down to extend his consecutive-point streak to 10 games. Casey finished with 38 saves. Minnesota improved to 10-8-2 over all and improved its Norris Division-best road record to 5-5. (AP) Jets 5, Red Wings 3: Rob Murray scored his first goal in three seasons to break a third-period tie and give Winnipeg the victory over the Red Wings in Detroit. Murray's last goal came for Washington in the 1989-90 season when he was playing for Washington, coached by the current Red Wings coach, Bryan Murray, and later by his brother, Terry. (AP) Nordiques 4, Canadiens 3: Joe Sakic scored a goal and set up two more, recording his 400th career point, as Quebec rallied to defeat Montreal in Quebec. The Nordiques' Mats Sundin set a club record with his second-period assist. He has points in 20 consecutive games, eclipsing the team record of 19 set in 1983-84 by Peter Stastny. (AP) Flames 4, Canucks 3: Joe Nieuwendyk and Theoren Fleury scored within a 46-second span of the second period, leading Calgary to the victory over visiting Vancouver. Nieuwendyk scored at 3:06 and Fleury clicked moments later to increase Calgary's lead to 3-0 and send the Flames to their fourth straight home-ice victory. (AP) SOCCER Spain Stops U.S. Francisco Ledesma scored a pair of second-half goals as Spain rallied to beat the United States by 5-3 last night in the first round of the FIFA World Indoor Championship in Hong Kong. The United States (1-1) is tied with Russia (1-1) for second place in Group D behind Spain (2-0). The Americans will play China (0-2) on Saturday. (AP) GOLF Peoples Grabs Lead David Peoples, an American playing in his first Japanese tour event, fired a six-under-par 66 yesterday and took a one-shot lead in the first round of the Dunlop Phoenix tournament in Miyazaki, Japan. Peoples mastered the 6,993-yard Phoenix course in southern Japan, needing just 27 putts. Yoshinori Mizumaki of Japan was one shot back. (AP) BASKETBALL Redmen to Play Duke St. John's announced yesterday that it would play Duke, winner of the last two National Collegiate Athletic Association titles, next season on the Blue Devils' court and in 1994-95 at Madison Sqaure Garden. TENNIS Ivanisevic Beats Courier Since arriving for the ATP Tour championship, top-ranked Jim Courier has found fault with the tour's ranking system and the slick, quick surface at the Frankfurt Festhalle, among other things. But yesterday, there was no assigning blame or making excuses after Goran Ivanisevic had thrashed him, 6-3, 6-3, in a round-robin match. Ivanisevic improved to 2-0 and clinched a semifinal spot with his complete performance. Also, Richard Krajicek overcame a minor injury to his left ankle in the second set to beat Michael Chang, 2-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-4). Pete Sampras (3-0), already in the semifinals from his group, was a 3-6, 6-3, 6-3 winner over Petr Korda (0-3).

title: Gregory Markopoulos, Film Maker, 64, Dies
description: Gregory J. Markopoulos, an avant-garde film maker, died last Friday in Freiburg, Germany. He was 64 years old.

title: Peace Corps Is Due to Send First Volunteers to Russia
description: The Peace Corps is sending its first volunteers to Russia this week. On Friday, 102 business executives and graduates of business schools will arrive in Moscow for three months of language training before being assigned to small business centers throughout Russia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: 'Tobacco' Its Middle Name, Law Firm Thrives, for Now
description: In early November, eight years after she died of lung cancer, Rose Cipollone joined John Ross, Mildred Peters, Peter Ierardi and a number of others on a lengthy list of losers in lawsuits against tobacco companies. They or their survivors took the cigarette companies to court, only to be vanquished once they got there by the law firm of Shook, Hardy & Bacon.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CARMIKE CINEMAS INC., Columbus, Ga., said it had purchased 16 theaters in Utah and Colorado from Cinamerica Theaters L.P., a partnership between Time Warner Inc. and Paramount Communications Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: W. David Streeter; Financial Manager, 75
description: W. David Streeter, an expert in hospital financial management, died on Monday at his home in Cuddebackville, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Review/Film; An '87 Mock Documentary by Fellini
description: Federico Fellini's "Intervista" (Interview) can be described as an impromptu fiction, a mock documentary or simply a divertissement. There are some who have suggested that it's just something Fellini turned out when he had nothing better to do, as if the cinema master had become a Sunday painter.

title: Plot Thickens for Giants' Defense in Disarray
description: The Giants' defense, which has complained all season about the read-and-react philosophy of its new coordinator, Rud Rust, may take matters into its own hands. Pepper Johnson, the mercurial inside linebacker, said today that if the Giants started badly Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles, he was ready to play a freelance rather than a structured defense.

title: Alan H. Balsam; Film Editor, 42
description: Alan H. Balsam, a Hollywood feature film editor, died last Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 42 years old.

title: Islander Scorers Are Coasting, Arbour Charges
description: On to Western Canada trudge the Islanders, losers again tonight, losers in six of their last seven games. This time the verdict was 5-2, in favor of the Boston Bruins, at old Boston Garden.

title: Juror: Race Had No Role In Acquittal
description: In the most extensive comments by a juror since Lemrick Nelson Jr. was acquitted last month in the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum, a 25-year-old college student said yesterday that race and general mistrust of the police played no role in the jury's decision.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES TRUST, Chicago, bought the 229-unit Preston Willow Bend apartment complex in Plano, Tex. Terms of the purchase were not released.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST HOME-CARE PLAN FACES BATTLE OVER COSTS

title: U.S. Raids Computer Pornography at Cornell
description: F.B.I. agents raided the dormitory room of a Cornell University sophomore Wednesday afternoon in an investigation into the distribution of child pornography through an international computer network.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sir Roland Hanna

title: Tandy Selects Texas Agency
description: The Tandy Corporation named GSD&M in Austin, Tex., to create advertising for new products such as Tandy computers that are sold at Tandy's Radio Shack stores. GSD&M's initial assignment will be to work with Tandy's in-house marketing team to develop a campaign for a new Tandy computer called Sensation.

title: Darkness and Disorder in Subway: Questions Swirl in Police Shooting
description: It was already dark, nearing the end of the homebound rush Tuesday night. Trailing a suspected thief, the transit officers, two men and a woman in plain clothes, came down the steps from the elevated mezzanine of the Brooklyn subway station. At the street, they emerged from the station door and immediately stumbled upon a shocking tableau in the shadows.

title: Review/Film; Taking a Close-Up Look At a Luminary of Jazz
description: "Texas Tenor: The Illinois Jacquet Story" starts out with a close-up of something fuzzy and spends the rest of its 81 minutes stylishly using close-ups and blurred shots to produce a modernist documentary. The fuzz turns out to be the chin of the tenor saxophonist Illinois Jacquet; the rest of the opening scene is close-ups of lips, reeds and mouthpiece. Filmed in black and white from 1988 to 1990, Mr. Jacquet at various times fills a third of the screen, sometimes less, his skin tone light against the coal-black background. Sometimes he takes over half the screen, and a huge portion of the screen always remains coal black, contrasting detail against nothingness. This is a documentary with style.

title: THE TRANSITION: Social Scene; The Clintons Are in Town, and Washington Is Ready to Party
description: The economy wasn't the only thing that went into decline under George Bush. When it came to partying, he turned out to be a real pooper, throwing only the required bashes, hardly ever venturing to the salons of Georgetown and hurrying off to Camp David on weekends.

title: Desperation. Frustration. Despair. Rangers.
description: Coach Roger Neilson changed every one of his Ranger lines. He sent down one defenseman and called up another. He played both of his tough guys, Tie Domi and Joe Kocur, to combat the Philadelphia Flyers' hard-checking style.

title: Hong Kong Risks China's Anger in Giving Airport Go-Ahead
description: In a move certain to increase tension between China and Britain over the future of Hong Kong, the colonial Government announced today that it would spend $1.2 billion to prepare the site for a new airport here despite Beijing's refusal to approve the financing of the project.

title: Henry B. Keiser Entrepreneur, 65
description: Henry B. Keiser, a lawyer and businessman in Washington, died Monday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 65 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Jury Ruling Shouldn't Be Retroactive
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League TEXAS RANGERS -- Purchased the contract of Jon Shave, infielder, from Oklahoma City of the American Association. Signed John Russell, catcher, to a minor-league contract.

title: U.S. Sees 'Good Progress' on European Trade
description: The United States and the European Community failed again today to reach an agreement on a farm subsidy dispute that threatens to explode into a trade war. But at the end of the talks here, both sides said they had made progress and would meet again soon.

title: Quest for Plant Is Discontinued
description: The United States Coast Guard yesterday called off its search for Mike Plant, the prominent solo sailor, noting that an aerial survey of more than 200,000 square miles in the Atlantic Ocean over six days had turned up no signs of him. Plant, who left New York Harbor on Oct. 16 on a voyage to France, relayed a radio message to friends Oct. 21 that the electronic system was down on his 60-foot racing yacht, Coyote. He has not been heard from directly since.

title: Review/Film; Jaded Cop, Raped Nun: Bad Indeed
description: When Abel Ferrara calls something bad, better believe it: he means business. Mr. Ferrara, whose gleefully down-and-dirty films include "Fear City" and "King of New York," has used his latest, "Bad Lieutenant," as a form of personal one-upmanship. He has come up with his own brand of supersleaze, in a film that would seem outrageously, unforgivably lurid if it were not also somehow perfectly sincere.

title: Eric Burroughs; Stage and Radio Actor, 81
description: Eric Burroughs, a stage and radio actor from the 1930's to the 50's, died on Nov. 12 at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Morrisania, the Bronx.

title: DOW JONES TO TAKE $25 MILLION CHARGE
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it would take a $25 million charge in 1992 to cover accounting changes and write-downs at two publishing investments and will restate its financial statements for the first three quarters of 1992. The company said a charge of $8 million would be taken for reducing the book value of The Chapel Hill (N.C.) News and Groupe Expansion S.A., a French publishing group. "The idea is to call them what they're worth, as opposed to an inflated value," said Jan Abernathy, a spokeswoman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The organizers of a benefit for the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, N.J., had no idea when they asked DIONNE WARWICK to perform on Sunday that it was the 30th anniversary of the release of her first hit record, "Don't Make Me Over."

title: Many Questions Linger Following State Dept. Inquiry
description: A State Department official helped a Republican Congressman draft a letter seeking documents from Bill Clinton's passport files. James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff and former Secretary of State, knew about the search through Mr. Clinton's records but did nothing to stop it or punish those responsible. Mr. Baker's aides were kept informed of the operation, but made a concerted effort to avoid contact with those conducting the search.

title: Article 627292 -- No Title
description: Danal is not for the austere. Be prepared to be welcomed, embraced and joined at your table by waitress, owner and sometimes even chef, just as if you were eating Danal's fresh, delicious American fare in their living room.

title: Continental Air To Restore Pay
description: Continental Airlines told employees today that it would partly restore some of a pay cut imposed last summer, even though the airline will achieve less than half of the $108 million of savings intially sought from the wage reductions.

title: A West Side Book Fair To Benefit the Homeless
description: Thousands of new books will be sold at reduced prices this weekend at the sixth New York Book Fair for the Homeless at the Goddard Riverside Community Center, 593 Columbus Avenue, at 88th Street. A preview and auction will open the fair tonight at 6 P.M.; tickets are $30. Among the items up for auction are original New Yorker cartoons, theater tickets and restaurant dinners. In addition, the author Roy Blount Jr. will read from his works.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Curtains for a Candidate

title: Stray Bullet Hits Boy in Child-Care Center
description: An 8-year-old boy sitting at a play table in a Brooklyn child-care center was shot in the left arm yesterday when a bullet, fired during a dispute in the street outside, went through the center's front window, and struck the child after it ricocheted off an interior wall.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Farber Artists Space 223 West Broadway (near Franklin Street) SoHo Through Dec. 1

title: Ravel's Piano Music
description: The pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet is to perform the complete piano music of Ravel in two Sunday concerts at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue. This Sunday, the program will be "Serenade Grotesque," "Pavane pour une Infante Defunte," "Miroirs," "Sonatine" and "Gaspard de la Nuit." The second recital is scheduled for Dec. 6. Mr. Thibaudet used scores with Ravel's own annotations. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: James E. Fanning; Investments Manager, 54
description: James E. Fanning, former president of Rockefeller & Company, an investment-management firm, died Oct. 13 at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. He was 54 years old and had lived in Madison, N.J., for 21 years.

title: Topics of The Times; A Model Soviet General
description: When Mikhail Milstein died on a Moscow tennis court in August, his death received little notice in the U.S. He deserved more. For he was a contradiction in a land of contradictions: a Russian Jew who became aide-de-camp to Marshal Zhukov, Commander in Chief of the Red Army during World War II, only to be sidetracked in one of Stalin's anti-Semitic purges . . . a man of the system who managed to think his way out of it.

title: Chinese Angered by French Arms Sale to Taiwan
description: China warned today that it would "react strongly" if France or any other country sold jet fighters to Taiwan, but the French, the United States and possibly other Western nations seem to be quietly pushing ahead with military sales to the Chinese Nationalists.

title: THE TRANSITION: Political Notebook; Mrs. Bush Gives Mrs. Clinton a Tour, and Some First Advice
description: One has been described as a tough political insider who is fiercely protective of her husband's interests; the other has gained a reputation as a warm friend and devoted mother.

title: 2 Rival Irish Groups Vie for Parade Permit
description: Two Irish groups -- one favoring the inclusion of a gay and lesbian organization, the other maintaining its traditional opposition -- are competing for the permit to run next year's St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: Term Limits Set Us on the Road to Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title:
BASKETBALL;
As Hawks Stand Still, Nets Make Their Move
description: The Nets stayed competitive long enough to accept a gift from the Atlanta Hawks tonight, a 108-101 victory at the Omni.

title: A.T.& T.'s Leasing Unit to Go Public
description: A.T.& T. said yesterday that it planned to sell 15 percent of its huge equipment-leasing unit to the public by the second quarter of next year, the first such offering since 1983.

title: A National Book Award For a Gay Autobiography
description: Paul Monette won the National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday night for "Becoming a Man: Half a Life Story" (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich), an autobiography about his struggle to come to terms with his homosexuality, a work he said "literally kept me alive" after he discovered he had AIDS.

title: Honors
description: * Hal Riney, chairman and chief executive at Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, received the first George H. Gallup Discovery Award for marketing and communications contributions from the Gallup Organization, Princeton, N.J. * Phillip Joanou, chairman and chief executive at Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, was named Advertising Leader of the West by the American Advertising Federation, Washington.

title: Free Interfaith Concert To Recall Holocaust
description: The third annual Interfaith Concert of Remembrance, an homage to the victims of the Holocaust, will take place tomorrow evening at 8 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Maxim Shostakovich will lead the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra in the world premiere of the Epilogue from "David of Sassoun," by Michelle Ekizian, and in the American premiere of Stephen Lucky's Elegy for Violin, Cello and Orchestra. The program also includes Beethoven's First Piano Concerto, Shostakovich's Chamber Symphony and "Song Cycle From Jewish Folk Poetry," and Mahler's "Kindertotenlieder." In addition, the folk singer Richie Havens will offer "Songs of Freedom."

title: New York to Expand Use of Welfare Hotels
description: Facing contempt charges for leaving hundreds of homeless families to sleep in city offices, the Dinkins administration said yesterday that it is being forced once again to expand New York City's use of hotels to shelter the homeless.

title: Corruption Cited in Housing Repair Agency
description: An investigation by a New York City Council committee has found that the agency that renovates and repairs housing for the city's homeless has been rife with corruption that includes "systemic mismanagement and waste, large-scale theft and fraud, poor internal controls and a pervasive lack of accountability."

title: Seton Hall Scrapes Away Some Rust
description: Seton Hall, a team most experts pick to have a significant national impact this season, struggled early, then cruised to a 75-54 victory over Delaware tonight in a first-round game of the preseason National Invitation Tournament.

title: Miscellany
description: * DDB Needham Worldwide, Toronto, agreed in principle to buy Anderson Advertising, Toronto and Montreal. Anderson, which will remain autonomous, brings in Canadian account billings estimated at $30 million (United States). * Three Syracuse agencies -- Latorra Advertising; Paul, John & Lee, and Signet Advertising -- merged to form Latorra, Paul & McCann, with billings estimated at $14.6 million.

title: Old Friend Gives Knicks A Migraine
description: Mark Jackson got revenge tonight, and the Knicks got another loss.

title: Topics of The Times; New York's Global City Council
description: Forget about mundane local problems. Those world affairs experts on the New York City Council have struck again.

title: Hawaiian Coup of 1893
description: To the Editor:

title: New President Named For House of Seagram
description: Steven J. Kalagher, an 18-year employee of the Seagram Company, will be the next president of House of Seagram, the beverage giant's United States spirits subsidiary.

title: Jury Weighs Evidence In Assault On Athlete
description: Shannon Siegel shifted uneasily in his chair as his lawyer pointed to him and asked jurors, "Is this the kind of kid who's capable of attempted murder?"

title: U.S. Agents Limit Corruption Inquiry
description: The F.B.I. inquiry into the activities of Connecticut's Republican Party chairman during legislative votes on bank regulation in 1989 shows little sign of expanding into a full-scale corruption investigation of either the House or Senate, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Audi Planning Job Cuts
description: The German car maker Audi A.G., a subsidiary of the Volkswagen group, said today that it would cut 3,000 to 4,000 jobs at its Ingolstadt and Neckarsulm plants next year. This is more than 10 percent of its work force of 37,500 at those two plants.

title: Suspected Black Hole Shows Its Face
description: New photographs by the Hubble Space Telescope have given astronomers their best view yet of a huge disk of gas and dust being sucked into what they think is a black hole.

title: Suburban Life in the Hectic 1990's: Dinner Delivered
description: Once or twice a week, Judy Chabala and her family sit down to a hot dinner delivered to their Westfield, N.J., home from a local restaurant. Some nights it is a bucket of fried chicken; other nights, grilled shrimp with whole-grain mustard sauce from one of the fancier places in town.

title:
DIALOGUE: Rights and Foreign Policy;
Morality Is No Mantra
description: Bill Clinton's six major statements on foreign policy show that he shares with George Bush a grandiose vision of an American effort to create a new world order.
