title:
IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES;
Life in a Worn-Out Valley
description: Wendy Ewald went to Colombia in 1982 on a Fulbright fellowship to teach in the small Andean town of Raquira. She spent two years photographing the town, and encouraged her students to do the same. MAGIC EYES: Scenes From an Andean Childhood (Bay Press, 155 West Denny Way, Seattle, Wash. 98119, paper, $18.95) combines photographs taken by Ms. Ewald and her students with the stories of Maria Vasquez and her 28-year-old daughter, Alicia, two women Ms. Ewald met in Raquira. Alicia recounts a childhood spent living in the mountains with her grandparents, a childhood full of curses and magic, especially the power of the evil eye. As a young child she helped to harvest coffee. But the "worn-out valley . . . coughs up its young people -- the ones who make the progress -- to the city," and so Maria took Alicia to the slums of Bogota, a 26-hour bus ride away. The two women's lives are filled with violent, unreliable men, women who keep their families together with little or no education or resources, and children who learn early "a lot about justice and injustice." Deep-toned, almost sepia, the photographs -- such as views of the barrio, a dresser piled high with possessions, hands clasping a rosary -- combine Ms. Ewald's vision with those of her fifth-grade students, who took two-thirds of the shots, and convey a richness and dignity to the simplest objects. For readers who have never seen Latin American poverty, the images are indelible. "Magic Eyes" is moving, intimate and unsparing.

title: Wendy Cramer and Andrew Sanford
description: Robert Cramer of Washington and Susan Tofel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Sue Cramer to Andrew Beatty Sanford, a son of Richard C. Sanford of New York and Elizabeth B. Boocock of Basking Ridge, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: How to Tickle Male Chauvinist Pigs to Death
description: "A . . . MY NAME IS ALICE" WAS hardly the sharpest-toothed revue on the block when it opened eight years ago in the bowels of the American Place Theater. But it proved a bright and personable collection of songs and sketches with a firm, feminist slant and a cast you would have described as "a honey," if that weren't courting obvious trouble.

title: Leaks About Slain Officer Inappropriate, Kelly Says
description: The New York City Police Commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, acknowledged yesterday that police officials had inappropriately leaked information to the press indicating that a police officer shot to death in Queens earlier this month had had sex shortly before her death with the man accused of killing her.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian, Manhattan Style, in Mount Kisco
description: DINERS yearning for the hustle, bustle and cozy seating arrangements of Manhattan eateries will certainly be satisfied with the pace and closeness in this sleek, stylish, informal trattoria. Tables are crowded into the small space left by the open kitchen (with its wood-burning oven), which, with the tiny two- or three-stool bar (really a service counter), occupies fully half the room. Serving staff and folks waiting for takeout orders occupy any remaining inches. Everything is in full view, and most things perform the function of being decorative while being stored: a stuffed rooster casts a glassy eye over the cheery jumble of ropes of peppers and garlic, crates of eggs, baskets of breadsticks, bottles and cases of wine, quarts of olive oil, trays of desserts and chefs cooking madly.

title: Gorge and Be Well
description: A HISTORY OF FOOD By Maguelonne Toussaint-Samat. Translated by Anthea Bell. Illustrated. 801 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Blackwell Publishers. $39.95.

title: RAGE IN A TENURED POSITION
description: When I read last summer that Carolyn Heilbrun had resigned from Columbia rather than continue to be the token woman in a male chauvinist department, I was so excited that I called to congratulate her. Her stand seemed as courageous and honest as Anita Hill's ("Rage in a Tenured Position," by Anne Matthews, Nov. 8).

title: In the Region: Connecticut; South Norwalk Commercial Pump Primed
description: A ROLLER-COASTER economy over the last decade has taken the rehabilitation of South Norwalk to the heights of the mid-80's, the depths of the 90's and the occasional whiplash stop.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Stapleton
description: THE great boon that the Navy Homeport was to be for Stapleton has yet to materialize. Instead, the Staten Island community got a one-two punch: The Navy plan attracted speculators who drove real estate prices up and businesses out; then the recession sent the real estate market plunging.

title: Robin Westfield, David Briskman
description: Robin Anne Westfield, a management consultant, was married Thursday to David Klar Briskman, an industrial engineer. Judge Howard Spitz of New York State Family Court performed the ceremony at La Reserve in White Plains.

title: Second Terminal Opening at Narita
description: A second terminal at the New Tokyo International Airport in Narita, which handles two-thirds of all international flights in and out of Japan, is to begin operation next Sunday. The terminal is 1.65 times the size of the first terminal building and will be able to serve 10 million passengers a year, a Japanese tourist official said.

title: If Caterpillars Could Ski
description: It's doubtful that the Colorado Tourism Board got permission from the woolly bear caterpillar before making it the star of a campaign to advertise the state's ski slopes. No one has yet discovered a woolly bear caterpillar that skis. Those with any sense are sound asleep during the big snow months. But if any of them do ski, they're not likely to choose Colorado.

title: The Messages of Pearl Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lots of Muscle, and a Touch of Turgeon
description: In a game that had plenty of rough stuff, Pierre Turgeon added a sizable ration of skill and grace. He scored twice and assisted on another goal to pace the Islanders to a 9-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight before a big, happy throng at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Generals Over Their Heads
description: THIS TERRIBLE SOUND The Battle of Chickamauga. By Peter Cozzens. Illustrated. 675 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $39.95.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks Are Banging Doors, Bulls
description: A FRIEND of mine once told the story of how his high school coach motivated the team: Just before a big game, the coach locked the first string in the dressing room and said they couldn't start because of casual play in recent days.

title: Assessments
description: To the Editor:

title: Carwash Accepts Settlement
description: A DAVID AND GOLIATH struggle between the White Plains Hospital Medical Center and a carwash on hospital-owned land here has been settled amicably, freeing the hospital to begin a $54 million building project next year.

title: Jennifer Coleman, John H. Thieroff
description: Jennifer Ashe Coleman, a daughter of John J. Coleman of Dumont, N.J., and Mary Ellen Coleman of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to John Henry Thieroff, a son of Michael and Jean Thieroff of Lambertville, Mich. The Rev. Fred Hoseli officiated at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Crime
description: Something always seems to happen to spoil Homecoming, the traditional summer festival in the tiny Wisconsin town of Oakalla, where Garth Ryland owns and operates the local newspaper. Twenty years ago it was the disappearance of 13-year-old Paul Samuel; last year it rained; and now, when A DRAGON LIVES FOREVER (Barricade Books, 1530 Palisade Avenue, Fort Lee, N.J. 07024, $17.95) opens, Garth and the sheriff are hauling a bloated body out of Hidden Quarry.

title: Wrapped in Art
description: During the Edo period (1615-1868), Japan was isolated from the rest of the world but developed a flourishing culture. One of its most exquisite products was the elaborately dyed and embroidered kosode, or short-sleeved robe, similar to the modern-day kimono. WHEN ART BECAME FASHION: Kosode in Edo-Period Japan (Weatherhill, 421 Madison Ave., New York, N.Y. 10017, $60), with pages of color photos of kosode, is a companion book to an exhibit of some 150 of these garments at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art; it was written by two of the museum's curators, Dale Carolyn Gluckman and Sharon Sadako Takeda, with additional contributions by seven scholars. The Edo Japanese expressed their individual style not in the cut of their clothing, as in the West, but through their choice of surface decoration. Sumptuary laws, meant to regulate extravagant dress, in fact encouraged alternative design and dyeing techniques for kosode, making it the designer clothing of the age. Because the Japanese made no distinction between fine art and decorative art, the great artists of the day used kosode as their painting surfaces, creating robes that became supreme status symbols. Wordplay, Chinese pictograph characters and even poetry were incorporated into kosode design as well, creating what Ms. Takeda calls "a cloak of language that announced the sensibilities, desires and values of the owner." Perhaps this is the precedent for the often inscrutable English one sees on T-shirts, jackets and shopping bags in today's Japan.

title: Lisa Coleman and Jonathan Bradlow
description: Margret and Thomas Bonito of Livingston, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for her daughter, Lisa Margret Coleman, and Dr. Jonathan Avery Bradlow, a son of Frieda and Dr. Paul A. Bradlow of New York.

title: Q and A
description: Driving New Zealand

title: The Homeless Sharply Split Santa Monica
description: To some people here, Robert M. Myers is a hero, a man who stands up for those who have long ceased to stand up for themselves. To others, who fear and resent the homeless people crowding the city's otherwise impeccable streets and parks, Mr. Myers's outstretched hand has stretched too far.

title: New Moves On Abuse Of Elderly
description: "IT'S like a nightmare," the elderly woman said, her voice cracking with emotion. "You can't believe it happened to you when you tried to be a good parent."

title: Settling Disputes Without Litigation
description: IN the current recession, the pressure is on photographers and their clients to keep costs low by making deals and cutting corners, which makes the climate ripe for disagreements. The phrase "sue me" is being heard nearly as often as "nice shot."

title: Once a Husky Coach . . .
description: Washington's DON JAMES, who has been mentioned in the search for a new football coach at Auburn, says he has no intentions of leaving the Huskies -- as long as he's wanted.

title: A Celebration in Black
description: A CONSTANT procession of contemporary deities -- John Malkovitch, Paloma Picasso, Sandra Bernhard -- passed through the wrought iron gate and buzzed the doorbell (labeled Blanche DuBois and Stanley Kowalski) to enter the Lower East Side home and studio of the photographer Timothy Greenfield-Sanders last Monday night.

title: CURRENCY
Pastiche of Rodgers And Hammerstein
description: FOR the 50th anniversary of the collaboration of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, the Queens Theater in the Park is presenting "Some Enchanted Evening," a revue of their canon.

title: Public & Private; The Transition Trimester
description: A wise obstetrician once said a newborn baby is so unfinished that the first three months of its life constitute a kind of fourth trimester of gestation.

title: Shift for Urban Renewal: Nurture the Grass Roots
description: LaVerne Cooper and Deborah Gibson spend their days about two blocks apart in the Sandtown neighborhood, where pride is more memory than reality. But a chasm separates Mrs. Cooper, who has a job and will soon own her home, from Mrs. Gibson, a former heroin addict daunted by the demands of any given day.

title: The U.N. Celebrates Human Rights Vision
description: THE United Nations Postal Administration has issued its fourth-annual series of stamps honoring the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

title: Big Effort Makes Little Difference
description: What was an ailing Michael Jordan doing on the court until the final 2 minutes 57 seconds of the most lopsided defeat of his professional career? In retrospect, he didn't really know.

title: Whose Woods? Hunter vs. Homeowner
description: THE vivid hills of autumn, deeply carpeted with rustling foliage, offer unusual pleasures to thousands of campers, joggers and mountain-bikers who take to the trails in greater numbers each year.

title: Seminoles Pound, Then Root For Gators
description: The Florida State football team today provided a convincing argument for its participation in a national championship showdown.

title: God Save The Taxpayer
description: If anyone doubts 1992 has been "annus horribilis" for Britain's royal family, as Queen Elizabeth II herself complained last week, consider the harsh medicine Her Majesty prescribed to improve the monarchy's blotchy image.

title: Even for Ordained Women, Church Can Be a Cold Place
description: IN the business world, women often complain about "the glass ceiling," that invisible barrier that impedes their progress up the corporate ladder. In the religious world, women call it "the stained glass ceiling," a barrier that many contend is thicker, more opaque and less permeable.

title: Don't Tie Weimar Clinics to Nazi Horrors
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Economic Turmoil Persists, but Not Chaos
description: A year ago, the stories out of Moscow were full of dark warnings about starvation, destitution, chaos and coups as the Soviet Union lurched toward its end.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WHITE PLAINS;
A Breast Clinic Offers Women a 'More Coordinated Approach'
description: DR. Karen Arthur informs "about 50 percent" of her patients that she had a mastectomy 12 years ago. "The ones that say, 'My God, I have cancer, I'm going to die'; the ones who say, 'You don't understand'; the ones who feel they will never again live happy, productive lives -- those are the ones I tell."

title: Leaf Fall Connects Us to Cycle of Seasons
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Screenings Of Prostates
description: "As Population Ages, Prostate Cancer Takes High Toll on L.I." [ Sept. 13 ] listed the Strang Clinic -- our correct name is the Strang Cancer Prevention Center -- as a resource without mentioning why. Your readers might be interested to know that Strang, in conjunction with the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, is offering free screenings to men more than 45 years old who have a family history of prostate cancer.

title: How the President Lost: a Campaign of Disorganization and Disappointment
description: By the time the Republican Party massed in Houston last August for its convention, President Bush's re-election campaign appeared a thoroughly snakebit enterprise. In just eight months it had been jolted by an ugly primary fight, a third-party challenge, two White House staff shake-ups, an urban riot and a seemingly endless economic slump. Bill Clinton led in the polls by 15 points. Yet the President, his political advisers say, was utterly, serenely certain of victory come fall.

title: Coyotes Blamed for Rabies Outbreak in Texas
description: As frustrated state and local health officials in southern Texas struggle to contain the nation's first sustained outbreak of rabies among coyotes, ranchers in at least one county are being encouraged to shoot the animals on sight.

title: Elizabeth Sigety, Gerald Marcus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Sigety of Pipersville, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Snell Sigety to Gerald P. Marcus, a son of Elaine Marcus of Wayne, N.J., and the late Richard P. Marcus. A January wedding is planned.

title: Seton Hall Loses a Game but Picks Up Some Insight
description: One of the best things about a rigorous early-season basketball competition like the preseason National Invitation Tournament is that regardless of who wins, each team walks away having gained something valuable.

title: Ellis A. Rosen, Seth R. Lesser
description: Ellis A. Rosen, the public relations associate at the Children's Aid Society in New York, was married last evening to Seth Richard Lesser, an associate at the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Witnesses Sought in a Reported Carjacking
description: The Nassau County police said yesterday that they had found no suspects in a case involving a 73-year-old woman who said she foiled an attempt by two men to steal her car as she drove to a Thanksgiving dinner.

title: No Headline
description: Taking his first vacation since winning an exhausting one-year race for the Presidency, Bill Clinton spent most of a sunny and warm Southern California day resting at a multimillion-dollar oceanside estate leased for his use by friends.

title: RAGE IN A TENURED POSITION
description: I enjoyed your article, but was a bit perplexed by the final paragraph that describes Heilbrun as mysteriously alone in her study, "not entirely willingly." It adds a tone of sadness and defeat to what I read as a strong and sensible next step for a successful female scholar in Heilbrun's not-at-all-mysterious position at Columbia: Leave! With lots of publicity about the reason. SUSAN SCHAEFER DAVIS Haverford, Pa.

title: As Pay for Nurses Increases, So Does the Number of Men Entering the Field
description: Gary Welch, an industrial parts distributor, decided to change careers the night he went to Valley Children's Hospital here to watch his sister work.

title: Who Speaks for Malcolm X? The Writings of Just About Everybody
description: IN "The Autobiography of Malcolm X," the charismatic black religious nationalist recalls his momentous 1964 pilgrimage to Mecca, a visit that would alter the course of his life and career. For 12 years this minister of the Nation of Islam had been trumpeting a doctrine of the intrinsic evil of white people, likening the dream of American equality to a nightmare for American blacks and championing a plan to redeem black Americans by saving them from the tide of brainwashing that had drowned awareness of the black race's true superiority. But now Malcolm X writes of an incident in Jedda, in which he is treated with great hospitality by a man who, in the United States, would be considered white.

title: Bus-Fare Cuts Fail to Lure Queens Riders
description: Frustrated by the swarms of private vans in southeastern Queens that have siphoned away thousands of riders each day, and millions of dollars in revenue each year, the Transit Authority recently did something it had never done before: It cut the bus fare.

title: Farm-Stand Growth Faces New Scrutiny
description: LIKE zucchini blossoming wildly at the end of the summer, farm stands overran their boundaries this year, attracting hordes of customers. Now officials in the Town of Southampton are working on controlling them.

title: Time for Optimism to Be Abroad in the Land?
description: LAST week's economic reports -- consumer confidence, durable goods and gross domestic product -- suggested that a recovery worthy of the name might finally be gathering strength. Time for a more optimistic stock-buying strategy as well?

title: Sports of The Times; Jets Need Boomer. But Giants May Need A Quarterback, Too.
description: SHOULDN'T the Jets try to trade for Boomer Esiason in the off season? And have the Giants already begun to develop Kent Graham or Dave Brown as their next quarterback?

title: Multiculturalism Is Examined At the Hudson River Museum
description: THE Hudson River Museum under the direction of Philip Verre can definitely be rated new and improved. For one thing, the restaurant with the picture-window view of the Palisades has reopened; for another, the exhibitions are coming thick and fast. In the current crop is an excerpt from the permanent collection that is focused on the development of the Hudson River Valley. This, in turn, leads to the show celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Old Croton Aqueduct, without which New York City would probably have died on the vine from epidemics and fires.

title: Unions Brace for Fight Over County Contracts
description: UNION leaders furious over the Board of Legislators' refusal to ratify their contracts -- say their rank and file feel like pawns in a power struggle, betrayed by government leaders who "sat back in their ivory tower and played with other people's lives."

title: Russia, History and the Struggle Not to Repeat It
description: RUSSIA has been the object of two of the most extraordinary experiments in modern history. The first was the attempt to build a Communist society. The second is the effort to undo the enormous damage of the first, and to return Russia and the other shards of the Soviet empire to the mainstream of history.

title: Tech Notes; Waiter, a Wineglass List, Please
description: SOME call it science, some call it art, some call it nonsense. But to anyone willing to listen, Georg Riedel will say, "There is no all-purpose wineglass." Mr. Riedel, the 10th-generation proprietor of Riedelglas of Kufstein, Austria, designs and produces different glasses for different varietals.

title: Danger From Runoff To Drinking Water
description: Erwin Ernst has done much over the years to raise public awareness of pollution in our marine environment [ "Harsh Lesson of L.I. Waters," Nov. 15 ] . In identifying sewage-treatment plant effluent and lawn fertilizer runoff as major sources of nitrate contamination in coastal waters, he suggests curtailing the latter by building berms in front of lawns to prevent water from transporting fertilizers onto roads and thence into coastal waters via storm drains. Some nitrates in the trapped water would, he claims, then be absorbed by vegetation after seeping into the ground.

title: Staying Cool At Whoopi's Talk Show
description: Whoopi Goldberg is being Whoopi Goldberg, the home girl iconoclast with the metamorphic face and sandpaper voice, looking more Haight-Ashbury than Beverly Hills in her dreadlocks and granny glasses.

title: NOV. 22-27: Elections in Peru; A Vote of Confidence (Well, Sort Of)
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori's political allies won a majority of seats in Congress in elections last week, but did it mean the Peruvian President's seizure of near-dictatorial powers in April had been blessed by the people? The Japanese reacted as if it did, agreeing to give Peru $100 million in new loans. The United States said Peru was on the path back toward full democracy.

title: Elizabeth Lane, Stuart Zweighaft
description: Richard and Susan Lane of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Ann Lane and Stuart Jay Zweighaft, a son of Joyce Bartfield of Long Beach, L.I., and Dr. Harold Zweighaft of New York.

title:
All About: Condoms;
A Safe-Sex Product in Need of a Marketing Plan
description: JUST when it seemed that the fear of AIDS and the proliferation of safe-sex campaigns would make condoms as familiar as deodorant in stores and perhaps even in television commercials, signs of trouble are appearing for the industry.

title: . . . And His Movie For All Seasons
description: Fifty years ago, on Thanksgiving Day 1942, "Casablanca" opened in New York at the Hollywood Theater. But the film, directed by Michael Curtiz, didn't attract a cult following until 1957, as recounted in "Round Up the Usual Suspects: The Making of Casablanca" by Aljean Harmetz. An excerpt from the book, just published by Hyperion, tells how the phenomenon began.

title: Santos Ready to Return After Speedy Recovery
description: Jose Santos still winces when he thinks of the collision at Belmont Park on July 13 when three horses and three jockeys went down. He still misses the $400,000 he might have earned since then. He still wonders if the two metals pins and 14 screws have mended his fractured right arm so that he can control 1,000-pound race horses again.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Oct. 18 about the Supreme Court's declining to review the life sentence of the former Navy analyst Jonathan J. Pollard described his crime incorrectly. Mr. Pollard pleaded guilty to spying for Israel, not treason. Lawyers for Mr. Pollard first questioned the article on Oct. 23; publication of this correction was delayed by an editorial lapse.

title: Japan (Bush Backer) Tiptoes Around Clinton
description: The Japanese Government is spreading a quiet message to the hundreds of bureaucrats, businessmen and politicians who hop trans-Pacific flights every week to the United States: Visit your factories, play lots of golf, but stay out of Little Rock.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's Failed Campaign: 11 Weeks of Incoherence

title: Euro Disney
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from Paris and a day spent at Euro Disney. I was shocked to find that there were no bins to place bottles, cans, plastic cutlery or food containers for recycling. Is this indicative of French attitudes towards recycling, or is this typical of Disney theme parks in the United States as well? It seems environmentally wasteful to say the least. MICHAEL SHERNOFF New York, N.Y. Kym Murphy, vice president for environmental policy for the Walt Disney Company, responds: An office of environmental affairs has been established to deal with the issues at Euro Disney, which is 49 percent owned by our company. Here in the United States, environmental efforts continue. Recently a 30,000-square-foot materials recovery facility was put into service at Walt Disney World. This allows us to intercept, segregate and recycle a significant amount of the resort's waste. Our company has recycled nearly 33,000 tons of material this year.

title: Looking Beyond Brooklyn Heights Toward Heaven
description: The massive tan buildings stand sentinel near the ramps of the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges, greeting commuters with two bold signs: "Watchtower" and "Read God's Word The Holy Bible Daily."

title:
Viewpoints;
The Sirens of Investment Tax Credits
description: THE investment tax credit being considered by the incoming Administration is a new twist to an old idea. It looks good initially, but then the troubles accumulate.

title:
All About: Condoms;
A Safe-Sex Product in Need of a Marketing Plan
description: JUST when it seemed that the fear of AIDS and the proliferation of safe-sex campaigns would make condoms as familiar as deodorant in stores and perhaps even in television commercials, signs of trouble are appearing for the industry.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: NONFICTION
description: MEMORIES THAT SMELL LIKE GASOLINE By David Wojnarowicz. Artspace Books, 1286 Folsom Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94103, $15.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Dover, Del.; Highway Inn Expanding
description: A HOTEL that opened in this capital city two decades ago is undergoing a $4 million expansion designed to turn the highway lodging into a regional conference center.

title: Lauren Spergel, Stuart Baron
description: Dr. and Mrs. Martin Spergel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Renee Spergel, to Stuart David Baron, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Baron of Brooklyn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Q and A
description: Closing a Public Space Question: I understand that some high-rise buildings receive benefits from the city in return for creating pocket parks, plazas and other public spaces. A building in my neighborhood had such a park. Recently, the entrance to the park was permanently sealed off with large iron gates topped with razor wire, presumably to keep homeless people from living there. Is there a way to prevent the the arbitrary closing of these public spaces? . . . Durer Shomer, Manhattan. Answer: Yes. According to Robert Flahive, director of the Manhattan office of the Department of City Planning, arbitrary closing of such a space would be a violation of the zoning rules pertaining to bonus spaces.

title: L.I.R.R. Adds Parking Spots As Ridership Keeps Slipping
description: LIKE a spurned suitor trying to overcome rejection the Long Island Rail Road, with its lowest ridership in 10 years, is expanding its commuter parking to help sweeten its appeal.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Hand-Painted Perfection, Porcelain From Nyon
description: FOR those whose pulses don't quicken at the sight of hand-painted porcelain, there are all kinds of reasons to visit Nyon. The lakeside town that Julius Caesar founded 15 miles east of Geneva seems to take its perfectly groomed antiquity for granted, and travelers are free to do likewise. It's possible to while away a very diverting day climbing Nyon's steep medieval streets, admiring the view of Lake Geneva and the Alps across the tiled rooftops of the lower town, visiting the town's three museums, sitting in the cafes on the Rue de Rive drinking the local white wines the Swiss like too much to export.

title: 2D DAY OF VIOLENCE WRACKS VENEZUELA
description: Breaking a nervous calm that followed the unsuccessful coup attempt on Friday, rebellious Venezuelan policemen hijacked a civilian helicopter here today and raked the presidential palace and surrounding Government buildings with rifle fire.

title: Amy Penwell, S. W. McLaughlin
description: Amy Ruth Penwell and Steven William McLaughlin, who are both employed by New York investment companies, have announced February wedding plans.

title: Dual Classes Help Pupils Learn 2 Languages
description: IN a classroom at the Oakwood Primary Center in South Huntington a group of 19 kindergartners stood in a circle.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph on Nov. 15 with an article about "Home Alone 2" carried an incorrect credit. It should have read, "Andy Schwartz/20th Century Fox."

title: What We Need Money for and Where to Get It
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: THE DRAGONFLY FLINGBy Jean McKay.Coach House Press/InBook, Box 120261, East Haven, Conn. 06512,paper, $12.95.

title: John C. Daniel, 93; Admiral Had a Role In '53 Korean Truce
description: Vice Adm. John C. Daniel, retired, who played an important role in the negotiations that led to the exchange of wounded and ill Korean War prisoners and to the end of the war itself, died Monday at North Beach Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 93 years old.

title: Jennifer Chirlian, Stephen Wood
description: Jennifer Ann Chirlian, a daughter of John and Margaret Lloyd of Delungra, New South Wales, Australia, was married yesterday to Stephen Hollingsworth Wood, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wood of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. John Andrew, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Focus: Idaho Panhandle; 'Paradise' Seekers Drive Up House Prices
description: STANDING on the wooden porch of her daughter's alpine home in the pine forests of northern Idaho one recent chilly evening, 73-year-old June Rinck took a deep breath of clear mountain air and insisted she was standing on "a piece of paradise."

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'CANDLELIGHT EVENINGS'

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Pine Barrens Suit Frustrating Builders
description: RISING hopes that sales are improving has heightened the frustration of home builders over a suit that has delayed their projects within a 110,000-acre area of the central Pine Barrens for the last three years.

title: Nina Coleman, Andrew LeSueur
description: Janine Michelle Coleman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Coleman of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Jaquith LeSueur, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey C. LeSueur of Plymouth, Mass. The Rev. Mark Connolly performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Riverside, Conn.

title:
The Executive Life;
Riding Bush's Coattails Right Out of Their Jobs
description: DAWN Haley and her husband, Daniel, are about to lose their jobs. They know it will happen. They even know when: Jan. 20, 1993, around noon.

title: Gifts Destined For a Suitcase
description: IN gifts of travel gadgets, lighter is almost always better. But in the mind of the writer and former Metropolitan Museum curator Thomas Hoving, the fattest, heaviest model of the Swiss Army knife is the best one, despite its weight of seven ounces. "It is the most important thing I carry when I travel," Mr. Hoving said. "It has the miniature eyeglass screwdriver inside the corkscrew, which is the most vital item. You can go down to half the weight and give up the pliers, but I won't." He said that the scissors were also important.

title: Under Siege: Liquor's Inner-City Pipeline
description: T S LIQUOR does a brisk business on Jefferson Avenue in South Central Los Angeles, where the small, tidy store sells everything from diapers and panty hose to eggs and tortillas. And, of course, liquor -- a lot of it.

title: Jenny-Anne Martz, Galen R. Horst,
description: Jenny-Anne Martz, the public information coordinator for the American Association for Cancer Research in Philadelphia, was married on Friday to Galen R. Horst, the executive director of the Germantown (Pa.) Mennonite Church Corporation, a historic trust. The Mennonite ceremony took place at the Historic Mennonite Meetinghouse in Germantown.

title: Yankees Are Often a Pawn in Free Agents' Game
description: In the beginning, George Steinbrenner was No. 1 in the courting and signing of free agents. No one played the new game better than the Yankees' owner. His masterly recruiting efforts produced such players as Reggie Jackson, Don Gullett, Rich Gossage, Luis Tiant, Tommy John, Rudy May, Bob Watson and Dave Winfield and two World Series championships.

title: Immigrants' Faith Lifts the Housing Market
description: When Tricia and Philip Chen landed on American soil in 1990, having endured an eight-year wait to gain entry from their native Taiwan, buying a house was low on their list of family priorities, somewhere below becoming fluent in English and obtaining credit cards.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'CANDLELIGHT EVENINGS'

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: NONFICTION
description: THE DECLINE AND FALL OF THE AMERICAN EMPIRE By Gore Vidal. Odonian Press, Box 7776, Berkeley, Calif. 94707, paper, $5.

title: Eve L. Yohalem and Nicholas Polsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel H. Yohalem of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Eve Leslie Yohalem to Nicholas Andrew Polsky, a son of Judge and Mrs. Leon B. Polsky of New York. A January wedding is planned.

title: International Gala
description: The Spanish Institute presents awards at a dinner-dance, Nov. 24.

title:
ART REVIEW;
Fascination With Northwestern Indians
description: IN the closing years of the last century, many areas of the arts reflected the prevailing anti-industrial sentiment and nostalgia for simpler, purer, unspoiled modes of life. The interest in cultures that stood apart from Western progress kindled a widespread fascination with the American Indian.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Corrections
description: The Architecture View column on Nov. 15, about renovations planned for the CBS building in Manhattan, characterized the building's plaza incorrectly. While no entrance to the building faces the Avenue of the Americas, there are stairs from the avenue to the plaza.

title: Conversations/Leticia Quezada; L.A.'s Schools Chief Wants Power, And the Vote, for Immigrant Parents
description: LETICIA QUEZADA remembers that day 16 years ago when, as a Mexican immigrant fresh out of college with a teaching credential in bilingual education, she applied for work at the Los Angeles schools. She was turned down "flatly," told Los Angeles did not need bilingual teachers. Today Ms. Quezada greets visitors as the first Hispanic president of the Los Angeles Board of Education, presiding over a school system in which nearly half the students cannot speak English.

title: Little Rock, Big Time
description: "Welcome to the Center of the Universe," the woman said, then laughed at the absurdity of her greeting.

title: Taggart Whipple, Law Partner, 80, In Manhattan Firm
description: Taggart Whipple, an antitrust lawyer who was a longtime partner in the Manhattan-based firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, died on Thursday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: Emily Saltzman, David S. Hoffner
description: Emily Saltzman, a daughter of Herb and Joan Saltzman of New York, was married last evening to David Scott Hoffner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton Hoffner of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Cliff Culwin officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Explanation Asked for Higher Gasoline Prices
description: The New York State Energy Commissioner has asked oil companies and gasoline retailers in the New York City area and on Long Island to explain larger-than-expected price increases for cleaner-burning gasoline that went on sale this month under new state regulations intended to reduce air pollution.

title: The Art of the Insult
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatric Hospitals Faulted On Medication of Children
description: State-run psychiatric hospitals for children typically fail to notify parents about the medications they give their patients and often prescribe drugs to control tantrums rather than as part of a treatment program, a New York State watchdog agency has found.

title: Talking: Paydowns; Reducing Mortgage Principal
description: ABOUT two years ago, Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH, a mortgage monitoring and advisory service in Butler, N.J., decided to personally try out an idea increasingly being promoted in his industry: making additional principal payments each month so the balance of his home mortgage could be paid off faster.

title: Poised in Haiti: 2 Kinds of Refugee With a Single Goal
description: IN the shade of an unfinished vessel that will almost certainly one day spirit Haitians off on a clandestine journey toward the United States, two distinct voices of desperation can be heard.

title: Joan Baez, the First Lady of Folk
description: Until recently, people were asking Joan Baez, "Do you still sing?"

title: Deeper Dish
description: FOR YEARS IT HAS BEEN impossible to utter the word "casserole" in polite company. It evokes tuna and noodles, macaroni and cheese, green beans and cream of mushroom soup -- all gooey and bound in perpetuity. Underneath these culinary cliches lurks the good mother of the 50's. The one who sought to be thrifty, efficient and creative in her nurturing, the one who wound up locked in Ozzie and Harriet land, unable to move past the canvas of a Corning Ware dish, the palette of a can of Campbell's soup, the mushy dominion of which she was queen.

title: L.I.R.R. Adds Parking Spots As Ridership Keeps Slipping
description: LIKE a spurned suitor trying to overcome rejection the Long Island Rail Road, with its lowest ridership in 10 years, is expanding its commuter parking to help sweeten its appeal.

title: NOV. 22-27: Runoff in Georgia; The Republicans Win A Senate Seat
description: The victory of a Republican, Paul D. Coverdell, over a one-term Democratic incumbent, Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., in a runoff election in Georgia last week was freighted with great political significance by Republicans while Democrats scorned it as a triumph of mudslinging. Georgians were also left to ponder the vagaries of the runoff system itself.

title:
MUSIC;
Giving New Life to Neglected Works
description: FOR John Eric Floreen, a conductor and associate professor of music at Rutgers-Newark, hundreds of hours spent researching neglected 18th-century composers have a practical purpose. Dr. Floreen's mission is to give unknown 18th-century works a first hearing for today's audiences, and he has been doing so for several years.

title: New York City's Deadliest Intersections
description: Traffic fatalities involving pedestrians in New York City have dropped to the lowest level in five years, but two hit-and-run accidnts on the Grand Concouse in the Bronx this month have drawn attention to unsafe intersections on that street.

title: Glimpses of Prague
description: ON THE SKY'S CLAYEY BOTTOM

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MATTER OF TIME

title: Eurailpass Cost To Go Up in '93
description: Eurailpass has announced increased prices for all its passes in 1993 and changes in how its Eurail Flexipasses will be used. From Jan. 1 all Eurail Flexipasses will allow travelers to use their 5, 10 and 15 days of train travel time over an expanded period of two months instead of 15 days, 21 days or one month. Three new Eurail Youth Flexipasses also include the same validity periods. Youth passes, for travelers aged under 26, allow unlimited train travel in 17 European countries in second class. All other passes are for first class.

title: Feeding Birds and the Uninvited Squirrels
description: GARDENERS can be thankful for the birds that will hang around during the next few months. The birds are not only delightful and colorful to see but also continue to eat insect grubs and eggs, or any morsels they can find. Gardeners who place feeders near the windows find these feathered friends a pleasure to watch, especially at breakfast.

title: WESTCHESTER Q&A;: PRISCILLA HAMBRICK-DIXONEthnic Pride vs. Ethnic Chauvinism
description: IT is not uncommon to find T-shirts, banners and other items in stores and catalogues proclaiming the likes of "Irish make the best mothers" or "Italian and proud of it" or "Jews make the best mothers" or "Black and proud of it." It is also not uncommon to hear ethnic slurs from one group toward another and read about ethnic and racial hate crimes -- caused at least to some degree because one group feels it is better than another.

title: Trade New World; As It Comes Together, It's Pulling Apart
description: In these waning days of the Bush Administration, with the Clinton regime still unborn, two competing forces are at work in the world, one pushing nations closer together and the other ripping them apart.

title: Robin Strauss, Ira Rashbaum
description: Robin Suzanne Strauss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Strauss of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married on Thursday to Dr. Ira Glenn Rashbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rashbaum of Huntington, L.I. Rabbi David Nesenoff performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: Choosing, and Losing, an H.M.O. Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WHERE TO CUT A TREE

title: New Haven Finds Offense Just in Time
description: Accustomed to playing in small stadiums, the University of New Haven put its high-scoring and undefeated team on display today at the Yale Bowl.

title: Business Diary
description: THE ECONOMY Maybe This Time Recovery Was Just Around the Corner

title: A Great Lover and a Great Reader
description: MAQROLL

title: Allison Lewis, F. H. Brooks Jr.
description: Allison Gayle Lewis, a computer programmer, was married yesterday evening to Frederic H. Brooks Jr., a business executive. Rabbi Jordan Parr performed the ceremony at the Radisson Riverfront Inn in Augusta, Ga.

title:
FILM;
Curtiz: A Man for All Genres . . .
description: If the double features shown at your favorite revival house paired "Casablanca" with "Yankee Doodle Dandy" or "Mildred Pierce" and "The Adventures of Robin Hood," you might deduce that the management was deranged -- before remembering all of them had the same director. These titles barely hint at the dizzying scope of the work of Michael Curtiz (1888-1962). More than 50 of his movies are being shown at a Museum of Modern Art retrospective, where lovers will be separated by global war, James Cagney will dance stiff-legged in the manner of George M. Cohan, a man shot full of bullets will fall gasping a woman's name, and Errol Flynn will swagger laughing through Sherwood Forest.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 29, 1992
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 MIXED BLESSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $23.50.) Three couples' lives are strained by the problems of having children. 2 2 6 THE TALE OF THE BODY THIEF, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $24.) Lestat embarks on a dangerous enterprise; "The Vampire Chronicles," continued. 3 6 4 MEXICO, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $25.) While researching the lives of his ancestors, an American journalist learns about the history of the land south of the border. (LP) 4 5 7 THE STARS SHINE DOWN, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $23.) The fortunes of a businesswoman are imperiled by secrets from her past. (LP) 5 4 5 MOSTLY HARMLESS, by Douglas Adams. (Harmony, $20.) The autobiography of the general who commanded the allied forces in the gulf war. 4 4 6 I CAN'T BELIEVE I SAID THAT! by Kathie Lee Gifford with Jim Jerome. (Pocket, $22.) The autobiography of the co-host of the television show "Live With Regis and Kathie Lee." 5 5 13 EVERY LIVING THING, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Aspects of Taoist philosophy explained through the actions of an A. A. Milne character. 11 8 27 THE SILENT PASSAGE, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $16.) The psychological and social significance of menopause for today's women. 12 12 4 GENIUS, by James Gleick. (Pantheon, $27.50.) The life and achievements of Richard Feynman, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. 13 11 24 TRUMAN, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A biography of the 33d President. 14 15 5 THE CHANGE, by Germaine Greer. (Knopf, $24.) An extensive survey of the physical, psychological and social effects of menopause. 15 13 13 YOUNG MEN & FIRE, by Norman Maclean. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) An account of a disastrous fire in a Montana forest in 1949. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 20 HARVEY PENICK'S LITTLE RED BOOK, by Harvey Penick with Bud Shrake. (Simon & Schuster, $19.) Anecdotes and tips about golf. 2 6 10 THE MEASURE OF OUR SUCCESS, by Marian Wright Edelman. (Beacon, $15.) Rules to live by. 3 3 9 THE AMERICAN HERITAGE DICTIONARY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE. (Houghton Mifflin, $39.95.) The third edition. 4 * 5 39 A RETURN TO LOVE, by Marianne Williamson. (HarperCollins, $25.) Inspirational advice. 5 2 9 ARE YOU THE ONE FOR ME? by Barbara De Angelis. (Delacorte, $21.) How to choose and keep the right partner in love and marriage. 6 * 4 10 LIFE'S LITTLE INSTRUCTION BOOK, by H. Jackson Brown Jr. (Rutledge Hill, $12.95.) Some 500 tips for achieving a self-fulfilling life. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,050 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large print.

title: Peace Is a Bookshelf Away
description: Here is Benjamin Hoff, little known best-selling author of "The Te of Piglet" and "The Tao of Pooh," going bump bump bump down the road, carrying two passengers, a 1971 Oregon road map and a cargo of birdseed and laundry.

title: Ho, Ho, Ho
description: Barneys unveils its holiday windows and caricatures, Nov. 23.

title: Hailing New 'Lucia'
description: The Metropolitan Opera Guild holds a benefit at the premiere of the production, Nov. 19.

title: When All They Really Want Is Seafood
description: ONE of the most frequently asked questions we encounter is "Where can I find a good seafood restaurant?" Anyone in the Hartford area might supply a quick answer: the Capitol Fish House.

title: Couples Is Remaining Right on Course
description: As powerfully as Fred Couples can pulverize a golf ball, as much as his game has matured and as much as he has manhandled the PGA Tour in the last two seasons, his unique appeal is that -- in an anxiety-ridden profession -- he projects the native, uncomplicated grace of a gifted child.

title: What We Need Money for and Where to Get It; Fixing Unemployment
description: To the Editor:

title: GERMANY CREATING POLICE UNIT AIMED AT RIGHTIST GROUPS
description: Germany will create a new police unit to monitor and combat far-right groups, the Federal police chief said today. The announcement came a day after the Government officially banned a neo-Nazi group in a response to the outcry against anti-foreigner violence.

title: N.H.L. Considers An N.B.A. Officer
description: Gary B. Bettman, third in command at the National Basketball Association, is one of two finalists for the newly established job of commissioner of the National Hockey League, according to a hockey team owner who is a member of the search committee and an influential voice on the league's board of governors.

title: NOV. 22-27: Neo-Nazi Challenge; Killings Prompt Germany To Crack Down
description: The killings of three Turkish citizens in a firebombing last week increased the pressure on the German Government to show that it is not ignoring the challenge posed by spreading rightist violence, and by the end of the week it responded by banning a neo-Nazi organization. Interior Minister Rudolf Seiters suggested there would soon be more such bans.

title: U.N. INVESTIGATING CROATS' GRAVE SITE
description: A United Nations war-crimes commission has decided to dig up a cornfield near here that investigators say could be a mass grave. Officials say the field could hold the bodies of 300 people believed to have been killed by Serbian military men last year.

title: Sound Bytes; A Wireless Widget Master
description: BILL CAMPBELL is no stranger to challenges. Armed with degrees in economics, he spent six years (1974-79) as head football coach at Columbia University, there compiling a 12-41-1 record (even so, it was better than any coach since then).

title: What Hath Ureli Corelli Hill Wrought?
description: FOR 99 YEARS BEFORE THE Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor and the 51 years since, the now infamous date Dec. 7 has carried happier significance for the New York Philharmonic and its extended family of listeners. On Dec. 7, 1842, the 63-member orchestra of the Philharmonic Society of New York presented its first concert, to about 600 listeners in the Apollo Rooms on lower Broadway. Three conductors took part, including the orchestra's founder, Ureli Corelli Hill, who led Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. Though not the first orchestra in the United States, the Philharmonic has survived and thrived to become the oldest.

title: Grand Illusions
description: Bergdorf's toasts a trompe-l'oeil holiday, Nov. 24.

title: Carolyn Thompson and Glenn Garrison
description: Carolyn Jean Thompson, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. George Thompson of Bellevue, Neb., was married there yesterday to Glenn Thomas Wilson Garrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Garrison of Shiloh, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Ward performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Escape Hatch For Commuters
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Sarah Lawrence Expansion; A New Science Center
description: Sarah Lawrence College, in Bronxville, N.Y., began construction last month on a three-story, 2,500-square-foot Science Center, its first new academic building in 20 years.

title: Nutritionists Urging Schools To Offer All Pupils Breakfast
description: RUMBLING stomachs, short attention spans, poor test scores, more colds and school days missed, behavioral problems in the classroom. These, nutritionists say, are the consequences of children coming to school without a nourishing breakfast.

title: From Geo, a Second-Generation Prizm
description: PITY the poor consumer who wants an American car. Some full-size Chevies and Mercurys are built in Canada. Some of Ford's popular Escorts are made in Mexico. The Dodge Stealth is made in Japan. Pontiac's LeMans comes from Korea, and nearly every new automobile carries parts from all over the world.

title: Operation Balkan Storm: Here's a Plan
description: Here's how the Balkan crisis could unfold.

title:
All About: Condoms;
A Safe-Sex Product in Need of a Marketing Plan
description: JUST when it seemed that the fear of AIDS and the proliferation of safe-sex campaigns would make condoms as familiar as deodorant in stores and perhaps even in television commercials, signs of trouble are appearing for the industry.

title: At Work; New Generation Feeling the Fire
description: GRADUATION day, a bittersweet time for most college seniors and parents as they look backward and forward, may have provided Derrick Diggs's parents with one alarmingly bittersweet moment last spring. They assumed their talented son had spent some part of his last year at Morehouse College in Atlanta applying to graduate schools or looking for a job, as most anxious seniors do.

title: Data Update

OUTDOORS;
A Pre-Holiday Turkey Hunt That Wasn't
description: About the only thing left of Thanksgiving is the food hangover, but I still can't stop thinking about turkeys -- not the store-bought critters that most of us ate, but wily, wild birds, the ones whose drumsticks are too tough to eat after just one stint in the oven because the birds actually walk on them.

title: Perspectives: Public Construction; The Courts Pipeline Is Starting to Flow
description: IT has taken five years, but the first tangible evidence of New York City's long-term court-building program -- apparently the largest by any city or state in the country -- is showing itself in Queens and the Bronx.

title:
Your Own Account;
Stumping the Pension Experts
description: MOST taxpayers feel that tax rules are unnecessarily complex, the better to trip them up. But public employees, those who work for nonprofit institutions and others who invest in retirement plans that are named for section 403(b) of the Internal Revenue Code have real reason to complain. The rules for withdrawing money from these plans have been so wrapped in confusion that even many experts get them wrong, recommending a course of action that is less favorable to the taxpayer than what the Internal Revenue Service will allow.

title: How Brokers Make Do In the Sluggish Market
description: CHARLES DARWIN called it natural selection. For Herbert Spencer, it was the survival of the fittest. But whatever one terms it, it's what has been happening in recent years to brokers and sales agents as the downturn in the real estate market has both diminished their numbers and required those who have remained to adopt different strategies, or variations of old ones, to stay alive.

title: The St. Lawrence
description: To the Editor: Pamela J. Petro's tempting article about three islands in the St. Lawrence River ("Old World Isles in the St. Lawrence," Sept. 13) have undoubtedly "discovered" these Quebecois havens for many future tourists to Canada. After two extended respites on Ile d'Orleans, just outside of Quebec City, my wife and I are worried that the island is no longer our secret.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19 GERMANY PLANS VIGIL ON RIGHTISTS Germany will create a police unit to monitor and combat far-right groups, and it will probably be devoted principally to observing and penetrating the groups. 1 A DIG FOR BODIES IN CROATIA A United Nations war-crimes commission has decided to dig up a cornfield in Croatia that investigators say could be a mass grave. 1 U.N.'S LUSTER FADES A LITTLE News Analysis: Despite U.N. success in defusing conflicts in Nicaragua and Namibia, other peace initiatives seem to be faltering. 1 RUSSIANS ARE GETTING BY Russia has tough economic problems, yet there is little unemployment and more than adequate supplies of food in the stores. 3 DAY 2 IN CARACAS The day after a failed coup in Venezuela, a helicopter fired on the presidential palace, leading to exchanges of gunfire through the capital. Officials said foyr rogue policemen aboard the copter were killed. 7 A KEY TO SOMALIA AID A major goal of an American military operation in Somalia would be to secure Mogadishu port, the main entry point for grain. 16 KOREAN FLIGHT TAPE MISSING A South Korean official said the tape was missing from a flight-data recorderof the airliner shot down over Soviet territory in 1983. 9 TOKYO KEEPING ITS DISTANCE Japan advises its bureaucrats and businessmen visiting the U.S. not to be too eager to court the Clinton administration-in-waiting. 18 TRIAL FOR FRENCH COLLABORATOR The French Supreme Court ruled Paul Touvier could stand trial for crimes against humanity for his role in the execution of seven Jewish hostages in 1944. 13 National 22-40 A SENATOR AND A SAVINGS CASE Senator Gramm of Texas helped guide a Dallas savings and loan operator in dealings with Federal regulators one year after the executive had helped pay for work on the Senator's vacation home. 1 A MULTI-FRONT WAR ON POVERTY An effort now under way in Baltimore offers a glimpse at a wide array of strategies aimed at helping inner-city residents meet the demands of home ownership. 1 THE FAILED CAMPAIGN As Bush campaign officials tell it, the President's re-election drive struggled with bouts of breathtaking incoherence. 26 At an oceanside estate, Clinton finally spent a day relaxing. 26 NEW ROLES, BUT WHICH ONES? How will the President-elect define the tasks of the nation's intelligence agencies? At this point, few answers could be more elusive. 28 MORE MEN TURN TO NURSING Lured by rising pay and a sense of excitement, more men than ever are in training to become registered nurses. 22 New Orleans Journal: A century after one battle, another one. 22 When motel security is found to be racial bias. 23 A rabies outbreak is leading to the shooting of Texas coyotes. 25 Descendants of Jews who fled the Inquisition gathered. 28 Santa Monica is at war with itself over the homeless. 31 Graduate instructors are on strike at Berkeley. 32 Two officers in the Dahmer case failed to win reinstatement. 35 Metro 41-55 CLASSES FOR GIFTED CUT As financially pressed school districts in the New York region struggle to cope with declining aid and rising costs, programs for gifted and talented students are being trimmed, gutted or eliminated. 1 FIGHTING TO FILL BUS SEATS Six weeks after the Transit Authority cut the bus fare in central Queens, hopes are evaporating that thousands of riders will be lured back from more expensive private vans. 41 BUYING AN AMERICAN DREAM Large numbers of immigrants to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have become homeowners. Analysts say their buying is fueled by a belief that ownership represents full enfranchisement in American society. 41 SECT FLOURISHES IN BROOKLYN The Jehovah's Witnesses have pieced together a small real estate empire in downtown Brooklyn, creating a virtually self-sustaining community and forging an uneasy co-existence with their neighbors. 41 NEEDIEST CASES CAMPAIGN BEGINS The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 81st annual campaign today. 44 Oil companies urged to explain high gasoline prices. 42 Faces from Queens or faces from history? 43 Growing gang problems in Connecticut. 48 Parents await Hartford segregation trial. 48 Agency faults state psychiatric hospitals. 51 Obituaries 54 Neediest Cases 44

title: 'Paradise' Seekers Drive Up Idaho Prices
description: Standing on the wooden porch of her daughter's alpine home in the pine forests of northern Idaho one recent chilly evening, 73-year-old June Rinck took a deep breath of clear mountain air and insisted she was standing on "a piece of paradise."

title: Elaine Eraklis, Jaap L. Tonckens
description: Elaine Katherine Eraklis, a lawyer in Paris, was married yesterday to Jaap Cornelis Warmolt Lunsingh Tonckens, an associate in Paris for the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling.

title: Pushing All the Hot Buttons
description: TIME WARNER, THE WORLD'S biggest media and entertainment company, has a problem. It's not the company's bottom line or the struggle over who is in charge. This time it's Time Warner's reputation. Are its profits and principles on a collision course?

title: Two Are Dead, but Race Goes On
description: The news last week that two round-the-world sailing competitors, Mike Plant of the United States and Nigel Burgess of Britain and Monaco, were dead at sea had a devastating effect on many of the yachtsmen still racing in the Vendee Globe Challenge.

title: Leonard Cohen, the Lord Byron of Rock-and-Roll
description: Leonard Cohen has stopped to smell a rose. He was in the middle of a train of thought, sitting at a table in a piano lounge of a ritzy hotel in midtown Manhattan. But the lure of blood red petals, the possible prick of thorn and the whiff of romance have proven irresistible. He leans forward, bends the stem toward him and breathes. The fragile petals contrast sharply with the chisled age of his face. The strong reds and greens accentuate his iron-gray hair and tailored charcoal suit.

title: Agreement on an Indian Claim Opens New Areas of Dispute
description: GOVERNMENT negotiators offered cash and miles of public and private lands in Arizona last week to bring peace to the Hopi and Navajo tribes. But as soon as the proposed settlement was made public, it ignited a new battle in and out of the Government between those anxious to end the torment of two ancient peoples and others who said it would set a bad precedent for using valuable public lands to settle Indian claims.

title: Karen Fox, William Barrett
description: Karen Fox, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Robert Fox of Dover, Del., was married there yesterday to William Sisson Barrett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John T. Barrett of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Gregory M. Howe performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church.

title: Data Bank/November 29, 1992

NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Bus Terminal Work Begins
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on an $81.4 million downtown bus terminal that will provide one center for commuter and regional bus transportation.

title: It's Summer in Montreal Biodome
description: Even on cold winter days, vistors to Montreal may opt for warm-weather attire when they visit the tropical rain forest in the city's newest tourist attraction, the Biodome.

title: Barbie to the Max on Madison Avenue
description: THE new Barbie on Madison boutique at the F. A. O. Schwarz toy store is a panorama of pink. Until recently the domain of Ninja Turtles, the store's downstairs area has been given over to one of America's most popular icons -- the big-haired, wasp-waisted, flounced-to-kill Barbie doll -- and all her accouterments.

title: This Land Is Your Land . . . This Land Is My Land
description: SANTA MARIA DE OSTUMA IN THE cool mountains of Matagalpa in northwestern Nicaragua is a deceptively peaceful spot, regardless of who, at any given moment, is controlling the farm's 1,500 acres of sweeping valleys, mountaintops and hillsides covered with coffee bushes. Just off the highway, on the road to the farm, a few dozen soldiers in battle dress lounge about, some sleeping in the middle of the road. More surprised than hostile on seeing a vehicle, they move aside good-naturedly, saying they were dispatched the previous week because of rumors that

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: ZAPATA ROSE IN 1992 And Other Tales. By Gary D. Keller. Maize Press/Bilingual Press, Hispanic Research Center, Arizona State University, Tempe, Ariz. 85287, paper, $14.

title: Fighting Mafia in Sicily Under Shadow of Death
description: Since he and his colleagues ordered the biggest roundup of Mafiosi in eight years last week, Paolo Giordano has been expecting "a reaction" from the mob. But that, he said, is part of his job tracking down the "men of honor," as mafiosi are called here.

title: Rembrandt Peale: Predestined To Be a Painter
description: How could he not have been a painter? The son of a painter, he was christened Rembrandt. His brothers were christened Raphael, Titian and Rubens. His sisters were named after three eminent women painters -- Angelica Kauffmann, Sofonisba Anguisciola and Rosalba Carriera. He named his own son Michael Angelo.

title: Carolyn Donohoe and Thomas Marieb
description: Carolyn Marie Donohoe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Donohoe of Potomac, Md., was married there yesterday to Thomas Norman Marieb, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Marieb of Orange, Conn. Msgr. Robert P. Mohan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Mercy.

title: Hensley Evans, Michael Abert
description: Mr. and Mrs. George J. Evans Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Mary Hensley Evans, and Michael Bruce Abert, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James G. Abert of Washington.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FLOW CHART, by John Ashbery. (Knopf, $13.) In a 216-page poem that our reviewer, Marjorie Perloff, compared to Wordsworth's "Prelude," John Ashbery shows how even the minutiae of television broadcasts, telephone calls and other daily interruptions can become the stuff of poetry. Of his long works, "perhaps none is quite so various, so beautiful and so new as 'Flow Chart,' " she said last year.

title: Turf Wars in New Mexico
description: ALBURQUERQUE

title: Low-Cost Stays in Czech Homes
description: NO longer are foreign visitors to Czechoslovakia wholly at the mercy of Cedok, the travel agency formerly run by the government. No longer is their choice of accommodations limited to dreary, exorbitantly priced hotels that only an apparatchik could love.

title: Leslie Greenberg and Wayne Josel
description: LESLIE GREENBERG, 29 years old, was determined to look bridal, even though she had been married before and had often been told that second brides should wear something more akin to a gray Mao suit.

title: Commercial Property: Retailer's Recession Strategy; Opportunity Drives Kmart's Expansion
description: LAST spring, the Kmart Corporation went looking for 15 acres or so in suburban Detroit on which to build a 108,000-square-foot Pace Warehouse Club. What it found instead was 35 acres in nearby Utica, Mich., at a major highway intersection a quarter mile west of a big regional mall.

title: A Fast Journey To 2 Celebrations
description: A supersonic splurge that allows travelers to ring in the New Year twice for the princely sum of $14,000 a person has been organized by Atlantic Time Tunnel, a British tour operator that has chartered a Concorde.

title: What We Need Money for and Where to Get It; Economic Council
description: To the Editor:

title: On Being 'Colored,' an Invention of Apartheid, in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Miriam Judlowe, Lorin Reisner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Judlowe of Murray Hill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Miriam S. Judlowe to Lorin L. Reisner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira A. Reisner of Suffern, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: New Group Speeds Food to the Hungry
description: As the director of Island Harvest, a newly formed prepared-and-perishable-food program on Long Island, I appreciate your thoughtful reporting about the hungry on Long Island. Island Harvest is a network of volunteers who pick up unserved fresh or prepared food from restaurants, caterers, convenience stores, groceries, bakeries, etc. This food would normally be thrown away, because, while still quite edible, it is not as fresh as the business requires for sale to its customers. The food is then delivered to local soup kitchens, homeless shelters and other not-for-profit tax-exempt agencies that feed people in need.

title: London Fashion: An S O S
description: LONDON fashion is an endangered species.

title: A Heisman Duel Is Reduced to a Hurricane Tuneup
description: Gino Torretta didn't strike a pose. That is not his style, and on the night of the Heisman confrontation that never happened, this was not the time and place.

title:
ART;
Nick and Nora of the Abstract
description: GEORGE L. K. MORRIS (1905-1975) and his wife, Suzy Frelinghuysen (1911-1988), are a lot like Nick and Nora Charles. They were an upper-class couple and comrades as well as man and wife. In a photograph he looks dapper like William Powell, and in another picture she is ready to pour the contents of a cocktail shaker into two glasses.

title: The Mayor Of Passaic Is Convicted Of Corruption
description: Joseph Lipari, the Mayor of Passaic, N.J., was convicted today on two charges of extortion and five counts of income tax evasion after a five-week corruption trial in Federal District Court. At the same time, the jury found him not guilty of seven other extortion charges.

title: A New Wine Cellar Stocked With Vintage Choreography
description: PINNING DOWN THE FLEETING art of movement is no easy task. But it can be done. As proof, the Dance Notation Bureau has a little list.

title:
THEATER;
A Comedy Writer Remembers Her Favorite Years
description: Writing comedy is like trying to catch mercury in a sieve. Impossible, though it has been done. The 1982 comic film "My Favorite Year" described the process and used as an example a live television comedy program not unlike "Your Show of Shows."

title:
CUTTINGS;
That Hardy Perennial the Seed Catalogue
description: THE wish books are rolling in: the annual flood of seed catalogues, with their bright pictures and breathless descriptions of marvels that could be growing in my garden next year.

title: Libya Faces More Sanctions at a Precarious Time
description: The French Foreign Ministry issued a statement this week raising the specter of further sanctions against Libya at a time when the country is reeling from rising economic chaos, deepening isolation within the Arab world and a new series of strange pronouncements by its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bethpage L.I. $150,000 340 Martin Place 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,300. Copiague $220,000 72 Shore Drive South 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 9-year-old ranch; fireplace, 1-car attached garage, 116- by 125-foot lot, water view; taxes $6,400. East Norwich $210,000 30 Gilbert Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,300. Lindenhurst $137,000 600 Heathcote Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800.
